H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if :
:( H^- )^âˆ˜ = âˆ…
where H^- denotes the closure of H and H^âˆ˜ denotes its interior.


That is, H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if  the interior of its closure is empty.

Another way of putting it is that H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if  it consists entirely of boundary.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


H is nowhere dense in T  if and only if :
:H^- contains no open set of T which is non-empty
where H^- denotes the closure of H.

title: Definition:Densely Ordered
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.


Then ( S, â‰¼) is defined as densely ordered  if and only if  strictly between every two elements of S there exists another element of S:

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a â‰º b âˆƒ c âˆˆ S: a â‰º c â‰º b
where a â‰º b denotes that a â‰¼ b but a  b.


=== Densely Ordered Subset ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.


A subset T âŠ† S is said to be densely ordered in ( S, â‰¼)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a â‰º b âˆƒ c âˆˆ T: a â‰º c â‰º b

title: Definition:Dense (Lattice Theory)
definition:
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

=== Dense Element ===
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

Let x âˆˆ S.


Then x is dense  if and only if 
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ S: y  x âˆ§ y

where  denotes the smallest element in L.

=== Dense Subset ===
Let L = ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a bounded below meet semilattice.

Then A is dense  if and only if  it includes only dense elements.

That means that  if and only if  âˆ€ x âˆˆ A: x is a dense element.

Category:Definitions/Lattice Theory

title: Definition:Mass Density
definition:
Mass density is a physical quantity.

The mass density of a body is its mass per unit volume.

Mass density is a scalar quantity.


For a homogeneous body it is found by finding its total mass and dividing it by its total volume:
:Ï =  m V
where:
:m is the body's mass
:V is the body's volume

However, if the substance of the body varies throughout, then its mass density may be a function of position within the body.


=== Symbol ===


=== Dimension ===
The dimension of (mass) density is ğ–¬ ğ–«^-3: mass per unit volume.


Category:Definitions/Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of mass density are kg m^-3 (kilograms per cubic metre).

* The CGS units of mass density are g cm^-3 or, less formally: g / cc (grams per cubic centimetre).

* The FPS units of mass density are lb ft^-3 (pounds per cubic foot).


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Mass Density/Area
definition:
The area mass density of a two-dimensional body is its mass per unit area.


=== Symbol ===
The usual symbol used to denote area mass density is Ï_A (Greek letter rho).

However, some sources simply use Ï if the context makes it clear that it refers to area mass density rather than volume mass density.

Occasionally, Ïƒ (Greek letter sigma) is also used, but this is more commonly used for surface charge density.


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density

=== Dimension ===
The dimension of area mass density is ğ–¬ğ–«^-2: mass per unit area.


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of area mass density are kg m^-2 (kilograms per square metre).

* The CGS units of area mass density are g cm^-2 (grams per square centimetre).

Thus:
:1  g cm^-2 = 10  kg m^-2


Category:Definitions/Area Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Units of Measurement

title: Definition:Mass Density/Linear
definition:
The linear mass density of a one-dimensional body is its mass per unit length.


=== Symbol ===
The usual symbol used to denote linear mass density is Î¼ (Greek letter mu).

Sometimes Î» (Greek letter lambda) is also used.


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density

=== Dimension ===
The dimension of linear mass density is ğ–¬ğ–«^-1: mass per unit length.


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement

=== Units ===
* The SI units of linear mass density are kg m^-1 (kilograms per metre).

* The CGS units of linear mass density are g cm^-1 (grams per centimetre).

Thus:
:1  kg m^-1 = 10  g cm^-1


Category:Definitions/Linear Mass Density
Category:Definitions/Units of Measurement

title: Definition:Electric Charge Density
definition:
Let A be a point in space in which an electric field acts.

Let Î´ V be a volume element containing A.


The (electric) charge density Ï(   )ğ« at A is defined as:
 
 
 
 

where:
:Q denotes the electric charge within Î´ V
:ğ« denotes the position vector of A.


Thus the electric charge density is the quantity of electric charge per unit volume, at any given point in that volume:


=== Symbol ===


=== Dimension ===
The dimension of electric charge density is ğ–¨ ğ–³ ğ–«^-3: electric charge per unit volume.

=== Units ===
The SI units of electric charge density are C m^-3 (coulombs per cubic metre).


Category:Definitions/Electric Charge Density
Category:Definitions/Units of Measurement

title: Definition:Dirichlet Density
definition:
Let ğ’« be a set of prime numbers.

S has Dirichlet density Î±  if and only if :

title: Definition:Diagram (Graphical Technique)
definition:
A diagram is a graphical technique for illustrating a concept in picture form.

It is generally considered that its use should be limited to that of an aid to understanding, and should not be used in order to prove something.

title: Definition:Diagram (Category Theory)
definition:
Let ğ‰ and ğ‚ be metacategories.


A diagram of type ğ‰ in ğ‚ is a functor D: ğ‰â†’ğ‚.


=== Index Category ===

In this context, ğ‰ is referred to as the index category.

Its objects are typically denoted by lowercase letters, i, j etc.


Furthermore, one writes D_i in place of the formally more correct D (i).

Similarly, for Î±: i â†’ j a morphism one writes D_Î± in place of D (Î±).

definition:

: 
:A diameter of the circle is any straight line drawn through the center and terminated in both directions by the circumference of the circle, and such a straight line also bisects the center.

title: Definition:Diameter of Ellipse
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be an ellipse.

A diameter of ğ’¦ is the locus of the midpoints of a system of parallel chords of ğ’¦.

definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a hyperbola.

A diameter of ğ’¦ is the locus of the midpoints of a system of parallel chords of ğ’¦.

title: Definition:Sphere/Geometry/Diameter
definition:
By the definition of a sphere, there is one point inside it such that the distance between that point and any given point on the surface of the sphere are equal, and that point is called the center of the sphere.


The diameter of a sphere is the length of any straight line drawn from a point on the surface to another point on the surface through the center.


 
: 
:A diameter of the sphere is any straight line drawn through the centre and terminated in both directions by the surface of the sphere.
 â€

title: Definition:Diameter of Parallelogram
definition:
Let ABCD be a parallelogram:

:

The diameters of ABCD are the lines AC and BD joining their opposite vertices.

title: Definition:Geometric Figure/Diameter
definition: The diameter of a geometric figure is the greatest length that can be formed between two opposite parallel straight lines that can be drawn tangent to its boundary.

title: Definition:Diameter of Subset of Metric Space
definition:
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

Let S âŠ† A be subset of A.


Then the diameter of S is the extended real number defined by:

:diam(   )S := sup{ d (   )x, y: x, y âˆˆ S }    : if this quantity is finite
 + âˆ    : otherwise


Thus, by the definition of the supremum, the diameter is the smallest real number D such that any two points of S are at most a distance D apart.

If d: S^2 â†’â„ does not admit a supremum, then diam(   )S is infinite.

title: Definition:Topological Manifold/Differentiable Manifold
definition:
Let M be a second-countable locally Euclidean space of dimension d. 

Let â„± be a d-dimensional differentiable structure on M of class ğ’^k, where k â‰¥ 1.

title: Definition:Differentiable Mapping
definition:
=== Real Function ===
=== At a Point ===

Let f be a real function defined on an open interval ( a  . . )b.

Let Î¾ be a point in ( a  . . )b.


==== Definition 1 ====
Let f be a real function defined on an open interval ( a  . . )b.

Let Î¾ be a point in ( a  . . )b.


f is differentiable at the point Î¾  if and only if  the limit:
:lim_x â†’Î¾f (   )x - f (   )Î¾/x - Î¾
exists.

==== Definition 2 ====
Let f be a real function defined on an open interval ( a  . . )b.

Let Î¾ be a point in ( a  . . )b.


f is differentiable at the point Î¾  if and only if  the limit:
:lim_h â†’ 0f (   )Î¾ + h - f (   )Î¾/h
exists.

These limits, if they exist, are called the derivative of f at Î¾.

=== On an Open Interval ===
Let f be a real function defined on an open interval ( a  . . )b.


Then f is differentiable on ( a  . . )b  if and only if  f is differentiable at each point of ( a  . . )b.


=== On a Closed Interval ===
Let f be a real function defined on a closed interval [ a  . . ]b.

Let f be differentiable on the open interval ( a  . . )b.


If the following limit from the right exists:

:lim_x â†’ a^+f (   )x - f (   )a/x - a

as well as this limit from the left:
:lim_x â†’ b^-f (   )x - f (   )b/x - b

then f is differentiable on the closed interval [ a  . . ]b.


Similar definitions for differentiability on a half-open interval can be expressed for a real function which has either a limit from the right at a or a limit from the left at b, but not both.

=== On the Real Number Line ===
Let f be a real function defined on â„.

By definition, â„ is an (unbounded) open interval.


Let f be differentiable on the open interval â„.

That is, let f be differentiable at every point of â„.


Then f is differentiable everywhere (on â„).


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Real Functions

=== Complex Function ===
=== At a Point ===

Let U âŠ‚â„‚ be an open set.

Let f : U â†’â„‚ be a complex function.

Let z_0 âˆˆ U be a point in U.


Then f is complex-differentiable at z_0  if and only if  the limit:

:lim_h â†’ 0f (   )z_0+h - f (   )z_0/h

exists as a finite number.


This limit, if it exists, is called the derivative of f at z_0.

=== In an Open Set ===
Let U âŠ†â„‚ be an open set.

Let f : U â†’â„‚ be a complex function.


Then f is holomorphic in U  if and only if  f is differentiable at each point of U.


 

Category:Definitions/Complex Differential Calculus

=== Real-Valued Function ===
=== At a Point ===

Let U be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let â€–Â·â€– denote the Euclidean norm on â„^n.

Let f: U â†’â„ be a real-valued function.

Let x âˆˆ U.

==== Definition 1 ====
Let U be an open subset of â„^n.

Let â€–Â·â€– denote the Euclidean norm on â„^n.

Let f: U â†’â„ be a real-valued function.

Let x âˆˆ U.


f is differentiable at x  if and only if  there exist Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n âˆˆâ„ and a real-valued function r: U âˆ–{ x }â†’â„ such that:

:(1):   f (   )x + h = f (   )x + Î±_1 h_1 + â‹¯ + Î±_n h_n + r (   )h â€– h â€–

:(2):  lim_h â†’ 0 r (   )h = 0


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Real-Valued Functions

==== Definition 2 ====
Let U be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let f: U â†’â„ be a real-valued function.

Let â€–Â·â€– denote the Euclidean norm on â„^n.

Let x âˆˆ U.


f is differentiable at x  if and only if  there exists a linear transformation T: â„^n â†’â„ and a real-valued function r: U âˆ–{ x }â†’â„ such that:

:(1):    f (   )x + h = f (   )x + T (   )h + r (   )h â€– h â€–
:(2):   lim_h â†’ 0 r (   )h = 0


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Real-Valued Functions

==== Definition 3 ====
Let U be an open subset of â„^n.

Let â€–Â·â€– denote the Euclidean norm on â„^n.

Let f: U â†’â„ be a real-valued function.

Let x âˆˆ U.


f is differentiable at x  if and only if  all its partial derivatives are defined at x.

=== In an Open Set ===
Let ğ• be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let f: ğ•â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


Then f is differentiable in the open set ğ•  if and only if  f is differentiable at each point of ğ•.

=== Vector-Valued Function ===
Let m, n â‰¥ 1 be natural numbers.

=== At a Point ===

Let ğ• be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let f = ( f_1, f_2, â€¦, f_m )^âŠº: ğ•â†’â„^m be a vector valued function.


f is differentiable at x âˆˆâ„^n  if and only if  there exists a linear transformation T: â„^n â†’â„^m and a mapping r : U â†’â„^m such that:

:(1):    f (   )x + h = f (   )x + T (   )h + r (   )h Â·â€– h â€–

:(2):   lim_h â†’ 0 r (   )h = 0


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Vector-Valued Functions

=== In an Open Set ===
Let ğ• be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let f = ( f_1, f_2, â€¦, f_m )^âŠº: ğ•â†’â„^m be a vector valued function.

Let S âŠ†ğ•.


Then f is differentiable in the open set S  if and only if  f is differentiable at each x in S.


This can be denoted f âˆˆğ’^1 (   )S, â„^m.

=== Function With Values in Normed Space ===
Let U âŠ‚â„ be an open set.

Let ( X, â€– Â· â€–_X ) be a normed vector space.

A function f : U â†’ X is (strongly) differentiable at x âˆˆ U  if and only if  there exists f' (   )x âˆˆ X such that:

:lim_h â†’ 0â€–f (   )x + h - f (   )x/h - f' (   )x â€–_X = 0

Moreover, f is called (strongly) differentiable if it is differentiable at every point of U.

=== Between Differentiable Manifolds ===
Let M and N be differentiable manifolds.

Let f : M â†’ N be continuous.

=== Definition 1 ===

f  is differentiable  if and only if  for every pair of charts (U, Ï•) and (V,Ïˆ) of M and N:
:Ïˆâˆ˜ fâˆ˜Ï•^-1 : Ï• ( U âˆ© f^-1(V)) â†’Ïˆ(V)
is differentiable.


=== Definition 2 ===


f  is differentiable  if and only if  f is  differentiable at every point of M.


=== At a Point ===
Let M and N be differentiable manifolds.

Let f: M â†’ N be continuous.

Let p âˆˆ M.


==== Definition 1 ====
f is differentiable at p  if and only if  for every pair of charts ( U, Ï•) and ( V, Ïˆ) of M and N with p âˆˆ U and f (   )p âˆˆ V:
:Ïˆâˆ˜ f âˆ˜Ï•^-1: Ï•(   )U âˆ© f^-1(   )Vâ†’Ïˆ(   )V
is differentiable at Ï•(   )p.


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Manifolds

==== Definition 2 ====
f is differentiable at p  if and only if  there exists a pair of charts ( U, Ï•) and ( V, Ïˆ) of M and N with p âˆˆ U and f (   )p âˆˆ V such that:
:Ïˆâˆ˜ f âˆ˜Ï•^-1: Ï•(   )U âˆ© f^-1(   )Vâ†’Ïˆ(   )V
is differentiable at Ï•(   )p.


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Manifolds

title: Definition:Differentiable Functional
definition:
Let S be a normed linear space of mappings.

title: Definition:Continuously Differentiable
definition:
A differentiable function f is continuously differentiable  if and only if  f is of differentiability class C^1.

That is, if the first order derivative of f (and possibly higher) is continuous.


=== Real Function ===
Let IâŠ‚â„ be an open interval.


Then f is continuously differentiable on I  if and only if  f is differentiable on I and its derivative is continuous on I.


=== Real-Valued Function ===
Let U be an open subset of â„^n. 

Let f: U â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


Then f is continuously differentiable in the open set U  if and only if :
:(1):    f is differentiable in U.
:(2): the partial derivatives of f are continuous in U.


This can be denoted:
:f âˆˆğ’^1 (   )ğ•, â„


=== Vector-Valued Function ===
Let U âŠ‚â„^n be an open set.

Let f: U â†’â„^m be a vector-valued function.


Then f is continuously differentiable in U  if and only if  f is differentiable in U and its partial derivatives are continuous in U.


Category:Definitions/Differentiable Vector-Valued Functions

title: Definition:Dimension (Geometry)
definition: The dimension of a (geometrical) space is the minimum number of coordinates needed to specify a point in it.

title: Definition:Dimension (Linear Algebra)
definition:
=== Module ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let G be a unitary R-module which has a basis of n elements.

Then G is said to have a dimension of n or to be n-dimensional.


=== Symbol ===


=== Finite Dimensional Module ===
Let G be a (unitary) module which is n-dimensional for some n âˆˆâ„•_>0.

Then G is finite dimensional.

=== Vector Space ===

Let K be a division ring.

Let V be a vector space over K.

Let K be a division ring.

Let V be a vector space over K.


The dimension of V is the cardinality of an arbitrary basis for V.

title: Definition:Matrix/Order
definition:
Let [ a ]_m n be an m Ã— n matrix.

Then the parameters m and n are known as the order of the matrix.


=== Square Matrix ===
Let ğ€ be an n Ã— n square matrix.

That is, let ğ€ have n rows (and by definition n columns).


Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.

=== Column Matrix ===
Let ğ€ be an n Ã— 1 column matrix.

Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.


Category:Definitions/Orders of Matrices
Category:Definitions/Column Matrices

=== Row Matrix ===
Let ğ€ be a 1 Ã— n row matrix.

Then the order of ğ€ is defined as being n.


Category:Definitions/Orders of Matrices
Category:Definitions/Row Matrices

title: Definition:Dimension (Hilbert Space)

title: Definition:Image (Relation Theory)/Mapping/Mapping
definition:
Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.


=== Definition 1 ===
The image of a mapping f: S â†’ T is the set:

:Img( f ) = { t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: f (   )s = t }

That is, it is the set of values taken by f.

=== Definition 2 ===
The image of a mapping f: S â†’ T is the set:

:Img( f ) = f [ S ]

where f [ S ] is the image of S under f.


=== Class Theory ===

 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let A âŠ† V and B âŠ† V be classes.

Let f: A â†’ B be a class mapping.

The image of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Img( â„›) := { y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all y such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one x.

title: Definition:Image (Relation Theory)/Relation/Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


The image of â„› is defined as:

:Img( â„›) := â„›[ S ] = { t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›}


=== General Definition ===
Let âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be the cartesian product of sets S_1 to S_n.

Let â„›âŠ†âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be an n-ary relation on âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i.

The image of â„› is the set defined as:
:Img( â„›) := { s_n âˆˆ S_n: âˆƒ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆâˆ_i  = 1^n - 1 S_i: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}


The concept is usually encountered when â„› is an endorelation on S:
:Img( â„›) := { s_n âˆˆ S: âˆƒ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆ S^n - 1: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}

=== Class Theory ===

 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.

The image of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Img( â„›) := { y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all y such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one x.

definition:

The direct image mapping of â„› is the mapping â„›^â†’: ğ’«( S ) â†’ğ’«( T ) that sends a subset X âŠ† T to its image under â„›:

title: Definition:Digraph
definition:
A digraph is a graph each of whose edges has a direction:



In the above digraph, the vertices are v_1, v_2, v_3 and v_4.


=== Arc ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

The arcs are the elements of E.

Informally, an arc is a line that joins one vertex to another.


If e âˆˆ E is an arc joining the vertex u to the vertex v, it is denoted u v.


=== Endvertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The endvertices of e are the vertices u and v.


=== Initial Vertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The initial vertex of e is the endvertex u which e is incident from.

=== Final Vertex ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let e = u v be an arc of D, that is, e âˆˆ E.


The final vertex of e is the endvertex v which e is incident to.

In the above graph, the arcs are v_1 v_2, v_2 v_4, v_4 v_3, v_4 v_1 and v_1 v_4.


As can be seen, in this general definition it is allowable for an arc to go in both directions between a given pair of vertices.


=== Formal Definition ===



A directed graph or digraph D is a non-empty set V together with an antireflexive relation E on V.

The elements of E are the arcs.


Thus the above digraph can be defined as:

:D = ( V, E ):
::V = { v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4 }
::E = {( v_1, v_2 ), ( v_2, v_4 ), ( v_4, v_3 ), ( v_4, v_1 ), ( v_1, v_4 )  }

=== Category-Theoretic Definition ===
Let ğ’ğğ­ be the category of sets.

A digraph is an arrangement of the following form in ğ’ğğ­:

::<0em,0em>*E = "E",
<5em,0em>*V = "V",

"E"+/^.3em/+/r1em/;"V"+/^.3em/+/l1em/ **@- ?>*@> ?*!/_.6em/s,
"E"+/_.3em/+/r1em/;"V"+/_.3em/+/l1em/ **@- ?>*@> ?*!/^.6em/t,

=== Symmetric Digraph ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph such that the relation E in D is symmetric.

Then D is called a symmetric digraph.


It follows from the definition of a (simple) graph that a symmetric digraph is in fact the same thing as an undirected graph.

=== Simple Digraph ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

If the relation E in D is also specifically asymmetric, then D is called a simple digraph.

That is, in a simple digraph there are no pairs of arcs (like there are between v_1 and v_4 in the diagram above) which go in both directions between two vertices.

title: Definition:Directed Preordering
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¾) be a preordered set.

definition:

Then H is a directed subset of S  if and only if :

title: Definition:Directed Smooth Curve
definition:
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let Ï: [a  . .  b] â†’â„^n be a smooth path in â„^n.


The directed smooth curve with parameterization Ï is defined as an equivalence class of smooth paths as follows:

A smooth path Ïƒ: [a  . .  b] â†’â„^n belongs to the equivalence class of Ï  if and only if :
: there exists a bijective differentiable strictly increasing real function:
:: Ï•: [c  . .  d] â†’[a  . .  b]
: such that Ïƒ = Ïâˆ˜Ï•.


It follows from Directed Smooth Curve Relation is Equivalence and Fundamental Theorem on Equivalence Relations that this does in fact define an equivalence class.


If a directed smooth curve is only defined by a smooth path Ï, then it is often denoted with the same symbol Ï.


=== Parameterization ===
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in â„^n.

Let Ï: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„^n.


Then Ï is a parameterization of C  if and only if  Ï is an element of the equivalence class that constitutes C.


=== Complex Plane ===

The definition carries over to the complex plane, in which context it is usually applied:

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚.

Let Î³: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„‚.


Then Î³ is a parameterization of C  if and only if  Î³ is a representative of the equivalence class that constitutes C.


=== Reparameterization ===
Let Î³ : [ a  . . ]b â†’â„‚ be a smooth path in â„‚.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚ parameterized by Î³.

Let Ï•: [ c  . . ]d â†’[ a  . . ]b be a bijective differentiable strictly increasing real function.

Let Ïƒ : [ c  . . ]d â†’â„‚ be defined by:

:Ïƒ = Î³âˆ˜Ï• 


Then Ïƒ is called a reparameterization of C.

=== Endpoints ===
Let â„^n be a real cartesian space of n dimensions.

Let C be a directed smooth curve in â„^n.


Let C be parameterized by a smooth path Ï: [a  . .  b] â†’â„‚.


Then:
: Ï(a) is the start point of C

: Ï(b) is the end point of C.


Collectively, Ï(a) and Ï(b) are known as the endpoints of Ï.


=== Complex Plane ===

The definition carries over to the complex plane, in which context it is usually applied:

Let C be a directed smooth curve in the complex plane â„‚.

Let C be parameterized by a smooth path Î³: [a  . .  b] â†’â„‚.


Then:
: Î³(a) is the start point of C

: Î³(b) is the end point of C.


Collectively, Î³(a) and Î³(b) are known as the endpoints of Ï.

title: Definition:Directed Line Segment
definition:
A directed line segment is a line segment endowed with the additional property of direction.

It is often used in the context of applied mathematics to represent a vector quantity.

title: Definition:Directed Hamilton Cycle Problem
definition:
There are two versions of the Directed Hamilton Cycle Problem.


=== Function Version ===
:Given a digraph G with n vertices, to find a Hamilton cycle in G.

=== Decision Version ===
:Given a digraph G with n vertices, to determine whether G has a Hamilton cycle.

title: Definition:Directrix of Ruled Surface
definition:
A directrix is a curve which defines the generators of a ruled surface.


=== Directrix of Cone ===
Let K be a cone.

Let B be the base of K.


The boundary of B is known as the directrix of K.

=== Directrix of Cylindrical Surface ===
The directrix of a cylindrical surface S is the curve C through which pass all the parallel straight lines forming S.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Directrix
definition:
Let K be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant e

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = e p


The line D is known as the directrix of the conic section.

title: Definition:Conchoid/Directrix
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conchoid.

Let ğ’ be the curve   which the conchoid is constructed.


ğ’ is known as the directrix of ğ’¦.


=== Also known as ===

title: Definition:Disconnected (Topology)
definition:
=== Topological Space ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is disconnected  if and only if  T is not connected.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


T is disconnected  if and only if  there exist non-empty open sets U, V âˆˆÏ„ such that:
:S = U âˆª V
:U âˆ© V = âˆ…

That is, if there exists a partition of S into open sets of T.

=== Subset of Topological Space ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a non-empty subset of S.


H is a disconnected set of T  if and only if  it is not a connected set of T.

=== Points in Topological Space ===
Let T = (S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let a, b âˆˆ S.


Then a and b are disconnected (in T)  if and only if  they are not connected (in T).


Category:Definitions/Disconnected Spaces

title: Definition:Connected (Graph Theory)/Graph/Disconnected
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Then G is a disconnected graph  if and only if  it is not a connected graph.

That is,  if and only if  there exists (at least) two vertices u, v âˆˆ V such that u and v are not connected vertices.

title: Definition:Discontinuous Mapping/Real Function/Point
definition:
Let A âŠ†â„ be a subset of the real numbers.

Let f : A â†’â„ be a real function.

Let aâˆˆ A.


Then f is discontinuous at a  if and only if  f is not continuous at a.

title: Definition:Discontinuous Mapping/Topological Space/Point
definition:
Let T_1 = ( A_1, Ï„_1 ) and T_2 = ( A_2, Ï„_2 ) be topological spaces.

Let f: A_1 â†’ A_2 x âˆˆ T_1 be a mapping from A_1 to A_2.


Then by definition f is continuous at x if for every neighborhood N of f (   )x there exists a neighborhood M of x such that f [ M ] âŠ† N.

Therefore, f is discontinuous at x if for some neighborhood N of f (   )x and every neighborhood M of x:
:f [ M ] âŠˆ N

The point x is called a discontinuity of f.

title: Definition:Discrete Mathematics
definition: Discrete mathematics is the branch of mathematics which studies mathematical structures that are discrete rather than continuous.

title: Definition:Discrete Category
definition:
Let ğ’ be a metacategory.


Then ğ’ is said to be discrete  if and only if  it comprises only identity morphisms.

If the collection ğ’ constitutes the objects of ğ‚, then ğ‚ may also be denoted ğƒğ¢ğ¬(   )ğ’.

title: Definition:Discrete Topology
definition:
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Then Ï„ is called the discrete topology on S and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) the discrete space on S, or just a discrete space.


=== Finite Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be a finite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is a finite discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is a finite discrete space.

=== Infinite Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be an infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is an infinite discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is an infinite discrete space.


=== Countable Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be an infinite set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be a countably infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is a countable discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is a countable discrete space.

=== Uncountable Discrete Topology ===
Let S âˆ… be a set.

Let Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) be the power set of S.

That is, let Ï„ be the set of all subsets of S:
:Ï„ := { H: H âŠ† S }


Let S be an uncountably infinite set.

Then Ï„ = ğ’«( S ) is an uncountable discrete topology, and ( S, Ï„) = ( S, ğ’«( S ) ) is an uncountable discrete space.

title: Definition:Discrete Group
definition:
A discrete group is a topological group whose topology is discrete.

Category:Definitions/Topological Groups

definition:
Let G be a subgroup of the additive group of real numbers.

title: Definition:Standard Discrete Metric
definition:
The standard discrete metric on a set S is the metric satisfying:

:d (   )x, y =  0     : x = y 
 1     : x  y


This can be expressed using the Kronecker delta notation as:
:d (   )x, y = 1 - Î´_x y


The resulting metric space M = ( S, d ) is the standard discrete metric space on S.

title: Definition:Discriminant of Polynomial
definition:
Let k be a field.

Let the roots of f in k be Î±_1, Î±_2, â€¦, Î±_n.

=== Quadratic Equation ===

The concept is usually encountered in the context of a quadratic equation a x^2 + b x + c = 0:
Consider the quadratic equation:
:a x^2 + b x + c = 0

The expression b^2 - 4 a c is called the discriminant of the equation.

=== Cubic Equation ===

In the context of a cubic equation a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d = 0:

title: Definition:Discriminant of Bilinear Form
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚ of finite dimension n>0.

Let b : VÃ— V â†’ğ•‚ be a bilinear form on V.

If b is nondegenerate, its discriminant is the equivalence class of the determinant A in the quotient group ğ•‚^Ã—( ğ•‚^Ã—)^2.

If b is degenerate, its discriminant is 0.

definition:
Let K be a conic section embedded in a Cartesian plane with the general equation:
:a x^2 + 2 h x y + b y^2 + 2 g x + 2 f y + c = 0
where a, b, c, f, g, h âˆˆâ„.

:Î” =  a     h     g

title: Definition:Discriminant Function
definition:
A discriminant function is a function which assigns a given individual to one of a number of populations according to the data appertaining to that individual.

It is based on measurements on individuals for whom the population to which each one belongs is known.

It is chosen to minimize the probabilities or costs of misclassification.

title: Definition:Dispersion (Statistics)
definition:
Let S be a sample of a population in the context of statistics.

The dispersion of S is a general term meaning how much the data describing the sample are spread out.


The word can also be applied to a random variable.


Measures of dispersion include the following:


=== Range ===
Range is a measure of dispersion of a set of observations.


Let S be a set of observations of a quantitative variable.

The range of S is defined as:
:R (   )S := max(   )S - min(   )S

where max(   )S and min(   )S are the greatest value of S and the least value of S respectively.


=== Infinite Range ===
For certain random variables, it is possible that the range may be infinite, in the sense that it is technically unbounded.


 

=== Interquartile Range ===
The interquartile range is a measure of dispersion in statistics.


Let Q_1 and Q_3 be first quartile and third quartile respectively.

The interquartile range is defined and denoted as:

:IQR := Q_3 - Q_1

=== Semi-Interquartile Range ===
The semi-interquartile range is a measure of dispersion in statistics.


Let Q_1 and Q_3 be first quartile and third quartile respectively.

The semi-interquartile range is defined as:

:Q_3 - Q_1 2

That is, half the interquartile range.

=== Mean Absolute Deviation ===
Let S = { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n } be a set of observations.

Let xÌ… denote a measure of central tendency of S.


The mean absolute deviation   xÌ… of S is defined as the arithmetic mean of the absolute values of the deviation of the elements of S from xÌ… :

:âˆ‘_i  = 1^n  1 n | x_i - xÌ…|


=== Discrete Random Variable ===
Let X be a discrete random variable.

Let xÌ… denote a measure of central tendency of X.


The mean absolute deviation of X is the first absolute moment of X about xÌ….

=== Continuous Random Variable ===
Let X be a continuous random variable.

Let m denote the median of X.

Let the frequency function of X be f.


The mean absolute deviation of X is defined as:
:âˆ«_-âˆ^+âˆ| x - m | f (   )x  d x

=== Variance ===
Let X be a continuous random variable. 

Then the variance of X, written ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ), is a measure of how much the values of X varies from the expectation ğ–¤( X ), and is defined as:

:ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ) := ğ–¤( ( X - ğ–¤( X ) )^2 )

That is, the expectation of the squares of the deviations from the expectation.


Letting Î¼ = ğ–¤( X ), this is often given as: 

:ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ) = ğ–¤( ( X - Î¼)^2 )

=== Standard Deviation ===
Standard deviation is a measure of dispersion of a set of observations.

Let X be a random variable.

Then the standard deviation of X, written Ïƒ_X or Ïƒ, is defined as the principal square root of the variance of X:

:Ïƒ_X := âˆš(ğ—ğ–ºğ—‹( X ))

title: Definition:Dispersion Point
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S be a connected set in T and let p âˆˆ H.

Let p âˆˆ H such that H âˆ–{ p } is totally disconnected, where âˆ– denotes set difference.


Then p is a dispersion point of H.

title: Definition:Distance/Points/Complex Numbers
definition:
Let x, y âˆˆâ„‚ be complex numbers.

Let | x - y | be the complex modulus of x - y.


Then the function d: â„‚^2 â†’â„:
:d (   )x, y = | x - y |
is called the distance between x and y.

title: Definition:Metric Space/Distance Function
definition:
Let ( A, d ) be a metric space.

The mapping d: A Ã— A â†’â„ is referred to as a distance function on A.


Here, d: A Ã— A â†’â„ is a real-valued function satisfying the metric space axioms:

definition:

Let S, T be subsets of A.


The distance between x and S is defined and annotated d (   )x, S = inf_y âˆˆ S( d (   )x, y).

The distance between S and T is defined and annotated d (   )S, T = inf_x âˆˆ S 
 y âˆˆ T( d (   )x, y).

title: Definition:Distance between Points
definition: The distance between two points A and B in space is defined as the length of a straight line segment that would be drawn from A to B.

title: Definition:Distance between Lines
definition:
Let L_1 and L_2 be straight lines in space.

The distance between L_1 and L_2 is defined as the length of the shortest line segment joining L_1 and L_2.

title: Definition:Distance between Parallel Lines
definition:
Let L_1 and L_2 be parallel lines.

The distance between L_1 and L_2 is defined as the length of a line segment joining L_1 and L_2 that is perpendicular to both.

title: Definition:Distributive Operation
definition:
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.


The operation âˆ˜ is distributive over *, or distributes over *,  if and only if :
:âˆ˜ is right distributive over *
and:
:âˆ˜ is left distributive over *.


=== Left Distributive ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, denoted here as âˆ˜ and *.

The operation âˆ˜ is left distributive over the operation *  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜( b * c ) = ( a âˆ˜ b ) * ( a âˆ˜ c )

=== Right Distributive ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, denoted here as âˆ˜ and *.

The operation âˆ˜ is right distributive over the operation *  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: ( a * b ) âˆ˜ c = ( a âˆ˜ c ) * ( b âˆ˜ c )

So as to streamline what may turn into cumbersome language, some further definitions:

=== Distributand ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.

Let âˆ˜ be distributive over *.

Then * is a distributand of âˆ˜.


=== Linguistic Note ===


Category:Definitions/Distributive Operations

=== Distributor ===
Let S be a set on which is defined two binary operations, defined on all the elements of S Ã— S, which we will denote as âˆ˜ and *.

Let âˆ˜ be distributive over *.

Then âˆ˜ is a distributor of *.


Category:Definitions/Distributive Operations

title: Definition:Distributive Lattice
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.

definition:

title: Definition:Divergent Sequence
definition:
A sequence which is not convergent is divergent.

 

=== Divergent Real Sequence ===
A real sequence which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Series
definition: A series which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Function
definition: A function which is not convergent is divergent.

title: Definition:Divergent Improper Integral
definition:
An improper integral of a real function f is said to diverge if any of the following hold:

:(1):    f is continuous on [ a  . . )â†’ and the limit lim_b â†’ +âˆâˆ«_a^b f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(2):    f is continuous on (  . . ]b and the limit lim_a â†’ -âˆâˆ«_a^b f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(3):    f is continuous on [ a  . . )b, has an infinite discontinuity at b, and the limit lim_c â†’ b^-âˆ«_a^c f (   )x  d x does not exist

:(4):    f is continuous on ( a  . . ]b, has an infinite discontinuity at a, and the limit lim_c â†’ a^+âˆ«_c^b f (   )x  d x does not exist.

title: Definition:Divergent Product
definition:
An infinite product which is not convergent is divergent.

 


=== Divergence to zero ===
Let ( ğ•‚, â€– Â· â€–) be a valued field.

Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be a sequence of elements of ğ•‚.


If either:

:there exist infinitely many n âˆˆâ„• with a_n = 0

:there exists n_0 âˆˆâ„• with a_n  0 for all n > n_0 and the sequence of partial products of âˆ_n  = n_0 + 1^âˆ a_n converges to 0

the product diverges to 0, and we assign the value:
:âˆ_n  = 1^âˆ a_n = 0


Category:Definitions/Divergent Products
Category:Definitions/Infinite Products

title: Definition:Divisor (Algebra)/Integer
definition:
Let ( â„¤, +, Ã—) be the ring of integers.

Let x, y âˆˆâ„¤.


Then x divides y is defined as:
:x \ y âˆƒ t âˆˆâ„¤: y = t Ã— x


=== Aliquot Part ===
An aliquot part of an integer n is a divisor of n which is strictly less than n.

=== Aliquant Part ===
An aliquant part of an integer n is a positive integer which is less than n but is not a divisor of n.

title: Definition:Prime Factor
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

Then p is a prime factor of n  if and only if :
: (1):    p is a prime number
: (2):    p is a divisor (that is, factor) of n.

title: Definition:Divisor (Algebra)/Ring with Unity
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be an ring with unity whose zero is 0_R and whose unity is 1_R.

Let x, y âˆˆ D.

We define the term x divides y in R as follows:
:x \_R y âˆƒ t âˆˆ R: y = t âˆ˜ x


When no ambiguity results, the subscript is usually dropped, and x divides y in R is just written x \ y.

title: Definition:Divisor of Polynomial
definition:
Let D be an integral domain.

Let D [ x ] be the polynomial ring in one variable over D.

Let f, g âˆˆ D [ x ] be polynomials.


Then:
:f divides g
:f is a divisor of g
:g is divisible by f
 if and only if :
:âˆƒ h âˆˆ D [ x ] : g = f h


This is denoted:
:f \ g


=== Notation ===
The conventional notation for x is a divisor of y is "x | y", but there is a growing trend to follow the notation "x \ y", as espoused by   etc.

From  :
:The notation 'm | n' is actually much more common than 'm \ n' in current mathematics literature. But vertical lines are overused â€“ for absolute values, set delimiters, conditional probabilities, etc. â€“ and backward slashes are underused. Moreover, 'm \ n' gives an impression that m is the denominator of an implied ratio. So we shall boldly let our divisibility symbol lean leftward.


An unfortunate unwelcome side-effect of this notational convention is that to indicate non-divisibility, the conventional technique of implementing / through the notation looks awkward with \, so \ is eschewed in favour of âˆ¤.


Some sources use | -10mu  3pt - or similar to denote non-divisibility.


Category:Definitions/Divisors

title: Definition:Division/Divisor
definition:
Let c = a / b denote the division operation on two elements a and b of a field or a Euclidean domain.

The element b is the divisor of a.

title: Definition:Domain (Relation Theory)
definition:
=== Relation ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.

The domain of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Dom( â„›) := { s âˆˆ S: âˆƒ t âˆˆ T: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›}


That is, it is the same as what is defined here as the preimage of â„›.


=== General Definition ===
Let âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be the cartesian product of sets S_1 to S_n.

Let â„›âŠ†âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i be an n-ary relation on âˆ_i  = 1^n S_i.

The domain of â„› is the set defined as:
:Dom( â„›) := {( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆâˆ_i  = 1^n - 1 S_i: âˆƒ s_n âˆˆ S_n: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}


The concept is usually encountered when â„› is an endorelation on S:
:Dom( â„›) := {( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆ S^n - 1: âˆƒ s_n âˆˆ S_n: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}

=== Class Theory ===
 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.

The domain of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Dom( â„›) := { x âˆˆ V: âˆƒ y âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all x such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one y.

=== Mapping ===

The term domain is usually seen when the relation in question is actually a mapping.

Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.

The domain of f is S, and can be denoted Dom( f ).

=== Binary Operation ===
Let âˆ˜: S Ã— S â†’ T be a binary operation.

The domain of âˆ˜ is the set S and can be denoted Dom( âˆ˜).


This definition can be considered as the same as that for the domain of a mapping, where the domain would be defined as S Ã— S.

Category:Definitions/Abstract Algebra

title: Definition:Variable/Domain
definition:
The collection of all possible objects that a variable may refer to has to be specified.

This collection is the domain of the variable.

title: Definition:Domain (Category Theory)
definition:
Let f: X â†’ Y be a morphism.

Then the domain of f is defined to be the object X.

This is usually denoted X = Dom( f ) or X = D (   )f.

title: Definition:Integral Domain
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is:

:a commutative ring which is non-null
:with a unity
:in which there are no (proper) zero divisors, that is:
::: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ D: x âˆ˜ y = 0_D  x = 0_D  or  y = 0_D

that is, in which all non-zero elements are cancellable.

=== Definition 2 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is a commutative ring such that ( D^*, âˆ˜) is a monoid, all of whose elements are cancellable.

In this context, D^* denotes the ring D without zero: D âˆ–{ 0_D }.

=== Integral Domain Axioms ===

title: Definition:Dominate (Set Theory)
definition:
Let S and T be sets.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let S and T be sets.


Then S is dominated by T  if and only if  there exists an injection from S to T.


The notation S â‰¼ T is used to indicate that S dominates T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S and T be sets.


Then S is dominated by T  if and only if  S is equivalent to some subset of T.

That is,  if and only if  there exists a bijection f: S â†’ T' for some T' âŠ† T.

The notation S â‰¼ T is used to indicate that S dominates T.

=== Strictly Dominated ===
Let S, T be sets.


S is strictly dominated by set T  if and only if  S â‰¼ T but T â‰¼ S.

This can be written S â‰º T or S < T.


Category:Definitions/Set Theory

title: Definition:Dominate (Analysis)
definition:
Let âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© be a sequence in â„.

Let âŸ¨ z_n âŸ© be a sequence in â„‚.


Then âŸ¨ a_n âŸ© dominates âŸ¨ z_n âŸ©  if and only if :
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„•: | z_n |â‰¤ a_n

Category:Definitions/Analysis
Category:Definitions/Complex Analysis

title: Definition:Avoirdupois/Dram
definition:
The dram is an avoirdupois unit of mass.

=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Apothecaries' Weights and Measures/Mass/Drachm
definition:
The drachm is an apothecaries' unit of mass.

=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Dual Relation
definition:
=== Inverse of Complement ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a binary relation.


Then the dual of â„› is denoted â„›^d and is defined as:

:â„›^d := ( R )^-1

where:
:R denotes the complement of â„›
:( R )^-1 denotes the inverse of the complement of â„›.

=== Complement of Inverse ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a binary relation.


Then the dual of â„› is denoted â„›^d and is defined as:

:â„›^d := ( â„›^-1)

where:
:â„›^-1 denotes the inverse of â„›
:( â„›^-1) denotes the complement of the inverse of â„›.


Category:Definitions/Relation Theory

title: Definition:Dual Ordering
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the inverse relation to â‰¼.

That is, for all a, b âˆˆ S:

:a â‰½ b  if and only if  b â‰¼ a


Then â‰½ is called the dual ordering of â‰¼.


=== Dual Ordered Set ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the dual ordering of â‰¼.


The ordered set ( S, â‰½) is called the dual ordered set (or just dual) of ( S, â‰¼).


That it indeed is an ordered set is a consequence of Dual Ordering is Ordering.

=== Notation for Dual Ordering ===
To denote the dual of an ordering, the conventional technique is to reverse the symbol.

Thus:
:â‰½ denotes â‰¼^-1
:â‰½ denotes â‰¼^-1
:â‹Ÿ denotes â‹^-1

and so:
:a â‰¼ b  b â‰½ a
:a â‰¼ b  b â‰½ a
:a â‹ b  b â‹Ÿ a


Similarly for the standard symbols used to denote an ordering on numbers:
:â‰¥ denotes â‰¤^-1
:â©¾ denotes â©½^-1
:âª– denotes âª•^-1

and so on.

=== Notation for Dual Strict Ordering ===
To denote the dual of an strict ordering, the conventional technique is to reverse the symbol.

Thus:
:â‰» denotes â‰º^-1

and so:
:a â‰º b  b â‰» a


Similarly for the standard symbol used to denote a strict ordering on numbers:
:> denotes <^-1

and so on.

title: Definition:Dual Statement (Order Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let â‰½ be the dual ordering to â‰¼.

Let x3a3 be any statement pertaining to ( S, â‰¼) (be it in natural language or a formal language).


The dual statement of x3a3, denoted x3a3^*, is the statement obtained from replacing every reference to â‰¼ in x3a3 with a reference to its dual â‰½.

This dual statement may then be turned into a statement about â‰¼ again by applying the equivalences on Dual Pairs (Order Theory).

title: Definition:Dual Isomorphism (Order Theory)
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T ) be ordered sets.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a bijection.


Then Ï• is a dual isomorphism between ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T )  if and only if  Ï• and Ï•^-1 are decreasing mappings.


If there is a dual isomorphism between ( S, â‰¼_S ) and ( T, â‰¼_T ), then ( S, â‰¼_S ) is dual to ( T, â‰¼_T ).

Equivalently, ( S, â‰¼_S ) is dual to ( T, â‰¼_T )  if and only if  S with the dual ordering is isomorphic to T.

title: Definition:Dual Order Embedding
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.


A dual order embedding is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T such that:

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )y â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )x


That is:
:if Ï• is an order embedding of ( S, â‰¼_1 ) into ( T, â‰½_2 )
where â‰½_2 is the dual of â‰¼_2.

Category:Definitions/Order Embeddings

title: Definition:Self-Dual (Order Theory)
definition:
Let (S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

If S is dual to S, then S is self-dual.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Eccentricity
definition:
Let K be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant e

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = e p


The constant e is known as the eccentricity of the conic section.

title: Definition:Eccentricity of Vertex
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Let v âˆˆ V be a vertex of G.


The eccentricity of v is the maximum distance from v to another vertex of G:


That is:
:E (   )v = max_u âˆˆ V D (   )v, u

where D (   )v, u denotes the distance from v to u.

title: Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)/Edge
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The edges are the elements of E.


In the above, the edges are AB, AE, BE, CD, CE, CF, DE, DF, FG.


=== Join ===
Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

Let u and v be vertices of G.

Let e = u v be an edge of G.


Then e joins the vertices u and v.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Edge
definition: The edges of a polyhedron are the sides of the polygons which constitute its faces.

title: Definition:Polyhedral Angle/Edge
definition: Each of the half-lines that form a polyhedral angle is known as an edge of the polyhedral angle.

title: Definition:Half-Plane/Edge
definition:
Let ğ’« denote the plane.

Let â„’ denote an infinite straight line in ğ’«.

Let â„‹ denote one of the half-planes into which â„’ divides ğ’«.

Then â„’ is called the edge of â„‹.

title: Definition:Morphism
definition:
Let ğ‚ be a metacategory.


A morphism of ğ‚ is an object f, together with:

* A domain dom f, which is an object of ğ‚
* A codomain cod f, also an object of ğ‚


The collection of all morphisms of ğ‚ is denoted ğ‚_1.


If A is the domain of f and B is its codomain, this is mostly represented by writing:

:f: A â†’ B or A  f âŸ¶ B

title: Definition:Efficiency (Statistics)
definition:
Let T_0 and T_1 both be statistics used as estimators.

Efficiency is a comparison of the variances of T_0 and T_1.


Thus T_0 is of higher efficiency than T_1  if and only if  T_0 has a smaller variance than T_1.

title: Definition:Efficiency (Experimental Design)
definition:
One design is more efficient than another  if and only if :
:the same precision can be achieved with less resources
or
:greater precision can be achieved with the same resources.

title: Definition:Efficiency (Physics)
definition:
Let S be a system.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let S be a system.


The efficiency of S is defined as:
:â„° = E_OE_IÃ— 100 %
where:
:E_I denotes the energy input to S over a particular time interval T
:E_O denotes the energy output from S over that same time interval T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S be a system.


The efficiency of S is defined as:
:â„° = W_LW_EÃ— 100 %
where:
:W_L denotes the work done by the load of S
:W_E denotes the work done by the effort of S.

title: Definition:Elevation of Point
definition: The elevation of a point P is the height of P above some reference horizontal baseline or plane.

title: Definition:Angle of Elevation
definition:
Let A and B be points in space such that A is higher than B.

The angle of elevation of A from B is the angle between the line AB and the horizontal.

title: Definition:Empty Set
definition:
The empty set is a set which has no elements.

That is, x âˆˆâˆ… is false, whatever x is.


It is usually denoted by some variant of a zero with a line through it, for example âˆ… or âˆ…, and can always be represented as {}.

title: Definition:Empty Class (Class Theory)
definition:
A class is defined as being empty  if and only if  it has no elements.

That is:
:âˆ€ x: x âˆ‰ A
or:
:âˆƒ x: x âˆˆ A


The empty class is usually denoted âˆ… or âˆ….

On   the preferred symbol is âˆ….

title: Definition:Empty Mapping
definition:
Let T be a set.


Then the mapping e: âˆ…â†’ T whose domain is the empty set and whose codomain is T is called the empty mapping:
:e âŠ†âˆ…Ã— T = âˆ…

title: Definition:Null Relation
definition:
The null relation is a relation â„› in S to T such that â„› is the empty set:
:â„›âŠ† S Ã— T: â„› = âˆ…


That is, no element of S relates to any element in T:
:â„›: S Ã— T: âˆ€( s, t ) âˆˆ S Ã— T:  s â„› t

title: Definition:Edgeless Graph
definition:
An edgeless graph is a graph with no edges.

That is, an edgeless graph is a graph of size zero.

Equivalently, an edgeless graph is a graph whose vertices are all isolated.


The edgeless graph of order n is denoted N_n and can be referred to as the n-edgeless graph.

title: Definition:Summation/Vacuous Summation
definition:
Take the summation:
:âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j
where Î¦(   )j is a propositional function of j.

Suppose that there are no values of j for which Î¦(   )j is true.

Then âˆ‘_Î¦(   )j a_j is defined as being 0.

This summation is called a vacuous summation.


This is because:
:âˆ€ a: a + 0 = a
where a is a number.

Hence for all j for which Î¦(   )j is false, the sum is unaffected.


This is most frequently seen in the form:
:âˆ‘_j  = m^n a_j = 0
where m > n.

In this case, j can not at the same time be both greater than or equal to m and less than or equal to n.


Some sources consider such a treatment as abuse of notation.

title: Definition:Class Interval/Empty
definition: A class interval is empty  if and only if  it is of frequency zero.

title: Definition:Zero (Category)
definition:
The category 0, zero, is the empty category:


:


with:
:no objects
and consequently:
:no morphisms.

title: Definition:Empty Class (Class Theory)
definition:
A class is defined as being empty  if and only if  it has no elements.

That is:
:âˆ€ x: x âˆ‰ A
or:
:âˆƒ x: x âˆˆ A


The empty class is usually denoted âˆ… or âˆ….

On   the preferred symbol is âˆ….

title: Definition:Class Interval/Empty
definition: A class interval is empty  if and only if  it is of frequency zero.

title: Definition:Uncertainty
definition:
Let X be a discrete random variable.

Let X take a finite number of values with probabilities p_1, p_2, â€¦, p_n.


The uncertainty of X is defined as:

:H (   )X =  -âˆ‘_k p_k  p_k

where:
: denotes logarithm base 2
:the summation is over those k where p_k > 0.


=== Units ===
The unit of measurement used to quantify uncertainty is the bit.


Category:Definitions/Uncertainty

title: Definition:Differential Entropy
definition:
Differential entropy extends the concept of entropy to continuous random variables.

Let X be a continuous random variable.

Let X have probability density function f_X. 

Then the differential entropy of X, h (   )X measured in nats, is given by: 

:h (   )X = -âˆ«_-âˆ^âˆ f_X (   )x ln f_X (   )x  d x


Where f_X (   )x = 0, we take f_X (   )x ln f_X (   )x = 0 by convention.

title: Definition:Entropy (Physics)
definition:
Entropy is a property of a thermodynamic system.

It quantifies the number Î© of microstates that are consistent with the macroscopic quantities that characterize the system.


The entropy of a system is equal to the expectation of the value:
:k ln P
where:
:k is a constant which relates the mean kinetic energy and absolute temperature of the system
:P is the coefficient of probability of the system.

title: Definition:Epicycle (Ptolemaic Astronomy)
definition:
An epicycle is the orbit described by a body moving in a uniform circular motion around a point which is itself moving in a uniform circular motion around another point.

:

That point may itself also be moving in a uniform circular motion around yet another point.

title: Definition:Epicycloid/Generator/Epicycle
definition:
Let an epicycloid be generated by rolling a circle C_1 around the outside of another circle C_2.


:


The circle C_1 can be referred to as the epicycle of the epicycloid.

title: Definition:Hypocycloid/Generator/Epicycle
definition:
Let a hypocycloid be generated by rolling circle C_1 around the inside of another (larger) circle C_2.


:


The circle C_1 can be referred to as the epicycle of the hypocycloid.

title: Definition:Geographical Equator
definition:
The (geographical) equator is the great circle described on the surface of Earth whose plane is perpendicular to Earth's axis of rotation.


:

title: Definition:Celestial Equator
definition:
Consider the celestial sphere with observer O.

Let P be the north celestial pole.


The great circle whose plane is perpendicular to OP is known as the celestial equator.


:

title: Definition:Galactic Equator
definition:
The galactic equator is the great circle that is the intersection of the plane of the Milky Way with the celestial sphere.


=== Galactic Poles ===
The galactic poles are the two poles of the great circle that is the galactic equator.

=== Galactic Axis ===
The galactic axis is the axis of the great circle that is the galactic equator.

title: Definition:Polygon/Equiangular
definition: An equiangular polygon is a polygon in which all the vertices have the same angle.

title: Definition:Equiangular Geometric Figures
definition: Two geometric figures are equiangular (with each other) when the angles of each pair of their corresponding vertices are equal.

title: Definition:Logarithmic Spiral
definition:
The logarithmic spiral is the locus of the equation expressed in polar coordinates as:
:r = a e^b Î¸


:

title: Definition:Rectangular Hyperbola
definition:
A rectangular hyperbola is a hyperbola whose transverse axis is equal to its conjugate axis.


=== Standard Form ===
Let K be a Rectangular hyperbola embedded in a cartesian plane.

K is in standard form  if and only if :
:(1) its major axis is aligned with the straight line y = x
:(2) its minor axis is aligned with the straight line y = -x.


:

title: Definition:Conformal Transformation
definition:
Let T be a transformation of the plane.

Let T have the property that:
:for all pairs of curves ğ’_1 and ğ’_2 which intersect at angle Î¸, the images of ğ’_1 and ğ’_2 under T also intersect at angle Î¸.

Then T is defined as being a conformal transformation.

title: Definition:Semantic Equivalence
definition:
Let â„³ be a formal semantics for a formal language â„’.

Let Ï•, Ïˆ be â„’-WFFs.


Then Ï• and Ïˆ are â„³-semantically equivalent  if and only if :

:Ï•_â„³Ïˆ and Ïˆ_â„³Ï•

that is,  if and only if  they are â„³-semantic consequences of one another.


Equivalently, Ï• and Ïˆ are â„³-semantically equivalent  if and only if , for each â„³-structure â„³:

:â„³_â„³Ï•  if and only if  â„³_â„³Ïˆ

title: Definition:Provable Equivalence
definition:
Let ğ’« be a proof system for a formal language â„’.

Let Ï•, Ïˆ be â„’-WFFs.


Then Ï• and Ïˆ are ğ’«-provably equivalent  if and only if :

:Ï•âŠ¢_ğ’«Ïˆ and ÏˆâŠ¢_ğ’«Ï•

that is,  if and only if  they are ğ’«-provable consequences of one another.


The provable equivalence of Ï• and Ïˆ can be denoted by:

:Ï•âŠ£âŠ¢_ğ’«Ïˆ

title: Definition:Set Equivalence
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Then S and T are equivalent  if and only if :
:there exists a bijection f: S â†’ T between the elements of S and those of T.

That is,  if and only if  they have the same cardinality.


This can be written S âˆ¼ T.


If S and T are not equivalent we write S  T.

title: Definition:Row Equivalence
definition:
Two matrices ğ€ = [ a ]_m n, ğ = [ b ]_m n are row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of elementary row operations.

This relationship can be denoted ğ€âˆ¼ğ.

title: Definition:Column Equivalence
definition:
Two matrices ğ€ = [ a ]_m n, ğ = [ b ]_m n are column equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of elementary column operations.

This relationship can be denoted ğ€âˆ¼ğ.

title: Definition:Topological Equivalence
definition:
=== Homeomorphism: Topological Spaces ===

Let T_Î± = ( S_Î±, Ï„_Î±) and T_Î² = ( S_Î², Ï„_Î²) be topological spaces.

Let f: T_Î±â†’ T_Î² be a bijection.

Let T_Î± = ( S_Î±, Ï„_Î±) and T_Î² = ( S_Î², Ï„_Î²) be topological spaces.

Let f: T_Î±â†’ T_Î² be a bijection.


f is a homeomorphism  if and only if  both f and f^-1 are continuous.


=== Homeomorphism: Metric Spaces ===
Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces.

Let f: A_1 â†’ A_2 be a bijection such that:
:f is continuous from M_1 to M_2
:f^-1 is continuous from M_2 to M_1.


Then:
:f is a homeomorphism
:M_1 and M_2 are homeomorphic.

=== Topologically equivalent metrics ===

Let M_1 = ( A, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A, d_2 ) be metric spaces on the same underlying set A.

Let M_1 = ( A, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A, d_2 ) be metric spaces on the same underlying set A.


d_1 and d_2 are topologically equivalent  if and only if :

:For all metric spaces ( B, d ) and ( C, d' ):
:For all mappings f: B â†’ A and g: A â†’ C:

::(1):    f is ( d, d_1 )-continuous  if and only if  f is ( d, d_2 )-continuous
::(2):    g is ( d_1, d' )-continuous  if and only if  g is ( d_2, d' )-continuous.

Such mappings f and g can be referred to as homeomorphisms.

title: Definition:Equivalence Relation
definition:
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

:(1): reflexive
:(2): symmetric
:(3): transitive

=== Definition 2 ===

:Î”_S âˆªâ„›^-1âˆªâ„›âˆ˜â„›âŠ†â„›

title: Definition:Euclidean Geometry
definition:
Euclidean geometry is the branch of geometry in which the parallel postulate applies.

An assumption which is currently under question is whether or not ordinary space is itself Euclidean.


Euclidean geometry adheres to Euclid's postulates.

title: Definition:Euclidean Space
definition:
Let S be one of the standard number fields â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let S^n be a cartesian space for n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 1.

Let d: S^n Ã— S^n â†’â„ be the usual (Euclidean) metric on S^n.

Then ( S^n, d ) is a Euclidean space.

title: Definition:Euclidean Space/Euclidean Topology
definition:
Let S be one of the standard number fields â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let S^n be a cartesian space for n âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 1.

Let M = ( S^n, d ) be a Euclidean space.


The topology Ï„_d induced by the Euclidean metric d is called the Euclidean topology.

title: Definition:Euclidean Metric
definition:
Let M_1' = ( A_1', d_1') and M_2' = ( A_2', d_2') be metric spaces.

Let A_1'Ã— A_2' be the cartesian product of A_1' and A_2'.


The Euclidean metric on A_1'Ã— A_2' is defined as:

:d_2 (   )x, y := ( ( d_1'(   )x_1, y_1)^2 + ( d_2'(   )x_2, y_2)^2 )^1/2

where x = ( x_1, x_2 ), y = ( y_1, y_2 ) âˆˆ A_1'Ã— A_2'.


=== General Definition ===
Let M_1' = ( A_1', d_1'), M_2' = ( A_2', d_2'), â€¦, M_n' = ( A_n', d_n') be metric spaces.

Let ğ’œ = âˆ_i  = 1^n A_i' be the cartesian product of A_1', A_2', â€¦, A_n'.


The Euclidean metric on ğ’œ = âˆ_i  = 1^n A_i' is defined as:

:d_2 (   )x, y := ( âˆ‘_i  = 1^n ( d_i'(   )x_i, y_i)^2 )^1/2

where x = ( x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n ), y = ( y_1, y_2, â€¦, y_n ) âˆˆğ’œ.

=== Riemannian Manifold ===
Let x âˆˆâ„^n be a point.

Let ( x_1, â€¦, x_n ) be the standard coordinates.

Let T_x â„^n be the tangent space of â„^n at x.

Let T_x â„^n be identified with â„^n:

:T_x â„^n â‰…â„^n
 

Let v, w âˆˆ T_x â„^n be vectors such that:

:v = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n v^i . âˆ‚_i |_x

:w = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n w^i . âˆ‚_i |_x

Let g be a Riemannian metric such that:

:g_x = âŸ¨ v,   âŸ© w_x = âˆ‘_i  = 1^n v^i w^i


Then g is called the Euclidean metric.

title: Definition:Euclidean Norm
definition:
Let ğ¯ = ( v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_n ) be a vector in the real Euclidean n-space â„^n.


The Euclidean norm of ğ¯ is defined as:

title: Definition:Euclidean Domain
definition:
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain.

Let there exist a Euclidean valuation on D.

Then D is called a Euclidean domain.


=== Euclidean Valuation ===
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain with zero 0_D.

Let there exist a mapping Î½: D âˆ–{ 0_D }â†’â„• such that for all a âˆˆ D, b âˆˆ D_ 0_D:

 
 
 
 

Then Î½ is a Euclidean valuation on D.

title: Definition:Euclidean Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


=== Left-Euclidean ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is left-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Right-Euclidean ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is right-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Euclidean ===

â„› is Euclidean  if and only if  it is both left-Euclidean and right-Euclidean.

title: Definition:Euler Characteristic of Finite Graph
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a finite graph.

Let G be embedded in a surface.


The Euler characteristic of G is written Ï‡(   )G and is defined as:
:Ï‡(   )G = v - e + f
where:
:v = | V | is the number of vertices
:e = | E | is the number of edges
:f is the number of faces.

title: Definition:Euler Characteristic of Surface
definition:
Let S be a surface.

Let T be a triangulation of S.

The Euler characteristic of S is written Ï‡(   )S and is defined as:
:Ï‡(   )S = v - e + f
where:
:v = | V | is the number of vertices of T
:e = | E | is the number of edges of T
:f is the number of faces of T.

title: Definition:Exterior (Topology)
definition:
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


The exterior of H is the complement of the closure of H in T.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† T.


The exterior of H is the interior of the complement of H in T.

title: Definition:Exterior Derivative
definition:
Let an exact n-form Ï‰ be given on an m-manifold, with local coordinates x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_m.

:Ï‰ = f (   )x_1, â€¦, x_m d x_Ï•(   )1âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )2âˆ§â‹¯âˆ§d x_Ï•(   )n

For inexact forms:
:d(   )a + b = d a + d b

title: Definition:Polygon/External Angle
definition:
Contrary to intuition, the external angle of a vertex of a polygon is not the size of the angle between the sides forming that vertex, as measured outside the polygon.

An external angle is in fact an angle formed by one side of a polygon and a line produced from an adjacent side.

:

While âˆ  AFE is the internal angle of vertex F, the external angle of this vertex is âˆ  EFG.

title: Definition:Transversal (Geometry)/Exterior Angle
definition:
:


An exterior angle of a transversal is an angle which is not between the two lines cut by a transversal.

In the above figure, the exterior angles with respect to the transversal EF are:
:âˆ  AHE
:âˆ  CJF
:âˆ  BHE
:âˆ  DJF

title: Definition:Exterior Point (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


z_0 is an exterior point of S  if and only if  z_0 has an Ïµ-neighborhood which is disjoint from S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z_0 âˆˆâ„‚.


z_0 is an exterior point of S  if and only if :
:z_0 is not an interior point of S
and:
:z_0 is not a boundary point of S.

title: Definition:Jordan Curve/Exterior
definition:
Let f: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’â„^2 be a Jordan curve.


It follows from the Jordan Curve Theorem that â„^2 âˆ–Img( f ) is a union of two disjoint connected components, one of which is unbounded.

This unbounded component is called the exterior of f, and is denoted as Ext( f ).

title: Definition:Root of Number/Extraction
definition: The process of evaluating roots of a given real number is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Root of Equation/Extraction
definition: The process of finding roots of a given equation is referred to as extraction.

title: Definition:Planar Graph/Face
definition:
:

The faces of a planar graph are the areas which are surrounded by edges.

In the above, the faces are BCEF, ABF, CFG, AFG and ABCDCEG.


=== Incident ===
:


Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph:

Then a face of G is incident to an edge e of G if e is one of those which surrounds the face.

Similarly, a face of G is incident to a vertex v of G if v is at the end of one of those incident edges.


In the above graph, for example, the face BCEF is incident to:
:the edges BC, CE, EF, FB
:the vertices B, C, E, F.

=== Adjacent ===
:

Let G = ( V, E ) be a planar graph.

Two faces of G are adjacent  if and only if  they are both incident to the same edge (or edges).

In the above diagram, BCEF and ABF are adjacent, but BCEF and AFG are not adjacent.


Note that faces which are both incident to the same vertex are not considered adjacent unless they are also both incident to the same edge.

title: Definition:Polyhedron/Face
definition: The faces of a polyhedron are the polygons which contain it.

title: Definition:Geometric Figure/Three-Dimensional Figure/Face
definition: The faces of a three-dimensional figure are the surfaces which form its extremities.

title: Definition:Surface (Geometry)
definition:
and:
: 
:An extremity of a solid is a surface.
 â€
 

=== Plane Surface ===
 


=== Side ===
From the definition of surface, it follows that a plane locally separates space into two sides.

Thus the sides of a plane are the parts of that space into which the plane separates it.


Category:Definitions/Surfaces

=== The Plane ===
The plane is the term used for the general plane surface which is infinite in all directions.

=== Regular Surface ===
A subset S âŠ†â„^3 is a regular surface  if and only if  for each p âˆˆ S there exist:
:a neighborhood V âŠ†â„^3 of p
:an open set U âŠ†â„^2
:a surjective mapping ğ± : U â†’ V âˆ© S, written as:
::ğ±(   )u, v := ( x (   )u, v, y (   )u, v, z (   )u, v)

such that:
:(1):    x (   )u, v, y (   )u, v, z (   )u, v are smooth
:(2):   ğ±: U â†’ V âˆ© S is a homeomorphism
:(3): For each q âˆˆ U, the differential d_q ğ±: â„^2 â†’â„^3 of ğ± at q is one-to-one

title: Definition:Polyhedral Angle/Face
definition: Each of the planes bounded by the defining half-lines is known as a face of the polyhedral angle.

title: Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


( F, +, Ã—) is a field  if and only if :
:(1): the algebraic structure ( F, + ) is an abelian group
:(2): the algebraic structure ( F^*, Ã—) is an abelian group where F^* = F âˆ–{ 0_F }
:(3): the operation Ã— distributes over +.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an integral domain such that every non-zero element a of F has a multiplicative inverse a^-1 such that:
:a Ã— a^-1 = 1_F = a^-1Ã— a
where 1_F denotes the unity of ( F, +, Ã—).


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a commutative ring with unity ( F, +, Ã—) such that every non-zero element a of F has a multiplicative inverse:
:a^-1 such that a Ã— a^-1 = 1_F = a^-1Ã— a
where 1_F denotes the unity of ( F, +, Ã—).


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a non-trivial division ring whose ring product is commutative.


Then ( F, +, Ã—) is a field.

=== Definition 5 ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be an algebraic structure.


( F, +, Ã—) is a field  if and only if  it fulfils the conditions of the field axioms, as follows:
 

=== Addition ===
The distributand + of a field ( F, +, Ã—) is referred to as field addition, or just addition.


=== Additive Group ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field.


The group ( F, + ) is known as the additive group of F.

=== Additive Inverse ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field whose addition operation is +.

Let a âˆˆ R be any arbitrary element of F.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0_F

where 0_F is the zero of R.


=== Additive Inverse of Number ===

The concept is often encountered in the context of numbers:
Let F be one of the standard number systems: â„•, â„¤, â„š, â„, â„‚.

Let a âˆˆ F be any arbitrary number.


The additive inverse of a is its inverse under addition, denoted -a:

:a + ( -a ) = 0

=== Product ===
Let ( F, +, Ã—) be a field.


The distributive operation Ã— in ( F, +, Ã—) is known as the (field) product.

title: Definition:Field of Relation
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


The field of â„› is defined as:
:Field( â„›) := { x âˆˆ S: âˆƒ t âˆˆ T: ( x, t ) âˆˆâ„›}âˆª{ x âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, x ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the union of the domain of â„› with its image.


=== Class Theory ===
 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.


The field of â„› is defined as:
:Field( â„›) := { x âˆˆ V: âˆƒ y âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}âˆª{ y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the union of the domain of â„› with its image.

title: Definition:Vector Field
definition:
Let F be a field which acts on a region of space S.

Let the point-function giving rise to F be a vector quantity.


Then F is a vector field.


=== Vector Field on Smooth Manifold ===
Let M be a smooth manifold.

Let TM be the tangent bundle of M.

Let T_p M be the tangent space at p âˆˆ M.


Then by the vector field on M we mean the continuous map X : M â†’ TM such that:

:âˆ€ p âˆˆ M : X_p âˆˆ T_p M

title: Definition:Operation/Arity/Finitary
definition:
A finitary operation is an operation which takes a finite number of operands.


Category:Definitions/Operations

title: Definition:Logical Argument/Finitary
definition: A finitary argument is a logical argument which starts with a finite number of axioms, and can be translated into a finite number of statements.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Module
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be a module over R.


Then M is finitely generated  if and only if  there is a generator for M which is finite.

title: Definition:Morphism of Schemes of Finite Type
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) and ( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be schemes.

Let f : ( X, ğ’ª_X ) â†’( Y, ğ’ª_Y ) be a morphism of schemes.


f is of finite type  if and only if  f is locally of finite type and quasi-compact.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Algebraic Structure
definition:
Let ( A, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let ( A, âˆ˜) have a generator which is finite.


Then ( A, âˆ˜) is finitely generated.

title: Definition:Generator of Monoid
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid.

Let S âŠ† M.

Let H be the smallest submonoid of M such that S âŠ† H.


Then:
:S is a generator of ( H, âˆ˜)
:S generates ( H, âˆ˜)
:( H, âˆ˜) is the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.


This is written H = âŸ¨ S âŸ©.


If S is a singleton, for example S = { x }, then we can (and usually do) write H = âŸ¨ x âŸ© for H = âŸ¨{ x }âŸ©.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Group
definition:
Let G be a group.


G is finitely generated  if and only if  G has a generator which is finite.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Module
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be a module over R.


Then M is finitely generated  if and only if  there is a generator for M which is finite.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Field Extension
definition:
Let E / F be a field extension.


Then E is said to be finitely generated over F  if and only if , for some Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n âˆˆ E:

:E = F (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n) 

where F (Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n) is the field in E generated by F âˆª{Î±_1, â€¦, Î±_n}.

title: Definition:Finitely Generated Algebra
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring.

Let B be an A-algebra.


Then B is finitely generated  if and only if  B has a generator which is finite.

title: Definition:Conic Section/Focus
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F is known as the focus of ğ’¦.

title: Definition:Ellipse/Focus
definition:
Let K be an ellipse specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ such that 0 < Ïµ < 1

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F is known as the focus of the ellipse.

title: Definition:Parabola/Focus
definition:
:


Let K be a parabola specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D equals the distance q from P to F:
:p = q


The point F is known as the focus of the parabola.

title: Definition:Hyperbola/Focus
definition:
:


Let K be a hyperbola specified in terms of:
:a given straight line D
:a given point F
:a given constant Ïµ such that Ïµ > 1

where K is the locus of points P such that the distance p from P to D and the distance q from P to F are related by the condition:
:q = Ïµ  p


The point F_1 is known as a focus of the hyperbola.

The symmetrically-positioned point F_2 is also a focus of the hyperbola.

title: Definition:FPS/Length/Foot
definition:
The foot is the FPS base unit and an imperial unit of length.


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Altitude of Triangle/Foot
definition:
Let ABC be a triangle.

Let h_a be the altitude of A:

:


The point at which h_a meets BC (or its production) is the foot of the altitude h_a.


Category:Definitions/Triangles

title: Definition:Right Angle/Perpendicular/Foot
definition:
:


The foot of a perpendicular is the point where it intersects the line to which it is at right angles.

In the above diagram, the point C is the foot of the perpendicular CD.

title: Definition:Well-Formed Formula
definition:
Let â„± be a formal language whose alphabet is ğ’œ.

A well-formed formula is a collation in ğ’œ which can be built by using the rules of formation of the formal grammar of â„±.


That is, a collation in ğ’œ is a well-formed formula in â„±  if and only if  it has a parsing sequence in â„±.

title: Definition:Logical Formula
definition:
Let â„’ be a formal language used in the field of symbolic logic.


Then the well-formed formulas of â„’ are often referred to as logical formulas.

They are symbolic representations of statements, and often of compound statements in particular.

title: Definition:Frequency (Physics)
definition:
Let f (   )t be a periodic function of time t.


The frequency of f is the number of periods of f that occur during a unit time interval.


=== Dimension ===
The dimension of measurement of frequency is:
:ğ–³^-1


Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement
Category:Definitions/Frequency

=== Units ===
The SI unit of measurement of frequency  is the hertz Hz:
:1  Hz = 1  s^-1

that is, 1 per second of time.

title: Definition:Periodic Real Function/Frequency
definition:
Let f: â„â†’â„ be a periodic real function.

The frequency Î½ of f is the reciprocal of the period L of f:
:Î½ =  1 L

where:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ X: f (   )x = f (   )x + L

title: Definition:Frequency (Descriptive Statistics)
definition:
Let S be a sample or a population.

Let Ï‰ be a qualitative variable, or a class interval of a quantitative variable.


The frequency of Ï‰ is the number of individuals in S satisfying Ï‰.
