Let S be a sample or a finite population.

Let Ï‰ be a qualitative variable, or a class interval of a quantitative variable.


The relative frequency of Ï‰ is defined as:

:RF(   )Ï‰ := f_Ï‰ n

where:

:f_Ï‰ is the (absolute) frequency of Ï‰

:n is the number of individuals in S.

title: Definition:Cumulative Frequency
definition:
Let ( Î©, x3a3, ) be a probability space.

Let X be a discrete random variable on ( Î©, x3a3, ).


=== Absolute ===
Let ( Î©, x3a3, ) be a probability space.

Let X be a discrete random variable on ( Î©, x3a3, ).


The absolute cumulative frequency of X is defined as:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆDom( X ): acf(   )x = âˆ‘_y â‰¤ xÎ©(   )y

 

=== Relative ===
Let ( Î©, x3a3, ) be a probability space.

:âˆ€ x âˆˆDom( X ): acf(   )x = âˆ‘_y â‰¤ xÎ©(   )y|Dom( X ) |

title: Definition:Frequency Curve (Statistics)
definition: A frequency curve is a smooth curve approximating a frequency polygon for a large data set.

title: Definition:Frequency Curve (Probability Theory)
definition: A frequency curve is a curve representing a frequency function.

title: Definition:FrÃ©chet Space (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


=== Definition 1 ===

Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a FrÃ©chet space or T_1 space  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S such that x  y, both:
::âˆƒ U âˆˆÏ„: x âˆˆ U, y âˆ‰ U
:and:
::âˆƒ V âˆˆÏ„: y âˆˆ V, x âˆ‰ V

That is:
:for any two distinct elements x, y âˆˆ S there exist open sets U, V âˆˆÏ„ such that x is in U but not in V, and y is in V but not in U.


That is:
:( S, Ï„) is T_1  if and only if  every two elements of S are separated.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.


( S, Ï„) is a FrÃ©chet space or T_1 space  if and only if  all points of S are closed in T.

title: Definition:FrÃ©chet Space (Functional Analysis)
definition:
Let â„^Ï‰ denote the countable-dimensional real Cartesian space.

Let:
:x := âŸ¨ x_i âŸ©_i âˆˆâ„• = ( x_0, x_1, x_2, â€¦)
and:
:y := âŸ¨ y_i âŸ©_i âˆˆâ„• = ( y_0, y_1, y_2, â€¦)
denote arbitrary elements of â„^Ï‰.


Let the distance function d: â„^Ï‰Ã—â„^Ï‰â†’â„ be applied to â„^Ï‰ as:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆâ„^Ï‰: d (   )x, y = âˆ‘_i âˆˆâ„•2^-i| x_i - y_i |1 + | x_i - y_i |


The distance function d is referred to as the FrÃ©chet (product) metric.


The resulting metric space ( â„^Ï‰, d ) is then referred to as the FrÃ©chet (metric) space.

title: Definition:Galois Group of Field Extension
definition:
Let L / K be a field extension.


The Galois group of L / K is the subgroup of the automorphism group of L consisting of field automorphisms that fix K point-wise:
:Gal( L / K ) = {ÏƒâˆˆAut( L ): âˆ€ k âˆˆ K: Ïƒ(   )k = k }


=== Topological Group ===
The notation Gal( L / K ) is also a shorthand for the topological group:
:( Gal( L / K ), Ï„)
where Ï„ is the Krull topology.

title: Definition:Galois Group of Polynomial
definition:
Let P be a polynomial.

The Galois group of P is the symmetry group of the roots of P.

title: Definition:Generated Algebraic Substructure
definition:
Let ( A, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

Let G âŠ† A be any subset of A.


The algebraic substructure generated by G is the smallest substructure of ( A, âˆ˜) which contains G.


It is written âŸ¨ G âŸ©.

title: Definition:Generated Submonoid
definition:
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity is e_M.

Let S âŠ† M

Let H be the smallest (with respect to set inclusion) submonoid of M such that ( S âˆª{ e_M }) âŠ† H.


Then ( H, âˆ˜) is the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.


This is written H = âŸ¨ S âŸ©.


If S is a singleton, for example S = { x }, then we can (and usually do) write H = âŸ¨ x âŸ© for H = âŸ¨{ x }âŸ©.


=== Generator ===
Let ( M, âˆ˜) be a monoid

Let S âŠ† M.

Let ( H, âˆ˜) be the submonoid of ( M, âˆ˜) generated by S.

Then S is known as a generator of ( H, âˆ˜).

title: Definition:Generated Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


The subgroup generated by S is the smallest subgroup containing S.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.


The subgroup generated by S is the intersection of all subgroups of G containing S.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ‚ G be a subset.

Let S^-1 be the set of inverses of S.


The subgroup generated by S is the set of words on the union S âˆª S^-1.

title: Definition:Generated Normal Subgroup
definition:
Let G be a group.

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let G be a group. 

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


The normal subgroup generated by S, denoted âŸ¨ S^G âŸ©,  is the intersection of all normal subgroups of G containing S.

=== Definition 2 ===
 

Let G be a group. 

Let S âŠ† G be a subset.


The normal subgroup generated by S, denoted âŸ¨ S^G âŸ©,  is the smallest normal subgroup of G containing S:
:âŸ¨ S^G âŸ© = âŸ¨ x S x^-1: x âˆˆ G âŸ©

title: Definition:Generated Submodule
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let M be an R-module.

Let SâŠ‚ M be a subset of M.


=== R-module ===
Let R be a ring.

Let M = ( G, +, âˆ˜)_R be an R-module.

Let S âŠ‚ M be a subset of M.


The submodule generated by S is the intersection of all submodules of M containing S.

=== Unitary R-Module ===
Let R be a ring with unity.

Let M be a unitary R-module.

Let SâŠ‚ M be a subset.


The submodule generated by S is the set of all linear combinations of elements of S.

title: Definition:Generated Ideal of Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the smallest ideal of R containing S, that is, the intersection of all ideals containing S.


=== Unitary Rings ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the set of all two-sided linear combinations of elements of S.

=== Commutative and Unitary Rings ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a commutative ring with unity.

Let S âŠ† R be a subset of R.


The ideal generated by S is the set of all linear combinations of elements of S.

title: Definition:Genus of Surface
definition:
Let S be a surface.

Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph which is embedded in S.

Let G be such that each of its faces is a simple closed curve.

Let Ï‡(   )G = v - e + f = 2 - 2 p be the Euler characteristic of G where:
:v = | V | is the number of vertices
:e = | E | is the number of edges
:f is the number of faces.

Then p is known as the genus of S.

title: Definition:Genus of Manifold
definition: The genus of a compact topological manifold is the number of handles it has.

title: Definition:Genus of Riemann Surface
definition: The genus of a Riemann surface R is the number of linearly independent holomorphic 1-forms that are defined on R.

title: Definition:Genus of Plane Algebraic Curve
definition:
Let ğ’ be a plane algebraic curve with no singular points.

The genus of ğ’ is defined as:
:d - 1 2
where d denotes the degree of ğ’.


=== Singular Points ===
Let ğ’ be a plane algebraic curve which has 1 or more singular points.

The genus of ğ’ is defined as:
:d - 2 2 - âˆ‘Î´
where:
:d denotes the degree of ğ’
:each term of the summation corresponds to one of the singular points of ğ’
:Î´ is 1 for a double point, but for more complicated singular points is larger.

title: Definition:Grad
definition:
The grad is a measurement of plane angle.

It is defined as 1 100 of a right angle.

title: Definition:Slope
definition:
=== Straight Line ===
Let â„’ be a straight line embedded in a Cartesian plane.

The slope of â„’ is defined as the tangent of the angle that â„’ makes with the x-axis.


=== General Form ===
Let â„’ be a straight line embedded in a Cartesian plane.

Let â„’ be given by the equation:

:l x + m y + n = 0

The slope of â„’ is defined by means of the ordered pair ( -l, m ), where:
:for m  0, Ïˆ = arctan(   )- l m
:for m = 0, Ïˆ = Ï€ 2
where Ïˆ is the angle that â„’ makes with the x-axis.


Thus:
:when m = 0, the slope of â„’ is ( l, 0 ) and â„’ is parallel to the y-axis
:when l = 0, the slope of â„’ is ( 0, m ) and â„’ is parallel to the x-axis.

=== Curve ===
Let P be a point on a curve ğ’ embedded in a Cartesian plane.

The slope of ğ’ at P is defined as the slope of the tangent to ğ’ at P.

title: Definition:Harmonic Mean
definition:
Let x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n âˆˆâ„ be real numbers which are all strictly positive.

The harmonic mean H_n of x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n is defined as:

:1 H_n := 1/n( âˆ‘_k  = 1^n 1/x_k)

That is, to find the harmonic mean of a set of n numbers, take the reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of their reciprocals.

title: Definition:Harmonic Numbers/General Definition
definition:
Let r âˆˆâ„_>0.

For n âˆˆâ„•_> 0 the harmonic numbers order r are defined as follows:
:H^( r )(   )n = âˆ‘_k  = 1^n 1/k^r


=== Complex Extension ===
Let r âˆˆâ„_>0.

For z âˆˆâ„‚âˆ–â„¤_< 0 the harmonic numbers order r can be extended to the complex plane as:
:H^( r ) (   )z = âˆ‘_k  = 1^âˆ( 1/k^r - 1/( k + z )^r)

title: Definition:Ore Number
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a positive integer.

n is an Ore number  if and only if  the harmonic mean of its divisors is an integer.

definition:
The Leibniz Harmonic Triangle is a triangular array where:
:the zeroth element in the nth row, counting from 0, is 1 n + 1

:[    n    0    1    2    3    4    5;    0  1/1;    1  1/2  1/2;    2  1/3  1/6  1/3;    3  1/4 1/12 1/12  1/4;    4  1/5 1/20 1/30 1/20  1/5;    5  1/6 1/30 1/60 1/60 1/30  1/6;      ]

title: Definition:Harmonic Function
definition:
A harmonic function is a is a twice continuously differentiable function f: U â†’â„ (where U is an open set of â„^n) which satisfies Laplace's equation:

:âˆ‚^2 fâˆ‚x_1^2 + âˆ‚^2 fâˆ‚x_2^2 + â‹¯ + âˆ‚^2 fâˆ‚x_n^2 = 0

everywhere on U.


This is usually written using the âˆ‡^2 symbol to denote the Laplacian, as:

:âˆ‡^2 f = 0


=== Riemannian Manifold ===
Let ( M, g ) be a compact Riemannian manifold with or without boundary.

Let C^âˆ(   )M be the smooth function space.

Let u âˆˆ C^âˆ(   )M be a smooth real function on M.

Let âˆ‡^2 be the Laplace-Beltrami operator.


Then u is said to be harmonic  if and only if :
:âˆ‡^2 u = 0

title: Definition:Harmonic Analysis
definition: Harmonic analysis is the study of functions by expressing them as the sum of series of a family of functions such as sines and cosines.

title: Definition:Linear Measure/Height
definition:
Height, like depth, is used as a term for linear measure in a dimension perpendicular to both length and breadth.


However, whereas depth has connotations of down, height is used for distances up from the plane.


=== Euclidean Definition ===

When discussing the size and shape of a general polygon, the words height and width are often seen.

The height of a polygon is the linear measure going up the page.


 
: 
:The height of any figure is the perpendicular drawn from the vertex to the base.
 â€
 

In contrast, the width is the linear measure going across the page.

title: Definition:Triangle (Geometry)/Height
definition:
The height of a triangle is the length of a perpendicular from the apex to whichever side has been chosen as its base.


That is, the length of the altitude so defined.


:

Thus the length of the altitude h_a so constructed is called the height of ABC.

title: Definition:Polygon/Height
definition:
The height of a polygon is the length of a perpendicular from the base to the vertex most distant from the base.


 
: 
:The height of any figure is the perpendicular drawn from the vertex to the base.
 â€

title: Definition:Cone (Geometry)/Height
definition:
:

Let a perpendicular AE be dropped from the apex of a cone to the plane containing its base.

The length h of the line AE is the height of the cone.

title: Definition:Height of Prime Ideal
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let ğ”­ be a prime ideal in A.


The height of ğ”­ is the supremum over all n such that there exists a chain of prime ideals:

:ğ”­_0 â«‹ğ”­_1 â«‹â‹¯â«‹ğ”­_n = ğ”­


It is denoted by:
:ht(   )ğ”­

title: Definition:Height of Proper Ideal
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let I be a proper ideal in A.


The height of I is defined as:
:ht(   )I := inf{ht(   )ğ”­ : ğ”­âˆˆSpec( A )  s.t.  I âŠ†ğ”­}
where:
:ht(   )ğ”­ is the height of ğ”­
:Spec( A ) is the prime spectrum of A

title: Definition:Group Homomorphism
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) and ( H, * ) be groups.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a mapping such that âˆ˜ has the morphism property under Ï•.


That is, âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ G:
:Ï•(   )a âˆ˜ b = Ï•(   )a * Ï•(   )b


Then Ï•: ( G, âˆ˜) â†’( H, * ) is a group homomorphism.

title: Definition:Ring Homomorphism
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) and ( S, âŠ•, * ) be rings.

Let Ï•: R â†’ S be a mapping such that both + and âˆ˜ have the morphism property under Ï•.


That is, âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ R:

 
 
 
 


Then Ï•: ( R, +, âˆ˜) â†’( S, âŠ•, * ) is a ring homomorphism.

definition:
Let ( F, +, Ã—) and ( K, âŠ•, âŠ—) be fields.

Let Ï•: F â†’ K be a mapping such that both + and Ã— have the morphism property under Ï•.


That is, âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ F:

 
 
 
 


Then Ï•: ( F, +, Ã—) â†’( K, âŠ•, âŠ—) is a field homomorphism.

title: Definition:F-Homomorphism
definition:
Let R, S be rings with unity.

Let F be a subfield of both R and S.


Then a ring homomorphism Ï†: R â†’ S is called an F-homomorphism if:
:âˆ€ a âˆˆ F: Ï•(   )a = a


That is, Ï•_F = I_F where:
:Ï•_F is the restriction of Ï• to F
:I_F is the identity mapping on F.

title: Definition:R-Algebraic Structure Homomorphism
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let ( S, âˆ—_1, âˆ—_2, â€¦, âˆ—_n, âˆ˜)_R and ( T, âŠ™_1, âŠ™_2, â€¦, âŠ™_n, âŠ—)_R be R-algebraic structures.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a mapping.


Then Ï• is an R-algebraic structure homomorphism  if and only if :

:(1):   âˆ€ k âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]n: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: Ï•(   )x âˆ—_k y = Ï•(   )x âŠ™_k Ï•(   )y
:(2):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: âˆ€Î»âˆˆ R: Ï•(   )Î»âˆ˜ x = Î»âŠ—Ï•(   )x
where [ 1  . . ]n = { 1, 2, â€¦, n } denotes an integer interval.


Note that this definition also applies to modules and vector spaces.

title: Definition:Homomorphism (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let G = ( V (   )G, E (   )G ) and H = ( V (   )H, E (   )H ) be graphs.


Let there exist a mapping F: V (   )G â†’ V (   )H such that:
:for each edge { u, v }âˆˆ E (   )G
:there exists an edge { F (   )u, F (   )v }âˆˆ E (   )H.


Then G and H are homomorphic.

The mapping F is called a homomorphism from G to H.

title: Definition:Ideal of Ring/Left Ideal
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let ( J, + ) be a subgroup of ( R, + ).


J is a left ideal of R  if and only if :
:âˆ€ j âˆˆ J: âˆ€ r âˆˆ R: r âˆ˜ j âˆˆ J

that is,  if and only if :
:âˆ€ r âˆˆ R: r âˆ˜ J âŠ† J

title: Definition:Ideal of Ring/Right Ideal
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let ( J, + ) be a subgroup of ( R, + ).


J is a right ideal of R  if and only if :
:âˆ€ j âˆˆ J: âˆ€ r âˆˆ R: j âˆ˜ r âˆˆ J

that is,  if and only if :
:âˆ€ r âˆˆ R: J âˆ˜ r âŠ† J

title: Definition:Ideal of Algebra/Left Ideal
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let ( A, âˆ—) be an R-algebra.

Let ( J, âˆ—) be a subalgebra of ( A, âˆ—). 


We say that J is a left ideal of A  if and only if :
:for each a âˆˆ A and x âˆˆ J we have a âˆ— x âˆˆ J.

title: Definition:Ideal of Algebra/Right Ideal
definition:
Let R be a ring.

Let ( A, âˆ—) be an R-algebra.

Let ( J, âˆ—) be a subalgebra of ( A, âˆ—). 


We say that J is a left ideal of A  if and only if :
:for each a âˆˆ A and x âˆˆ J we have x âˆ— a âˆˆ J.

title: Definition:Ideal (Physics)
definition: An ideal (or idealized) object is one in which certain attributes are approximated to zero or infinity.

title: Definition:Identity (Equation)
definition:
An identity is an equation which is true for all values attained by the variables it contains.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Identity (Abstract Algebra)
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


=== Left Identity ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element e_L âˆˆ S is called a left identity (element)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: e_L âˆ˜ x = x

=== Right Identity ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element e_R âˆˆ S is called a right identity (element)  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ e_R = x

=== Two-Sided Identity ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element e âˆˆ S is called an identity (element)  if and only if  it is both a left identity and a right identity:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ e = x = e âˆ˜ x


In Identity is Unique it is established that an identity element, if it exists, is unique within ( S, âˆ˜).

Thus it is justified to refer to it as the identity (of a given algebraic structure).


This identity is often denoted e_S, or e if it is clearly understood what structure is being discussed.

title: Definition:Image (Relation Theory)/Mapping/Mapping
definition:
Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.


=== Definition 1 ===
The image of a mapping f: S â†’ T is the set:

:Img( f ) = { t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: f (   )s = t }

That is, it is the set of values taken by f.

=== Definition 2 ===
The image of a mapping f: S â†’ T is the set:

:Img( f ) = f [ S ]

where f [ S ] is the image of S under f.


=== Class Theory ===

 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let A âŠ† V and B âŠ† V be classes.

Let f: A â†’ B be a class mapping.

The image of â„› is defined and denoted as:
:Img( â„›) := { y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all y such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one x.

title: Definition:Image (Relation Theory)/Relation/Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.


The image of â„› is defined as:

:Img( â„›) := â„›[ S ] = { t âˆˆ T: âˆƒ s âˆˆ S: ( s, t ) âˆˆâ„›}

:Img( â„›) := { s_n âˆˆ S_n: âˆƒ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆâˆ_i  = 1^n - 1 S_i: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}

:Img( â„›) := { s_n âˆˆ S: âˆƒ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n - 1) âˆˆ S^n - 1: ( s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_n ) âˆˆâ„›}

=== Class Theory ===

 
Let V be a basic universe.

Let â„›âŠ† V Ã— V be a relation in V.

:Img( â„›) := { y âˆˆ V: âˆƒ x âˆˆ V: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›}

That is, it is the class of all y such that ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„› for at least one x.

definition:

title: Definition:Fraction/Improper
definition:
An improper fraction is a fraction representing a rational number whose absolute value is greater than 1.

Specifically, when expressed in the form r =  p q, where p and q are integers such that (the absolute value of) the numerator is greater than (the absolute value of) the denominator: | p | > | q |.

title: Definition:Improper Integral
definition:
An improper integral is a definite integral over an interval which is not closed, that is, open or half open, and whose limits of integration are the end points of that interval.

When the end point is not actually in the interval, the conventional definition of the definite integral is not valid.

Therefore we use the technique of limits to specify the integral.


Note: In the below, in all cases the necessary limits must exist in order for the definition to hold.

title: Definition:Inconsistent (Logic)
definition:
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.


A set â„± of logical formulas is inconsistent for ğ’«  if and only if :

:For every logical formula Ï•, â„±âŠ¢_ğ’«Ï•.

That is, every logical formula Ï• is a provable consequence of â„±.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„’ be a logical language.

Let ğ’« be a proof system for â„’.


A set â„± of logical formulas is inconsistent for ğ’«  if and only if :

:There exists a logical formula Ï• such that both
::â„±âŠ¢_ğ’«( Ï•Ï•)

title: Definition:Consistent Simultaneous Equations/Inconsistent
definition:
A set of equations is described as inconsistent  if and only if  they are not consistent

That is, there exists no set of values for its variables such that all the equations are satisfied.

title: Definition:Inertia (Physics)
definition:
Inertia is the tendency of a body to maintain the same velocity in the absence of an external force, in accordance with Newton's First Law of Motion.

Equivalently put, inertia is the resistance of a body to a change in its motion.

Inertia is equivalent to mass.

title: Definition:Inertia of Hermitian Matrix
definition:
Let ğ‡ be a Hermitian matrix.

The inertia of ğ‡ is an ordered triple of integers comprising:
:the number of positive eigenvalues of ğ‡
:the number of negative eigenvalues of ğ‡
:the number of zero eigenvalues of ğ‡
in that order.

title: Definition:Infimum of Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let T âŠ†â„.


A real number c âˆˆâ„ is the infimum of T in â„  if and only if :

:(1):    c is a lower bound of T in â„
:(2):    d â‰¤ c for all lower bounds d of T in â„.


If there exists an infimum of T (in â„), we say that T admits an infimum (in â„).


The infimum of T is denoted inf T or inf(   )T.

definition:

definition:

title: Definition:Integral Closure
definition:
Let A be an extension of a commutative ring with unity R.


Let C be the set of all elements of A that are integral over R.

Then C is called the integral closure of R in A.

title: Definition:Integrally Closed
definition:
=== Ring Extension ===
Let Ï• : A â†ª B be a ring extension.

Let C be the integral closure of A in B.


Then A is integrally closed in B  if and only if  C = Ï•(A).

=== Integral Domain ===
Let R be an integral domain.


Then R is integrally closed  if and only if  it is integrally closed in its field of fractions.

title: Definition:Integral Element of Ring Extension
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let R âŠ† A be a subring.


Then a âˆˆ A is said to be integral over R  if and only if  is is a root of a monic nonzero polynomial over R.

title: Definition:Integral Ring Extension
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let RâŠ‚ A be a subring.


The ring extension R âŠ† A is said to be integral  if and only if  for all a âˆˆ A, a is integral over R.

title: Definition:Integral Domain
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is:

:a commutative ring which is non-null
:with a unity
:in which there are no (proper) zero divisors, that is:
::: âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ D: x âˆ˜ y = 0_D  x = 0_D  or  y = 0_D

that is, in which all non-zero elements are cancellable.

=== Definition 2 ===
An integral domain ( D, +, âˆ˜) is a commutative ring such that ( D^*, âˆ˜) is a monoid, all of whose elements are cancellable.

In this context, D^* denotes the ring D without zero: D âˆ–{ 0_D }.

=== Integral Domain Axioms ===

title: Definition:Integral Polynomial
definition: An integral polynomial is a polynomial over the ring of integers â„¤.

title: Definition:Interior (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The interior of H is the union of all subsets of H which are open in T.


That is, the interior of H is defined as:
:H^âˆ˜ := â‹ƒ_K âˆˆğ•‚ K
where ğ•‚ = { K âˆˆÏ„: K âŠ† H }.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The interior of H is defined as the largest open set of T which is contained in H.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let H âŠ† S.


The interior of H is the set of all interior points of H.

title: Definition:Interior (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let H âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

The interior of H is the subset of H which consists of the interior points of H.

title: Definition:Interior Point (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let S âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the complex plane.

Let z âˆˆ S.


z is an interior point of S  if and only if  z has an Ïµ-neighborhood N_Ïµ(   )z such that N_Ïµ(   )z âŠ† S.

title: Definition:Region
definition:
=== Metric Space ===
Let M = ( A, d ) be a metric space.

A region of M is a subset U of M such that U is:

:(1): non-empty
:(2): path-connected.

=== Complex ===
Let D âŠ†â„‚ be a subset of the set of complex numbers.

D is a region of â„‚  if and only if :
:(1): D is non-empty
:(2): D is path-connected.

=== Region in the Plane ===

The usual usage of region is in the real number plane or complex plane.

A point set R in the plane is a region  if and only if :

:(1): Each point of R is the center of a circle all of whose elements consist of points of R
:(2): Each point of R can be joined by a curve consisting entirely of points of R.

==== Interior ====

The boundary of a region separates its interior from the exterior.

The interior consists of the points of the plane which are the elements of the region.

Such points are called interior points of the region.


It is "usual" that the interior is the "smaller bit" which is visually apparently on the inside as it appears on the page or screen, but this is of course not necessarily the case.


Also see the definition of interior and boundary from a topological perspective.


==== Bounded ====

A region in the the plane is bounded if there is a circle in the plane which encloses it.


Also see the definition of bounded in the context of a metric space.

title: Definition:Polygon/Internal Angle
definition: The internal angle of a vertex of a polygon is the size of the angle between the sides adjacent to that vertex, as measured inside the polygon.

title: Definition:Jordan Curve/Interior
definition:
Let f: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’â„^2 be a Jordan curve.


It follows from the Jordan Curve Theorem that â„^2 âˆ–Img( f ) is a union of two disjoint connected components, one of which is bounded.

This bounded component is called the interior of f, and is denoted as Int( f ).

title: Definition:Polygon/Internal Angle
definition: The internal angle of a vertex of a polygon is the size of the angle between the sides adjacent to that vertex, as measured inside the polygon.

title: Definition:Set Intersection
definition:
Let S and T be sets.


The (set) intersection of S and T is written S âˆ© T.

It means the set which consists of all the elements which are contained in both of S and T:

:x âˆˆ S âˆ© T  x âˆˆ S  x âˆˆ T

or, more formally:

:A = S âˆ© T âˆ€ z: ( z âˆˆ A  z âˆˆ S  z âˆˆ T )


We can write:

:S âˆ© T := { x: x âˆˆ S  x âˆˆ T }

and can voice it S intersect T.


It can be seen that, in this form, âˆ© is a binary operation which acts on sets.


One often says that two sets intersect  if and only if  they have non-empty intersection.


=== Set of Sets ===
Let S be a set of sets.

The intersection of S is:
:â‹‚ S := { x: âˆ€ S âˆˆ S: x âˆˆ S }
That is, the set of all objects that are elements of all the elements of S.


Thus:
:â‹‚{ S, T } := S âˆ© T

=== Family of Sets ===
Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of sets indexed by I.


Then the intersection of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined as:

:â‹‚_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x: âˆ€ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }


=== In the context of the Universal Set ===

In treatments of set theory in which the concept of the universal set is recognised, this can be expressed as follows.

Let ğ•Œ be a universal set.

Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of subsets of ğ•Œ.


Then the intersection of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined and denoted as:

:â‹‚_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x âˆˆğ•Œ: âˆ€ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }

=== Subsets of General Set ===
This definition is the same when the universal set ğ•Œ is replaced by any set X, which may or may not be a universal set:

Let I be an indexing set.

Let âŸ¨ S_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be an indexed family of subsets of a set X.


Then the intersection of âŸ¨ S_i âŸ© is defined as:

:â‹‚_i âˆˆ I S_i := { x âˆˆ X: âˆƒ i âˆˆ I: x âˆˆ S_i }
where i is a bound variable.

=== Countable Intersection ===
Let ğ•Š be a set of sets.

Let âŸ¨ S_n âŸ©_n âˆˆâ„• be a sequence in ğ•Š.

Let S be the intersection of âŸ¨ S_n âŸ©_n âˆˆâ„•:
:S = â‹‚_n âˆˆâ„• S_n


Then S is a countable intersection of sets in ğ•Š.

=== Finite Intersection ===
Let S = S_1 âˆ© S_2 âˆ©â€¦âˆ© S_n.

Then:
:S = â‹‚_i âˆˆâ„•^*_n S_i := { x: âˆ€ i âˆˆâ„•^*_n: x âˆˆ S_i }
where â„•^*_n = { 1, 2, 3, â€¦, n }.


If it is clear from the context that i âˆˆâ„•^*_n, we can also write â‹‚_â„•^*_n S_i.

title: Definition:Intersection (Geometry)
definition:
The intersection of two lines AB and CD is denoted by AB âˆ© CD.

The intersection of two geometric figures is the set of points shared by both figures.


Note that this use of âˆ© is consistent with that of its more usual context of set intersection.


When two lines intersect, they are said to cut each other.

âˆ…    : Img( â„›) âˆ© Y = âˆ…

title: Definition:Inverse Image Mapping/Mapping
definition:
Let S and T be sets.

Let ğ’«( S ) and ğ’«( T ) be their power sets.

Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let S and T be sets.

Let ğ’«( S ) and ğ’«( T ) be their power sets.

The inverse image mapping of f is the mapping f^: ğ’«( T ) â†’ğ’«( S ) that sends a subset Y âŠ† T to its preimage f^-1[ T ] under f:

âˆ…    : Img( f ) âˆ© Y = âˆ…

title: Definition:Inverse Image Presheaf
definition:

title: Definition:Inverse Mapping
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.

Let f^-1âŠ† T Ã— S be the inverse of f:
:f^-1 := {( t, s ): f (   )s = t }


Let f^-1 itself be a mapping:
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ T: ( y, x_1 ) âˆˆ f^-1( y, x_2 ) âˆˆ f^-1 x_1 = x_2
and
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ T: âˆƒ x âˆˆ S: ( y, x ) âˆˆ f


Then f^-1 is called the inverse mapping of f.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let f: S â†’ T and g: T â†’ S be mappings.

Let:
:g âˆ˜ f = I_S
:f âˆ˜ g = I_T
where:
:g âˆ˜ f and f âˆ˜ g denotes the composition of f with g in either order
:I_S and I_T denote the identity mappings on S and T respectively.

That is, f and g are both left inverse mappings and right inverse mappings of each other.


Then:
:g is the inverse (mapping) of f
:f is the inverse (mapping) of g.

title: Definition:Invertible Element
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure which has an identity e_S.

If x âˆˆ S has an inverse, then x is said to be invertible for âˆ˜.


That is, x is invertible  if and only if :

:âˆƒ y âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ y = e_S = y âˆ˜ x


=== Invertible Operation ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


The operation âˆ˜ is invertible  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: âˆƒ r, s âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ r = b = s âˆ˜ a

title: Definition:Nonsingular Matrix
definition:

ğ€ is a nonsingular matrix  if and only if :
:âˆƒğâˆˆ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—): ğ€ğ = ğˆ_n = ğğ€
where ğˆ_n denotes the unit matrix of order n.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.

Let ğ€ be an element of the ring of square matrices ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—).


ğ€ is a nonsingular matrix  if and only if :
:ğ€ 0
where  denotes the determinant.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring with unity.

Let ğ€ be an element of the ring of square matrices ( â„³_R (   )n, +, Ã—).


ğ€ is a nonsingular matrix  if and only if  ğ€ is not singular.

title: Definition:Invertible Bounded Linear Operator
definition:
=== Normed Vector Space ===
Let ( X, â€–Â·â€–) be a normed vector space.

Let T : X â†’ X be an invertible bounded linear transformation.


We say that A is a bounded linear operator. 

=== Inner Product Space ===
Let ( X, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product  space.

Let T : X â†’ X be an invertible bounded linear transformation.


We say that A is a bounded linear operator.

title: Definition:Invertible Bounded Linear Transformation
definition:
=== Normed Vector Space ===
Let ( V, â€–Â·â€–_V ) and ( U, â€–Â·â€–_U ) be normed vector spaces.

Let A : V â†’ U be a bounded linear transformation.


We say that A is invertible as a bounded linear transformation  if and only if :

:A has an inverse mapping that is a bounded linear transformation.


That is:

:there exists a bounded linear transformation B : U â†’ V such that: 

::A âˆ˜ B = I_U
::B âˆ˜ A = I_V

where I_U and I_V are the identity mappings on U and V respectively.

We say that B is the inverse of A and write B = A^-1. 

The process of finding an A^-1 given A is called inverting.

=== Inner Product Space ===
Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) and ( U, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be inner product spaces.

Let A : V â†’ U be a bounded linear transformation.


We say that A is invertible as a bounded linear transformation  if and only if :

:A has an inverse mapping that is a bounded linear transformation.


That is:

:there exists a bounded linear transformation B : U â†’ V such that: 

::A âˆ˜ B = I_U
::B âˆ˜ A = I_V

where I_U and I_V are the identity mappings on U and V respectively.

We say that B is the inverse of A and write B = A^-1. 

The process of finding an A^-1 given A is called inverting.

title: Definition:Power (Algebra)
definition:
=== Natural Numbers ===
Let â„• denote the natural numbers.


For each m âˆˆâ„•, recursively define e_m: â„•â†’â„• to be the mapping:
:e_m (   )n =  1     : n = 0 
 m Ã— e_m (   )x     : n = x + 1
where:
:+ denotes natural number addition.
:Ã— denotes natural number multiplication.


e_m (   )n is then expressed as a binary operation in the form:
:m^n := e_m (   )n

and is called m to the power of n.

=== Integers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

The expression x^n is called x to the power of n.

x^n is defined recursively as:


:x^n =  1     : n = 0 
   
 x Ã— x^n - 1    : n > 0 
   
x^n + 1 x     : n < 0

where x^n + 1 x denotes division.


=== Even Power ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an even integer.


Then x^n is called an even power of x.


Category:Definitions/Integer Powers
Category:Definitions/Even Integers

=== Odd Power ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an odd integer.


Then x^n is called an odd power of x


Category:Definitions/Integer Powers
Category:Definitions/Odd Integers

=== Rational Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number such that x > 0.

Let m âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

Let y = âˆš(x) be the mth root of x.


Then we can write y = x^1/m which means the same thing as y = âˆš(x).


Thus we can define the power to a positive rational number:

Let r =  p q âˆˆâ„š be a positive rational number where p âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0, q âˆˆâ„¤_> 0.

Then x^r is defined as:
:x^r = x^p/q = ( âˆš(x))^p = âˆš(( x^p ) )


When r = -p q âˆˆâ„š: r < 0 we define:
:x^r = x^-p/q =  1 x^p/q
analogously for the negative integer definition.

=== Real Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„_>0 be a (strictly) positive real number.

Let r âˆˆâ„ be a real number.


We define x^r as:

:x^r := exp(   )r ln x
where exp denotes the exponential function.


This definition is an extension of the definition for rational r.

This follows from Logarithms of Powers and Exponential of Natural Logarithm: it can be seen that:
:âˆ€ r âˆˆâ„š: exp(   )r ln x = exp(   )ln(   )x^r = x^r

 

=== Complex Numbers ===
Let z, k âˆˆâ„‚ be complex numbers.


z to the power of k is defined as the multifunction:

:z^k := e^k ln( z )

where:
:e^z is the exponential function
:ln is the  natural logarithm multifunction.


=== Principal Branch ===
The principal branch of a complex number raised to a complex power is defined as:

:z^k = e^k Ln z

where Ln z is the principal branch of the natural logarithm.


=== Positive Real Base ===
Let t > 0 be a real number and let k be a complex number.


The principal branch of a positive real number raised to a complex power is defined as:

:t^k = e^k ln t

where ln is the natural logarithm of a positive real number.


Category:Definitions/Complex Powers

Category:Definitions/Complex Powers

=== Multiindices ===
Let k = âŸ¨k_jâŸ©_j = 1, â€¦, n be a multiindex indexed by { 1, â€¦, n }.

Let x = ( x_1, â€¦, x_n ) âˆˆâ„^n be an ordered tuple of real numbers.


Then x^k is defined as:

:x^k := âˆ_j  = 1^n x_j^k_j
where the powers on the   are integer powers.


Category:Definitions/Analysis

=== Power of Zero ===
Let r âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

(This includes the situation where r âˆˆâ„¤ or r âˆˆâ„š.)

When x=0, x^r is defined as follows:

:0^r =  1     : r = 0 
 0     : r > 0 
Undefined    : r < 0

This takes account of the awkward case 0^0: it is "generally accepted" that 0^0 = 1 as this convention agrees with certain general results which would otherwise need a special case.

title: Definition:Involution (Mapping)
definition:
Let A be a set.

Let f: A â†’ A be a mapping on A.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let A be a set.

Let f: A â†’ A be a mapping on A.


f is an involution  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x âˆˆ A: f (   )f (   )x = x

That is:
:f âˆ˜ f = I_A
where I_A denotes the identity mapping on A.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let A be a set.

Let f: A â†’ A be a mapping on A.


f is an involution  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ A: f (   )x = y  f (   )y = x

=== Definition 3 ===
Let A be a set.

Let f: A â†’ A be a mapping on A.


f is an involution  if and only if  f is both a bijection and a symmetric relation.

That is,  if and only if  f is a bijection such that:
:f = f^-1

title: Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring
definition:
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain whose zero is 0_D.

Let ( U_D, âˆ˜) be the group of units of ( D, +, âˆ˜).


Let x âˆˆ D: x âˆ‰ U_D, x  0_D, that is, x is non-zero and not a unit.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain whose zero is 0_D.

Let ( U_D, âˆ˜) be the group of units of ( D, +, âˆ˜).

Let x âˆˆ D: x âˆ‰ U_D, x  0_D, that is, x is non-zero and not a unit.


x is defined as irreducible  if and only if  it has no non-trivial factorization in D.

That is,  if and only if  x cannot be written as a product of two non-units.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( D, +, âˆ˜) be an integral domain whose zero is 0_D.

Let ( U_D, âˆ˜) be the group of units of ( D, +, âˆ˜).

Let x âˆˆ D: x âˆ‰ U_D, x  0_D, that is, x is non-zero and not a unit.


x is defined as irreducible  if and only if  the only divisors of x are its associates and the units of D.

That is,  if and only if  x has no proper divisors.

title: Definition:Irreducible Polynomial
definition:
An irreducible polynomial is a polynomial which is not reducible.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let R be an integral domain.


An irreducible polynomial over R is an irreducible element of the polynomial ring R [ X ].

=== Definition 2: for fields ===
Let K be a field.


An irreducible polynomial over K is a nonconstant polynomial over K that is not the product of two polynomials of smaller degree.

=== Definition 3: for fields ===
Let K be a field.


An irreducible polynomial over K is a polynomial over K that is not the product of two nonconstant polynomials.

title: Definition:Irreducible Space
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  there exists no cover of T by two proper closed sets of T.

=== Definition 2 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  there is no finite cover of T by proper closed sets of T.

=== Definition 3 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  every two non-empty open sets of T have non-empty intersection:

:âˆ€ U, V âˆˆÏ„: U, V âˆ… U âˆ© V âˆ…

=== Definition 4 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  every non-empty open set of T is (everywhere) dense in T.

=== Definition 5 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  the interior of every proper closed set of T is empty.

=== Definition 6 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  the closure of every non-empty open set is the whole space:
:âˆ€ U âˆˆÏ„: U âˆ… U^- = S

=== Definition 7 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is irreducible  if and only if  every open set of T is connected.

title: Definition:Irreducible Subset (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let A be a subset of S.


Then A is irreducible (subset)  if and only if 
:A is non-empty and closed and for all closed subsets B, C of S: A = B âˆª C  A = B or A = C

title: Definition:Irreducible (Representation Theory)/Linear Representation
definition:
Let Ï: G â†’GL( V ) be a linear representation.

Then Ï is irreducible  if and only if  it is not reducible.


That is,  if and only if  there exists no non-trivial proper vector subspace W of V such that:
: âˆ€ g âˆˆ G: Ï(   )g (   )W âŠ† W


Category:Definitions/Representation Theory

title: Definition:Meet Irreducible Element
definition:
Let (S, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a meet semilattice.

Let g âˆˆ S.


Then g is meet irreducible  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: g = x âˆ§ y  g = x or g = y


=== Lattice ===
Let L = ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be a lattice.

Let z âˆˆ S.


Then z is said to be meet irreducible in L  if and only if :
:z is meet irreducible in the meet semilattice ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼)

title: Definition:Completely Irreducible
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Let p âˆˆ S.

An element p is completely irreducible  if and only if 
:p^â‰½âˆ–{ p } admits a minimum element
where p^â‰½ denotes the upper closure of p.

title: Definition:Irreducible Scheme
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) be a scheme.


Then ( X, ğ’ª_X ) is irreducible  if and only if  X is an irreducible space.

title: Definition:Isometry (Metric Spaces)
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces or pseudometric spaces.


Let Ï•: A_1 â†’ A_2 be a bijection such that:
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ A_1: d_1 (   )a, b = d_2 (   )Ï•(   )a, Ï•(   )b


Then Ï• is called an isometry.

That is, an isometry is a distance-preserving bijection.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces or pseudometric spaces.


:M_1 and M_2 are isometric  if and only if  there exist inverse mappings Ï•: A_1 â†’ A_2 and Ï•^-1: A_2 â†’ A_1 such that:

::âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ A_1: d_1 (   )a, b = d_2 (   )Ï•(   )a, Ï•(   )b
:and:
::âˆ€ u, v âˆˆ A_2: d_2 (   )u, v = d_1 (   )Ï•^-1(   )u, Ï•^-1(   )v

Such metric spaces M_1 and M_2 are defined as being isometric.


=== Isometry Into ===
Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces or pseudometric spaces.


Let Ï•: A_1 â†’ A_2 be an injection such that:
:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ A_1: d_1 (   )a, b = d_2 (   )Ï•(   )a, Ï•(   )b


Then Ï• is called an isometry (from M_1) into M_2.


That is, an isometry (from M_1) into M_2 is an isometry which is not actually a surjection, but satisfies the other conditions for being an isometry.

title: Definition:Isometry (Euclidean Geometry)
definition:
Let â„° be a real Euclidean space.


Let Ï•: â„°â†’â„° be a bijection such that:
:âˆ€ P, Q âˆˆâ„°: PQ = P'Q'
where:
:P and Q are arbitrary points in â„°
:P' and Q' are the images of P and Q respectively
:PQ and P'Q' denote the lengths of the straight line segments PQ and P'Q' respectively.


Then Ï• is an isometry.


That is, an isometry is a bijection which preserves distance between points.


=== Context ===
An isometry is defined usually for either:
:n = 2, representing the plane
or:
:n = 3, representing ordinary space.

title: Definition:Isometry (Inner Product Spaces)
definition:
Let V and W be inner product spaces.

Let their inner products be âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_V and âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_W respectively.

Let the mapping F : V â†’ W be a vector space isomorphism that preserves inner products:

:âˆ€ v_1, v_2 âˆˆ V : âŸ¨ v_1,   âŸ©v_2_V = âŸ¨ F (   )v_1,   âŸ©F (   )v_2_W


Then F is called a (linear) isometry.


=== Hilbert Spaces ===
Let H and K be Hilbert spaces.

Let their inner products be âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_H and âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·_K respectively.


A linear map U: H â†’ K is called an isometry  if and only if :

:âˆ€ g,h âˆˆ H: âŸ¨ g,   âŸ© h_H = âŸ¨ U g,   âŸ©U h_K

title: Definition:Isometry (Riemannian Manifolds)
definition:
Let ( M, g ) and ( MÌƒ, gÌƒ) be Riemannian manifolds with Riemannian metrics g and gÌƒ respectively.

Let the mapping Ï• : M â†’MÌƒ be a diffeomorphism such that:

:Ï•^* gÌƒ = g


Then Ï• is called an isometry from ( M, g ) to ( MÌƒ, gÌƒ).

title: Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)/Group Isomorphism
definition:
Let ( G, âˆ˜) and ( H, * ) be groups.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a (group) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a group isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a bijection.


That is, Ï• is a group isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is both a monomorphism and an epimorphism.


If G is isomorphic to H, then the notation G â‰… H can be used (although notation varies).

title: Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)/Ring Isomorphism
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) and ( S, âŠ•, * ) be rings.

Let Ï•: R â†’ S be a (ring) homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a ring isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a bijection.

That is, Ï• is a ring isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is both a monomorphism and an epimorphism.

title: Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)/R-Algebraic Structure Isomorphism
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ—_1, âˆ—_2, â€¦, âˆ—_n, âˆ˜)_R and ( T, âŠ™_1, âŠ™_2, â€¦, âŠ™_n, âŠ—)_R be R-algebraic structures.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be an R-algebraic structure homomorphism.


Then Ï• is an R-algebraic structure isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a bijection.


=== Module Isomorphism ===
Let R be a ring.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R and ( H, +_H, âˆ˜)_R be R-modules.

Let Ï•: G â†’ H be a module homomorphism.


Then Ï• is a module isomorphism  if and only if  Ï• is a bijection.

=== Vector Space Isomorphism ===
Let ( V, +, âˆ˜) and ( W, +', âˆ˜' ) be K-vector spaces.

Then Ï•: V â†’ W is a vector space isomorphism  if and only if :

:(1):   Ï• is a bijection
:(2):   âˆ€ğ±, ğ²âˆˆ V: Ï•(   )ğ± + ğ² = Ï•(   )ğ± +' Ï•(   )ğ²
:(3):   âˆ€ğ±âˆˆ V: âˆ€Î»âˆˆ K: Ï•(   )Î»ğ± = Î»Ï•(   )ğ±


Category:Definitions/Isomorphisms (Abstract Algebra)
Category:Definitions/R-Algebraic Structure Isomorphisms
Category:Definitions/Linear Algebra

title: Definition:Relation Isomorphism
definition:
Let ( S_1, â„›_1 ) and ( S_2, â„›_2 ) be relational structures.

Let there exist a bijection Ï•: S_1 â†’ S_2 such that:
:(1):   âˆ€( s_1, t_1 ) âˆˆâ„›_1: ( Ï•(   )s_1, Ï•(   )t_1) âˆˆâ„›_2
:(2):   âˆ€( s_2, t_2 ) âˆˆâ„›_2: ( Ï•^-1(   )s_2, Ï•^-1(   )t_2) âˆˆâ„›_1


Then ( S_1, â„›_1 ) and ( S_2, â„›_2 ) are isomorphic, and this is denoted S_1 â‰… S_2.


The function Ï• is called a relation isomorphism, or just an isomorphism, from ( S_1, â„›_1 ) to ( S_2, â„›_2 ).

title: Definition:Order Isomorphism
definition:
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.


Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a bijection such that:

:Ï•: S â†’ T is order-preserving
:Ï•^-1: T â†’ S is order-preserving.

Then Ï• is an order isomorphism.


That is, Ï• is an order isomorphism  if and only if :

:Ï• is bijective
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )x â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )y
:âˆ€ p, q âˆˆ T: p â‰¼_2 q Ï•^-1(   )p â‰¼_1 Ï•^-1(   )q

So an order isomorphism can be described as a bijection that preserves ordering in both directions.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.


Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a surjective order embedding.

Then Ï• is an order isomorphism.


That is, Ï• is an order isomorphism  if and only if :

:(1):   Ï• is surjective
:(2):   âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )x â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )y

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be ordered sets.


Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a bijection such that:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )x â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )y

Then Ï• is an order isomorphism.

=== Well-Orderings ===

When â‰¼_1 and â‰¼_2 are well-orderings, the condition on the order preservation can be relaxed:

Let ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) be well-ordered sets.

Let Ï•: S â†’ T be a bijection such that Ï•: S â†’ T is order-preserving:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )x â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )y


Then Ï• is an order isomorphism.


Two well-ordered sets ( S, â‰¼_1 ) and ( T, â‰¼_2 ) are (order) isomorphic  if and only if  there exists such an order isomorphism between them.

Thus ( S, â‰¼_1 ) is described as (order) isomorphic to (or with) ( T, â‰¼_2 ), and vice versa.

This may be written ( S, â‰¼_1 ) â‰…( T, â‰¼_2 ).


Where no confusion is possible, it may be abbreviated to S â‰… T.


=== Class-Theoretical Definition ===
 
Let ( A, â‰¼_1 ) and ( B, â‰¼_2 ) be well-ordered classes.

Let Ï•: A â†’ B be a bijection such that Ï•: A â†’ B is order-preserving:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: x â‰¼_1 y Ï•(   )x â‰¼_2 Ï•(   )y


Then Ï• is an order isomorphism.

title: Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)/Ordered Structure Isomorphism
definition:
An ordered structure isomorphism from an ordered structure ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to another ( T, *, â‰¼) is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T that is both:

:(1): An isomorphism, that is a bijective homomorphism, from the structure ( S, âˆ˜) to the structure ( T, * )
:(2): An order isomorphism from the ordered set ( S, â‰¼) to the ordered set ( T, â‰¼).


=== Ordered Semigroup Isomorphism ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) and ( T, *, â‰¼) be ordered semigroups.


An ordered semigroup isomorphism from ( S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to ( T, *, â‰¼) is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T that is both:

:(1): A semigroup isomorphism from the semigroup ( S, âˆ˜) to the semigroup ( T, * )

:(2): An order isomorphism from the ordered set ( S, â‰¼) to the ordered set ( T, â‰¼).

=== Ordered Group Isomorphism ===
Let (S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) and (T, *, â‰¼) be ordered groups.


An ordered group isomorphism from (S, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to (T, *, â‰¼) is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T that is both:

:(1): A group isomorphism from the group (S, âˆ˜) to the group (T, *)

:(2): An order isomorphism from the ordered set (S, â‰¼) to the ordered set (T, â‰¼).

=== Ordered Ring Isomorphism ===
Let ( S, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) and ( T, âŠ•, *, â‰¼) be ordered rings.


An ordered ring isomorphism from ( S, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to ( T, âŠ•, *, â‰¼) is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T that is both:

:(1): An ordered group isomorphism from the ordered group ( S, +, â‰¼) to the ordered group ( T, âŠ•, â‰¼)

:(2): A semigroup isomorphism from the semigroup ( S, âˆ˜) to the semigroup ( T, * ).

=== Ordered Field Isomorphism ===
Let ( S, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) and ( T, âŠ•, *, â‰¼) be ordered fields.


An ordered field isomorphism from ( S, +, âˆ˜, â‰¼) to ( T, âŠ•, *, â‰¼) is a mapping Ï•: S â†’ T that is both:

:(1): An ordered group isomorphism from the ordered group ( S, +, â‰¼) to the ordered group ( T, âŠ•, â‰¼)

:(2): A group isomorphism from the group ( S_ 0, âˆ˜) to the semigroup ( T_ 0, * )

where S_ 0 and T_ 0 denote the sets S and T without the zeros of S and T respectively.

title: Definition:Isotropy (Physics)
definition: Isotropy is a property of a physical system such that measurements of that system are independent of the direction in which those measurements are taken.

title: Definition:Isotropy Representation
definition:
Let ( M, g ) be a Riemannian manifold.

Let Iso(   )M, g be the set of all isometries from M to itself.

Let Iso_p (   )M, g be the isotropy subgroup at p âˆˆ M.

That is, let Iso_p (   )M, g be the subgroup of Iso(   )M, g consisting of isometries that fix p âˆˆ M.

Let T_p M be the tangent space of M at p âˆˆ M.

For each Ï•âˆˆIso_p (   )M, g let dÏ•_p be a linear mapping such that:

:dÏ•_p : T_p M â†’ T_p M

Let GL( T_p M ) be the general linear group over T_p M.

Let I_p : Iso_p (   )M, gâ†’GL( T_p M ) be a mapping such that I_p (   )Ï• =  dÏ•_p.


Then the mapping I_p is a representation of Iso_p (   )M, g and is called the isotropy representation.

title: Definition:Kernel of Group Action
definition:
Let G be a group with identity e.

Let X be a set.

Let * : GÃ— Xâ†’ X be a group action.


=== Definition 1 ===

Let X be a set.

The kernel of the group action is the set:
:G_0 = { g âˆˆ G: âˆ€ x âˆˆ X: g * x = x }

=== Definition 2 ===
Let G be a group with identity e.

Let X be a set.

Let * : G Ã— X â†’ X be a group action.


The kernel of the group action is the kernel of its permutation representation.

:(   )Ï• := Ï•^-1[ { e_H }]

=== In Vector Space ===

Let ( ğ•', +, Ã—) be a vector space whose zero vector is 0'.

Let T: ğ•â†’ğ•' be a linear transformation.


Then the kernel of T is defined as:

:(   )T := T^-1[ {0' }] = {ğ±âˆˆğ•: T (   )ğ± = 0' }

title: Definition:Kernel of Homomorphism of Differential Complexes
definition:
Let ( R, +, Â·) be a ring.

Let:
:M:   â‹¯âŸ¶ M_i d_iâŸ¶ M_i + 1d_i + 1âŸ¶ M_i + 2d_i + 2âŸ¶â‹¯
and

be two differential complexes of R-modules.

For each i âˆˆâ„¤ let f_i be the restriction of d_i to K_i.

definition:
Let F (   )p be an integral transform:

:F (   )p = âˆ«_a^b f (   )x K (   )p, x d x


The function K (   )p, x is the kernel of F (   )p.

definition:
Consider the integral equation:

:of the first kind:

title: Definition:Kernel (Measure Theory)
definition:
Let ( X, x3a3) be a measurable space.

Let R_â‰¥ 0 be the set of positive extended real numbers.


A kernel is a mapping N: X Ã—x3a3â†’â„_â‰¥0 such that:

:(1):   âˆ€ x âˆˆ X: N_x: x3a3â†’R_â‰¥ 0, E â†¦ N (   )x, E is a measure
:(2):   âˆ€ E âˆˆx3a3: N_E: X â†’R_â‰¥ 0, x â†¦ N (   )x, E is a positive x3a3-measurable function

title: Definition:Knot Theory
definition: Knot theory is the branch of geometry which studies the embedding of knots in 3-dimensional space.

title: Definition:Knot (Knot Theory)
definition:
Let Y be a manifold and X âŠ‚ Y a submanifold of Y.

Let i: X â†’ Y be an inclusion, that is a mapping such that i [ X ] = X.


Then a knotted embedding is an embedding Ï•: X â†’ Y (or the image of such an embedding) such that Ï•[ X ] is not freely homotopic to i [ X ].


=== Sphere Knot ===
A knotted n-sphere is a knotted embedding:
: Ï•:  S^n â†’â„^n + 2


Category:Definitions/Knot Theory

=== Circle Knot ===
The description of the sphere is dropped for S^1 and the term knot is used without qualification for knotted embeddings Ï•:  S^1 â†’â„^3.

 


Category:Definitions/Knot Theory

=== Elementary Knot ===
Circle knots can often be quite wild and unwieldy - most of modern knot theory concerns itself with a specific kind of knot.

These knots are described as a finite set of points in â„^3 called { x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n }, together with line segments from x_i to x_i + 1 and a line segment from x_n to x_1.

The union of all these line segments is clearly a circle knot, or an unknot, an embedding of the circle which is homotopic to a circle.


 

Category:Definitions/Knot Theory

title: Definition:Knot (Unit of Measurement)
definition:
The knot is a unit of speed which is used for air and sea navigation.

It is defined as 1 nautical mile per hour.

It is now defined as exactly 1   852 metres per hour.


=== Conversion Factors ===

title: Definition:Spline Function/Knot
definition:
Let [ a  . . ]b be a closed real interval.

Let T := { a = t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n = b } form a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b.

Let S: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„ be a spline function on [ a  . . ]b on T.


The points T := { t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n } of S are known as the knots.


=== Knot Vector ===
Let [ a  . . ]b be a closed real interval.

Let T := { a = t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n = b } form a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b.

Let S: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„ be a spline function on [ a  . . ]b on T.


The ordered n + 1-tuple ğ­ := ( t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n ) of S is known as the knot vector.


Category:Definitions/Knots of Splines

title: Definition:Lattice (Order Theory)
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
Let ( S, â‰¼) be an ordered set.

Suppose that S admits all finite non-empty suprema and finite non-empty infima.

Denote with âˆ¨ and âˆ§ the join and meet operations on S, respectively.


Then the ordered structure ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is called a lattice.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) be an ordered structure.


Then ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is called a lattice  if and only if :

:(1):   ( S, âˆ¨, â‰¼) is a join semilattice
and:
:(2):   ( S, âˆ§, â‰¼) is a meet semilattice.


That is, for all a, b âˆˆ S:

:a âˆ¨ b is the supremum of { a, b }
and:
:a âˆ§ b is the infimum of { a, b }

=== Definition 3 ===
Let ( S, âˆ¨) and ( S, âˆ§) be semilattices on a set S.

Suppose that âˆ¨ and âˆ§ satisfy the absorption laws, that is, for all a, b âˆˆ S:

:a âˆ¨( a âˆ§ b ) = a
:a âˆ§( a âˆ¨ b ) = a

Let â‰¼ be the ordering on S defined by:

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: a â‰¼ b  if and only if  a âˆ¨ b = b

as on Semilattice Induces Ordering.


Then the ordered structure ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is called a lattice.


Thus ( S, âˆ¨, âˆ§, â‰¼) is called a lattice  if and only if  the lattice axioms are satisfied and â‰¼ is defined as above:

title: Definition:Point Lattice
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A point lattice is a discrete subgroup of â„^m under vector addition.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„^m be the m-dimensional real Euclidean space.

Let {ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n } be a linearly independent set of vectors of â„^m.

A point lattice in â„^m is the set of all integer linear combinations of such vectors.


That is:
:â„’(   )ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n = {âˆ‘_i  = 1^n a_i ğ¯_i : a_i âˆˆâ„¤}

=== Basis ===
Let â„^m be the m-dimensional real Euclidean space.

Let â„¬ = {ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n } be a linearly independent set of vectors of â„^m.

Let â„’(   )â„¬ be the point lattice in â„^m:

:â„’(   )â„¬ = {âˆ‘_i  = 1^n a_i ğ¯_i : a_i âˆˆâ„¤}


Then â„¬ is known as a basis of â„’(   )â„¬.

=== Dimension ===
Let â„^m be the m-dimensional real Euclidean space.

Let â„¬ = {ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n } be a linearly independent set of vectors of â„^m.

Let â„’(   )â„¬ be the point lattice in â„^m whose basis is â„¬.


The cardinality n of â„¬ is known as the dimension of â„’(   )â„¬.

=== Determinant ===
Let â„^m be the m-dimensional real Euclidean space.

Let â„¬ = {ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n } be a linearly independent set of vectors of â„^m.

Let â„’(   )â„¬ be the point lattice in â„^m whose basis is â„¬.


Let â„³ = [ ğ¯_1 ğ¯_2   â‹¯ ğ¯_n ] be the square matrix formed by writing the coordinates of ğ¯_1, ğ¯_2, â€¦, ğ¯_n in rows.

The determinant ğ’Ÿ of â„’(   )â„¬ is the absolute value of the determinant of â„³:
:ğ’Ÿ = |[ ğ¯_1 ğ¯_2   â‹¯ ğ¯_n ]|

title: Definition:Leading Coefficient of Polynomial
definition:
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let P âˆˆ R [ X ] be a nonzero polynomial over R.

Let n be the degree of P.


The leading coefficient of P is the coefficient of x^n in P.

 

Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let ( S, +, âˆ˜) be a subring of R.

Let f = âˆ‘_k  = 0^n a_k âˆ˜ x^k be a polynomial in x over S.


The coefficient a_n  0_R is called the leading coefficient of f.


=== Polynomial Form ===
Let R be a commutative ring with unity.

Let f = a_0 + a_1 X + â‹¯ + a_r-1 X^r-1 + a_r X^r be a polynomial form in the single indeterminate X over R.


Then the ring element a_r is called the leading coefficient of f.

title: Definition:Leading Coefficient of Matrix
definition:
Let ğ€ = [ a ]_m n be an m Ã— n matrix.

The leading coefficient of each row of ğ€ is the leftmost non-zero element of that row.


A zero row has no leading coefficient.

title: Definition:Left (Direction)

Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— T be a relation.

title: Definition:Left Quasi-Reflexive Relation
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is left quasi-reflexive  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ S: ( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›( x, x ) âˆˆâ„›

=== Definition 2 ===
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is left quasi-reflexive  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x âˆˆDom( â„›): ( x, x ) âˆˆâ„›

where Dom( â„›) denotes the domain of â„›.

title: Definition:Euclidean Relation/Left-Euclidean
definition:
Let â„›âŠ† S Ã— S be a relation in S.


â„› is left-Euclidean  if and only if :

:( x, z ) âˆˆâ„›( y, z ) âˆˆâ„›( x, y ) âˆˆâ„›

definition:
Let A be a class.

Let â„› be a relation on A.


An element x of A is left normal with respect to â„›  if and only if :
:âˆ€ y âˆˆ A: â„›(   )x, y holds.

title: Definition:Cancellable Element/Left Cancellable
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


An element x âˆˆ( S, âˆ˜) is left cancellable  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a, b âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ a = x âˆ˜ b  a = b

title: Definition:Left Cancellable Operation
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.


The operation âˆ˜ in ( S, âˆ˜) is left cancellable  if and only if :
:âˆ€ a, b, c âˆˆ S: a âˆ˜ b = a âˆ˜ c  b = c

That is,  if and only if  all elements of ( S, âˆ˜) are left cancellable.

definition:
A mapping f: Y â†’ Z is left cancellable (or left-cancellable)  if and only if :

:âˆ€ X: âˆ€( g_1, g_2: X â†’ Y ): f âˆ˜ g_1 = f âˆ˜ g_2  g_1 = g_2

That is, for any set X, if g_1 and g_2 are mappings from X to Y:
:If f âˆ˜ g_1 = f âˆ˜ g_2
:then g_1 = g_2.

title: Definition:Left Inverse Mapping
definition:
Let S, T be sets where S âˆ…, that is, S is not empty.

Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping.


Let g: T â†’ S be a mapping such that:
:g âˆ˜ f = I_S
where:
:g âˆ˜ f denotes the composite mapping f followed by g;
:I_S is the identity mapping on S.


Then g: T â†’ S is called a left inverse (mapping).

title: Definition:Inverse (Abstract Algebra)/Left Inverse

Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity is e_S.

An element x_L âˆˆ S is called a left inverse of x  if and only if :
:x_L âˆ˜ x = e_S

title: Definition:Inverse Matrix/Left
definition:
Let m, n âˆˆâ„¤_>0 be a (strictly) positive integer.


Let ğ€ = [ a ]_m n be a matrix of order m Ã— n.

Let ğ = [ b ]_n m be a matrix of order n Ã— m such that:
:ğğ€ = ğˆ_n

where ğˆ_n denotes the unit matrix of order n.


Then ğ is known as a left inverse (matrix) of ğ€.

title: Definition:Linear Measure/Length
definition:
Length is linear measure taken in a particular direction.

Usually, in multi-dimensional figures, the dimension in which the linear measure is greatest is referred to as length.

It is the most widely used term for linear measure, as it is the standard term used when only one dimension is under consideration.


Length is the fundamental notion of Euclidean geometry, never defined but regarded as an intuitive concept at the basis of every geometrical theorem.


=== Vector Definition ===
Let A and B be points in a real Euclidean space â„^n.

Let ğš and ğ› be the position vectors of A and B respectively.


The length of the straight line AB is given by:
:L (   )AB := |ğš - ğ›|
where:
:ğš - ğ› denotes the vector subtraction operation
:|ğš - ğ›| denotes the magnitude of ğš - ğ›.

title: Definition:Real Interval/Length
definition:
Let:
:[ a  . . ]b
or
:[ a  . . )b
or
:( a  . . ]b
or
:( a  . . )b
be a real interval.


The difference b - a between the endpoints is called the length of the interval.

title: Definition:Arc Length
definition:
Let y = f (   )x be a real function which is:
:continuous on the closed interval [ a  . . ]b
and:
:continuously differentiable on the open interval ( a  . . )b.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let y = f (   )x be a real function which is:
:continuous on the closed interval [ a  . . ]b
and:
:continuously differentiable on the open interval ( a  . . )b.


The arc length s of f between a and b is defined as: 

:s := âˆ«_a^b âˆš(1 + ( d y/d x)^2) d x

=== Definition 2 ===
The length of the arc of a curve is defined as the limit of the length of a polygonal line inscribed within the curve as the maximum length of the chords which form that polygonal line tends to zero.

title: Definition:Length of Sequence
definition:
The length of a finite sequence is the number of terms it contains, or equivalently, the cardinality of its domain.


=== Sequence of n Terms ===
A sequence of n terms is a (finite) sequence whose length is n.

title: Definition:Contour/Length/Complex Plane
definition:
Let C be a contour in â„‚ defined by the (finite) sequence âŸ¨ C_1, â€¦, C_n âŸ© of directed smooth curves in â„‚.

Let C_k be parameterized by the smooth path Î³_k: [ a_k  . . ]b_kâ†’â„‚ for all k âˆˆ{ 1, â€¦, n }.


The length of C is defined as:

:L (   )C := âˆ‘_k  = 1^n âˆ«_a_k^b_k|Î³_k' (   )t | d t


It follows from Length of Contour is Well-Defined that L (   )C is defined and independent of the parameterizations of C_1, â€¦, C_n.

title: Definition:Vector Length
definition:
The length of a vector ğ¯ in a normed vector space ( V, â€– Â· â€–) is defined as â€–ğ¯â€–, the norm of ğ¯.


=== Arrow Representation ===
Let ğ¯ be a vector quantity represented as an arrow in a real vector space â„^n.

The length of ğ¯ is the length of the line segment representing ğ¯ in â„^n.

title: Definition:Formal Language/Alphabet/Letter
definition:
A letter of a formal language is a more or less arbitrary symbol whose interpretation depends on the specific context.

In building a formal language, letters are considered to be the undefined terms of said language.


An important part of assigning semantics to a formal language is to provide an interpretation for its letters.


=== Vocabulary ===
The vocabulary of a formal language is the collection of all of its letters.

As such, it forms part of the alphabet of this language.


Each signature for the language may have a different vocabulary.

However, different signatures only have different members of the respective classes of symbols comprising the alphabet, rather than introducing new such classes.

title: Definition:Letter of Alphabet
definition:
A letter is one of the symbols of the alphabet of a natural language.

The letters of the English alphabet, for example, are:
:
:


Category:Definitions/Language Definitions

title: Definition:Like Vector Quantities
definition:
Let ğš and ğ› be vector quantities.

Then ğš and ğ› are known as like vector quantities  if and only if  they have the same direction.

title: Definition:Electric Charge/Polarity/Like
definition:
If 2 electric charges are of the same polarity, they are referred to as being like (electric) charges.


The usage is archaic; the word one would expect is alike.

title: Definition:Limit of Sequence
definition:
=== Topological Space ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

definition:

or:

 if and only if  the following equivalent conditions hold:


=== Ïµ-Î´ Condition ===

Let M_1 = ( A_1, d_1 ) and M_2 = ( A_2, d_2 ) be metric spaces.

or

 if and only if :

where:

title: Definition:Limit of Real Function
definition:

:N_Ïµ(   )L is the Ïµ-neighborhood of L in M_2.

title: Definition:Limit Superior
definition:
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a bounded sequence in â„.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a bounded sequence in â„.

title: Definition:Linear Algebra (Mathematical Branch)
definition: Linear algebra is the branch of algebra which studies vector spaces and linear transformations between them.

title: Definition:Algebra over Field
definition:
Let F be a field.


An algebra over F is an ordered pair ( A, * ) where:
:A is a vector space over F
:*: A^2 â†’ A is a bilinear mapping


That is, it is an algebra ( A, * ) over the ring F where:
:F is a field
:the F-module A is a vector space.


The symbol A is often used for such an algebra, more so as the level of abstraction increases.


=== Multiplication ===
Let F be a field.

Let ( A, * ) be an algebra over F such that:
:A is a vector space over F
:* : A^2 â†’ A is a bilinear mapping.


The bilinear mapping * is often referred to as multiplication.

title: Definition:Linear Form (Linear Algebra)
definition:
Let ( R, +, Ã—) be a commutative ring.

Let ( R, +_R, âˆ˜)_R denote the R-module R.

Let ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R be a module over R.


Let Ï•: ( G, +_G, âˆ˜)_R â†’( R, +_R, âˆ˜)_R be a linear transformation from G to the R-module R.


Ï• is called a linear form on G.

title: Definition:Linear Form (Polynomial Theory)
definition: A linear form is a form whose variables are of degree 1.

title: Definition:Loop (Plane Geometry)
definition:
A loop is a part of a plane curve that intersects itself.

Hence it encloses a bounded set of points.

title: Definition:Loop (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a loop-graph.

A loop is an edge e of G whose endvertices are the same vertex.


Thus a loop e on the vertex v would be written:
:e = vv

title: Definition:Algebra Loop
definition:
An algebra loop ( S, âˆ˜) is a quasigroup with an identity element.
:âˆƒ e âˆˆ S: âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ e = x = e âˆ˜ x

title: Definition:Relational Loop
definition:
Let â„› be a relation on a set S.

Let a_1, a_2, â€¦ a_n be elements of S.


A relational loop on S takes the form:

:( a_1 â„› a_2  a_2 â„› a_3 â€¦ a_n - 1â„› a_n  a_n â„› a_1 )

That is, it is a subset of â„› of the form:
:{( a_1, a_2 ), ( a_2, a_3 ), â€¦, ( a_n - 1, a_n ), ( a_n, a_1 )  }

title: Definition:Loop (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let Î³: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ S be a path in T.

Let Î³(   )0 = Î³(   )1.


Then Î³ is called a loop (in T).


=== Simple Loop ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let Î³: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ S be a path in T.


Î³ is a simple loop (in T)  if and only if :
:Î³(   )t_1Î³(   )t_2 for all t_1 ,t_2 âˆˆ[ 0  . . )1 with t_1  t_2
:Î³(   )0 = Î³(   )1

=== Base Point ===
Let X be a topological space.

Let Î³: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ X be a loop.


The base point of Î³ is Î³(   )0.

In other words, Î³ is said to be based at Î³(   )0.

=== Set of All Loops ===
Let T be a topological space.


The set of all loops based at p âˆˆ T is denoted by Î©(   )T, p.

=== Constant Loop ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let p âˆˆ T.

Let Î©(   )T, p denote the set of all loops based at p.


A constant loop c_p is the loop c_p âˆˆÎ©(   )T, p such that:

:âˆ€ t âˆˆ[ 0  . . ]1 : c_p (   )t = p

=== Null-Homotopic Loop ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let Î³ be a loop in T.

Suppose Î³ is path-homotopic to a constant loop.


Then Î³ is said to be null-homotopic.

=== Circle Representative of Loop ===
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let Î³: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ S be a loop in T.

Let S^1 âŠ†â„‚ be the unit circle in â„‚:

:S^1 = { z âˆˆâ„‚ : | z | = 1 }

Suppose Ï‰ : [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ S^1 such that Ï‰(   )s = exp(   )2 Ï€ i s.


Then the unique map fÌƒ :  S^1 â†’ T such that fÌƒâˆ˜Ï‰ = f is called the circle representative of f.

=== Loop in Topological Manifold ===
Let M be a topological manifold.

Let Ïƒ : [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ M be a continuous path.

Let Ïƒ(   )0 = Ïƒ(   )1.


Then Ïƒ is called a loop.

title: Definition:Loop (Matroid)
definition:
Let M = ( S, â„) be a matroid.


A loop of M is an element x of S such that { x } is a dependent subset of S.

That is, x âˆˆ S is a loop  if and only if  { x }âˆ‰â„.

title: Definition:Lower Bound of Set/Real Numbers
definition:
Let â„ be the set of real numbers.

Let T be a subset of S.


A lower bound for T (in â„) is an element m âˆˆâ„ such that:
:âˆ€ t âˆˆ T: m â‰¤ t

title: Definition:Lower Bound of Mapping/Real-Valued
definition:
Let f: S â†’â„ be a real-valued function.


Let f be bounded below in T by L âˆˆ T.


Then L is a lower bound of f.


=== Lower Bound of Number ===
When considering the lower bound of a set of numbers, it is commonplace to ignore the set and instead refer just to the number itself.

Thus the construction:

:The set of numbers which fulfil the propositional function P (n) is bounded below with the lower bound N

would be reported as:

:The number n such that P (n) has the lower bound N.


This construct obscures the details of what is actually being stated. Its use on   is considered an abuse of notation and so discouraged.


This also applies in the case where it is the lower bound of a mapping which is under discussion.


Category:Definitions/Numbers
