definition:
Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be a real sequence.


Let âŸ¨ x_n âŸ© be bounded below in T by L âˆˆâ„.


Then L is a lower bound of âŸ¨ x_n âŸ©.


=== Lower Bound of Number ===
When considering the lower bound of a set of numbers, it is commonplace to ignore the set and instead refer just to the number itself.

Thus the construction:

:The set of numbers which fulfil the propositional function P (n) is bounded below with the lower bound N

would be reported as:

:The number n such that P (n) has the lower bound N.


This construct obscures the details of what is actually being stated. Its use on   is considered an abuse of notation and so discouraged.


This also applies in the case where it is the lower bound of a mapping which is under discussion.


Category:Definitions/Numbers

title: Definition:Machine (Mechanics)
definition: A machine, in the context of mechanics, is a physical artefact which takes energy in a particular form and converts it into energy in another form for a specific purpose.

title: Definition:Finite State Machine
definition:
A finite state machine is an ordered tuple:

: F = ( S, A, I, x3a3, T )

where:

: S is the (finite) set of states
: A âŠ† S is the set of accepting states
: I âˆˆ S is the initial state
: x3a3 is the alphabet of symbols that can be fed into the machine
: T : ( S Ã—x3a3) â†’ S is the transition function.


A finite state machine operates as follows:

:(1): At the beginning, the current state s of the finite state machine is I.
:(2): One by one, the input (a sequence of symbols from x3a3) is fed into the machine.
:(3): After each input symbol Ïƒ, the current state s is set to the result of T(s, Ïƒ).


If, at the end of processing an input word w, s âˆˆ A, the finite state machine is said to accept w, otherwise to reject it.


The set of words w accepted by the machine F is called the accepted language L(F).

Category:Definitions/Abstract Machines

title: Definition:Unlimited Register Machine
definition:
An unlimited register machine, abbreviated URM, is an abstract machine with the following characteristics:


=== Registers ===
A URM has a sequence of registers which can store natural numbers: { 0, 1, 2, â€¦}.

Any given URM program may make use of only a finite number of these registers.


Registers are usually referred to by the subscripted uppercase letters R_1, R_2, R_3, â€¦.

The number held at any one time by a register is usually referred to by the corresponding lowercase letter r_1, r_2, r_3, â€¦.


The registers are unlimited in the following two senses:
:(1): Although a URM program may make use of only a finite number of registers, there is no actual upper bound on how many a particular URM program can actually use.
:(2): There is no upper bound on the size of the natural numbers that may be stored in any register.


=== Index of Register ===
The subscript (which is a natural number) appended to a URM register is called the index of that register.

Hence, for example, the index of register R_5 is 5.

=== Program ===
The numbers held in the registers of a URM are manipulated according to a program.

A URM program is a finite sequence of basic instructions.


=== Basic Instruction ===
The basic instructions of a URM program form a finite sequence and hence can be considered a set indexed by the (positive) integer 1, 2, 3, â€¦.


The basic instructions are as follows:


Name     	Notation          	Effect                     	Description
Zero     	Z (   )n        	0 â†’ R_n                	Replace the number in R_n by 0.
Successor	S (   )n        	r_n + 1 â†’ R_n          	Add 1 to the number in R_n.
Copy     	C (   )m, n   	r_m â†’ R_n              	Replace the number in R_n by the number in R_m (leaving the one in R_m as it was).
Jump     	J (   )m, n, q	r_m = r_n ? â‡’ q	If the numbers in R_m and R_n are equal, go to instruction number q, otherwise go to the next instruction.



=== Execution ===
The operation of carrying out a basic URM instruction is referred to as execution.

=== Execution ===
The operation of carrying out a basic URM instruction is referred to as execution.

=== Line Number ===
For historical reasons, the index of an instruction in a given URM program is called its line number.

We can refer either to the line of the program or the line in the URM.

=== Set of All URM Programs ===
It is convenient to use U to stand for the set of all URM programs.

=== Length of Program ===
Let U denote the set of all URM programs.

Let P âˆˆ U be a URM program.

By definition, P is a finite sequence of basic instructions.


We define the function Î»:  U â†’â„• as follows:
:âˆ€ P âˆˆ U: Î»(   )P = the number of basic instructions that comprise P

Thus Î»(   )P is referred to as the length of P.

=== Highest Register ===
Let U denote the set of all URM programs.

Let P âˆˆ U be a URM program.

By definition, P uses a finite number of registers.


We define the function Ï:  U â†’â„• as follows:
:âˆ€ P âˆˆ U: Ï(   )P = the highest register number used by P

That is, in any URM program P, no instruction refers to any register with index greater than Ï(   )P.

=== Highest Register ===
Let U denote the set of all URM programs.

Let P âˆˆ U be a URM program.

By definition, P uses a finite number of registers.


We define the function Ï:  U â†’â„• as follows:
:âˆ€ P âˆˆ U: Ï(   )P = the highest register number used by P

That is, in any URM program P, no instruction refers to any register with index greater than Ï(   )P.

=== Termination ===
A URM program terminates when there are no more instructions to execute.

This can happen in either of two ways:
:(1): If the program executes the last instruction, and this does not involve a Jump to an earlier instruction, the program will stop.
:(2): If the program executes a Jump instruction to a non-existent instruction, the program will stop.


=== Exit Jump ===
 

Such a Jump instruction is known as an exit jump .

=== Exit Line ===
 

The line on which a particular run of a URM program stops is called the exit line.


=== Endless Loop ===
 

If a URM program, when running, never reaches a state where it terminates, then it is said to be in an endless loop and will never terminate.

 

Note that whether a program terminates or not may depend on its input.

It may terminate perfectly well for one input, but go into an endless loop on another.

=== Input ===

The input to a URM program is:
:either an ordered k-tuple ( n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k ) âˆˆâ„•^k
:or a natural number n âˆˆâ„•.


In the latter case, it is convenient to consider a single natural number as an ordered 1-tuple ( n_1 ) âˆˆâ„•^1 = â„•.

Hence we can discuss inputs to URM programs solely as instances of tuples, and not be concerned with cumbersome repetition for the cases where k = 1 and otherwise.


The convention usually used is for a URM program P to start computation with:
:the input (n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k) in registers R_1, R_2, â€¦, R_k
:0 in all other registers used by P.


That is, the initial state of the URM is:
:âˆ€ i âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]k: r_i = n_i
:âˆ€ i > k: r_i = 0.


It is usual for the input (either all or part) to be overwritten during the course of the operation of a program. That is, at the end of a program, R_1, R_2, â€¦, R_k are not guaranteed still to contain n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k unless the program has been explicitly written so as to ensure that this is the case.


=== Output ===

At the end of the running of a URM program, the output will be found in register R_1.

=== Operation ===
When a URM runs a program, it always starts by executing the first instruction of the program.

When it has executed an instruction, it moves to the next instruction and executes that one, unless required otherwise by a Jump instruction.


=== Execution ===
The operation of carrying out a basic URM instruction is referred to as execution.

=== Instruction Pointer ===
The line number of the instruction which is currently about to be executed is known as the instruction pointer.

It can be imagined as a special-purpose register in the URM whose purpose is to hold that line number.

=== Stage of Computation ===
The stage of computation (or just stage) of a URM program is the count of how many instructions have been executed.

Thus each stage corresponds to the processing of one instruction.

=== State ===
The state of a URM program at a particular stage is defined as:
:(1): the value of the instruction pointer
:(2): the values contained by each of the registers that are used by the URM program.

=== Instruction Pointer ===
The line number of the instruction which is currently about to be executed is known as the instruction pointer.

It can be imagined as a special-purpose register in the URM whose purpose is to hold that line number.

=== Stage of Computation ===
The stage of computation (or just stage) of a URM program is the count of how many instructions have been executed.

Thus each stage corresponds to the processing of one instruction.

=== State ===
The state of a URM program at a particular stage is defined as:
:(1): the value of the instruction pointer
:(2): the values contained by each of the registers that are used by the URM program.

=== Input ===

The input to a URM program is:
:either an ordered k-tuple ( n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k ) âˆˆâ„•^k
:or a natural number n âˆˆâ„•.


In the latter case, it is convenient to consider a single natural number as an ordered 1-tuple ( n_1 ) âˆˆâ„•^1 = â„•.

Hence we can discuss inputs to URM programs solely as instances of tuples, and not be concerned with cumbersome repetition for the cases where k = 1 and otherwise.


The convention usually used is for a URM program P to start computation with:
:the input (n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k) in registers R_1, R_2, â€¦, R_k
:0 in all other registers used by P.


That is, the initial state of the URM is:
:âˆ€ i âˆˆ[ 1  . . ]k: r_i = n_i
:âˆ€ i > k: r_i = 0.


It is usual for the input (either all or part) to be overwritten during the course of the operation of a program. That is, at the end of a program, R_1, R_2, â€¦, R_k are not guaranteed still to contain n_1, n_2, â€¦, n_k unless the program has been explicitly written so as to ensure that this is the case.


=== Output ===

At the end of the running of a URM program, the output will be found in register R_1.


=== Null Program ===
The null URM program is a URM program which contains no instructions.

That is, a URM program whose length is zero.

title: Definition:Turing Machine
definition:
A Turing machine is an abstract machine which works by manipulating symbols on an imaginary piece of paper by means of a specific set of algorithmic rules.

To simplify things, the piece of paper being worked on is in the form of a series of boxes on a one-dimensional "tape" divided into squares.

Each square can be either blank or can contain a symbol taken from a finite set, e.g. s_1, s_2, â€¦, s_Î±.


The machine examines one square at a time, and carries out an action determined by both:
:(1): the symbol in the square
:(2): the current internal state of the machine.

The internal state of the machine is a way of providing a device that can keep track of the symbols in other squares.

There can be only a finite set of these states, say q_1, q_2, â€¦, q_Î².


The actions that the machine can take are as follows:
:(1): Replace the symbol in the square with another symbol
:(2): Move to examine the square in the immediate left of the current square being looked at
:(3): Move to examine the square in the immediate right of the current square being looked at.

After carrying out an action, the machine may change to a different internal state.


The program for the machine is a set of instructions which specify:
:(1): what action to take in some possible combinations of the internal state and symbol in the square currently being read
:(2): which internal state the machine moves into after carrying out that action.

Thus the instructions have the following form:
:q_i    s_j    A    q_t
which is interpreted as:

"If:
:* the machine is in internal state q_i
: the symbol in the square currently being examined is s_j
then:
: Carry out action A
: Move into internal state q_t.


The actions can be abbreviated to:
: L: Move one square to the left
: R: Move one square to the right
: s_k: Replace the symbol in the square currently being read with symbol s_k.


The computation stops when there is no instruction which specifies what should be done in the current combination of internal state and symbol being read.


=== Formal Definition ===

 

A Turing machine is a 7-tuple ( Q, x3a3, Î“, Î´, q_0, B, F ) that satisfies the following:
* Q is a finite set, the states of the Turing machine.
* x3a3 is a finite set, the input symbols.
* Î“âŠ‹x3a3 is a finite superset of the input symbols, called the tape symbols.
** For convenience, we also require that Î“ and Q are disjoint.
* Î´ : Q Ã—Î“â†’ Q Ã—Î“Ã—{ L, R } is a partial mapping, the transition function.
** L and R are arbitrary constants called directions.
* q_0 âˆˆ Q is a distinguished state called the start state.
* B âˆˆÎ“ is a distinguished tape symbol called the blank symbol. B must not be an element of x3a3.
* F âŠ‚ Q be a designated subset of the states called accepting states.


An instantaneous description of a Turing machine is a finite sequence of elements of Î“âˆª Q, subject to the following conditions:
* There is exactly one element of Q in the sequence.
* The first entry in the sequence is not B.
* The last entry in the sequence is not in Q.
* If the last entry in the sequence is B, then the second-to-last is in Q.

By this definition, an instantaneous description can always be written as:
:X_m X_m-1â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n-1 Z_n
where m or n may be 0; X_i, Y, and Z_j are all elements of Î“; and q is an element of Q.

Additionally, X_m and Z_n are not B if they exist; that is, if m and n are not 0, respectively.


A move reduces one instantaneous description into another by applying the transition function.

We write A âŠ¢ B if a machine with instantaneous description A has, after a single move, instantaneous description B.

Let Î´(   )q, Y = ( q', Y', d ).

Then there are seven cases to consider:

* If d = L and m > 0, and either n > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y Z_1 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_2 q' X_1 Y' Z_1 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = L and m > 0, but n = 0 and Y' = B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_2 q' X_1

* If d = L but m = 0, and either n > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:q Y Z_1 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ q' B Y' Z_1 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R and n > 0, and either m > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_1 q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_1 Y' q' Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R and n > 0, but m = 0 and Y' = B then:
:q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ q' Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R but n = 0, and either m > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_1 q Y âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_1 Y' q' B

* If m = 0, n = 0, and Y' = B then regardless of d:
:q Y âŠ¢ q' B


Let A âŠ¢^* B indicate that there exists a finite sequence âŸ¨ A_i âŸ©_0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n such that:
:A = A_0 âŠ¢ A_1 âŠ¢ A_2 âŠ¢â€¦âŠ¢ A_n = B


The language L (   )M accepted by the machine M is the set of strings w âˆˆx3a3^* for which, for some Î±, Î²âˆˆÎ“^* and p âˆˆ F:
:q_0 w âŠ¢^* Î± p Î²

As a special case, the null string is in the language  if and only if  the above holds for w = B.


A machine M halts on an input w, using the same special case for the null string as above,  if and only if  for some Î±, Î²âˆˆÎ“^*, X âˆˆÎ“, and q âˆˆ Q:
:q_0 w âŠ¢^* Î± q X Î²
where Î´(   )q, X is undefined.

title: Definition:Nondeterministic Turing Machine
definition:
A nondeterministic Turing machine (NTM) is a variation of the classical Turing machine that relaxes the restriction that all the steps in the machine must be definite.

That is, given a single internal state and a single character being read on the tape the machine may have more than one possible response.

If any sequence of choices puts the machine into a halting state, then the machine stops after n steps, where n is the minimum number of steps needed to put the machine into a halting state.

 

=== Formal Definition ===

A nondeterministic Turing machine is a 7-tuple ( Q, x3a3, Î“, Î´, q_0, B, F ) that satisfies the following:
* Q is a finite set, the states of the machine.
* x3a3 is a finite set, the input symbols.
* Î“âŠ‹x3a3 is a finite superset of the input symbols, called the tape symbols.
** For convenience, we also require that Î“ and Q are disjoint.
* Î´ : Q Ã—Î“â†’ğ’«( Q Ã—Î“Ã—{ L, R }) is a mapping, the transition function.
** L and R are arbitrary constants called directions.
* q_0 âˆˆ Q is a distinguished state called the start state.
* B âˆˆÎ“ is a distinguished tape symbol called the blank symbol. B must not be an element of x3a3.
* F âŠ‚ Q be a designated subset of the states called accepting states.


An instantaneous description of a nondeterministic Turing machine is a finite sequence of elements of Î“âˆª Q, subject to the following conditions:
* There is exactly one element of Q in the sequence.
* The first entry in the sequence is not B.
* The last entry in the sequence is not in Q.
* If the last entry in the sequence is B, then the second-to-last is in Q.

By this definition, an instantaneous description can always be written as:
:X_m X_m-1â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n-1 Z_n
where m or n may be 0; X_i, Y, and Z_j are all elements of Î“; and q is an element of Q.

Additionally, X_m and Z_n are not B if they exist; that is, if m and n are not 0, respectively.


A move reduces one instantaneous description into another by applying the transition function. There may be many possible moves from any given instantaneous description.

We write A âŠ¢ B if a machine with instantaneous description A may have, after a single move, instantaneous description B.

Let ( q', Y', d ) âˆˆÎ´(   )q, Y.

Then there are seven cases to consider:

* If d = L and m > 0, and either n > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y Z_1 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_2 q' X_1 Y' Z_1 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = L and m > 0, but n = 0 and Y' = B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_2 X_1 q Y âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_2 q' X_1

* If d = L but m = 0, and either n > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:q Y Z_1 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ q' B Y' Z_1 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R and n > 0, and either m > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_1 q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_1 Y' q' Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R and n > 0, but m = 0 and Y' = B then:
:q Y Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n âŠ¢ q' Z_1 Z_2 â€¦ Z_n

* If d = R but n = 0, and either m > 0 or Y' â‰  B then:
:X_m â€¦ X_1 q Y âŠ¢ X_m â€¦ X_1 Y' q' B

* If m = 0, n = 0, and Y' = B then regardless of d:
:q Y âŠ¢ q' B


Let A âŠ¢^* B indicate that there exists a finite sequence âŸ¨ A_i âŸ©_0 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n such that:
:A = A_0 âŠ¢ A_1 âŠ¢ A_2 âŠ¢â€¦âŠ¢ A_n = B


The language L (   )M accepted by the machine M is the set of strings w âˆˆx3a3^* for which, for some Î±, Î²âˆˆÎ“^* and p âˆˆ F:
:q_0 w âŠ¢^* Î± p Î²

As a special case, the null string is in the language  if and only if  the above holds for w = B.

title: Definition:Topological Manifold/Differentiable Manifold
definition:
Let M be a second-countable locally Euclidean space of dimension d. 

Let â„± be a d-dimensional differentiable structure on M of class ğ’^k, where k â‰¥ 1.


Then ( M, â„±) is a differentiable manifold of class ğ’^k and dimension d.

definition:
Let M be a second-countable locally Euclidean space of dimension d. 

Let â„± be a smooth differentiable structure on M.

definition:
Let M be a second-countable, complex locally Euclidean space of dimension d.

title: Definition:Vector Subspace/Hilbert Spaces
definition:
Let K be a division ring.

Let (S, +, âˆ˜)_K be a K-algebraic structure with one operation.


Let T be a closed subset of S.

Let (T, +_T, âˆ˜_T)_K be a K-vector space where:
: +_T is the restriction of + to T Ã— T and
: âˆ˜_T is the restriction of âˆ˜ to K Ã— T.


Then (T, +_T, âˆ˜_T)_K is a (vector) subspace of (S, +, âˆ˜)_K.


When considering Hilbert spaces, one wants to deal with projections onto subspaces.

These projections however require the linear subspace to be closed in topological sense in order to be well-defined.

Therefore, in treatises of Hilbert spaces, one encounters the terminology linear manifold for the concept of vector subspace defined above.

The adapted definition of linear subspace is then that it is a topologically closed linear manifold.

title: Definition:Arithmetic Mean
definition:
Let x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n âˆˆâ„ be real numbers.

The arithmetic mean of x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n is defined as:

:A_n :=  1 n âˆ‘_k  = 1^n x_k

title: Definition:Geometric Mean
definition:
Let x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n âˆˆâ„_>0 be (strictly) positive real numbers.

The geometric mean of x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n is defined as:

That is, to find out the geometric mean of a set of n numbers, multiply them together and take the nth root.


=== Mean Proportional ===
In the language of  , the geometric mean of two magnitudes is called the mean proportional.

Thus the mean proportional of a and b is defined as that magnitude c such that:
:a : c = c : b
where a : c denotes the ratio between a and c.


From the definition of ratio it is seen that a c =  c b from which it follows that c = âˆš(a b) demonstrating that the definitions are logically equivalent.


=== General Definition ===
In the language of  , the terms of a (finite) geometric sequence of positive integers between (and not including) the first and last terms are called mean proportionals.

:1 H_n := 1/n( âˆ‘_k  = 1^n 1/x_k)

title: Definition:Weighted Mean
definition:
Let S = âŸ¨ x_1, x_2, â€¦, x_n âŸ© be a sequence of real numbers.

Let W be a weight function to be applied to the terms of S.


The weighted mean of S   W is defined as:
:xÌ… := âˆ‘_i  = 1^n W (   )x_i x_iâˆ‘_i  = 1^n W (   )x_i

This means that elements of S with a larger weight contribute more to the weighted mean than those with a smaller weight.


If we write:

From the definition of the weight function, none of the weights can be negative.

=== Normalized Weighted Mean ===

as by definition of normalized weight function all the weights add up to 1.

This weighted mean is known as a  normalized weighted mean.

definition: Measure theory is the subfield of analysis concerned with the properties of measures, particularly the Lebesgue measure.

title: Definition:Lebesgue Measure
definition:
Let ğ’¥_ho^n be the set of half-open n-rectangles.

Let â„¬(   )â„^n be the Borel Ïƒ-algebra on â„^n.


Let Î»^n be the n-dimensional Lebesgue pre-measure on ğ’¥_ho^n.

A measure Î¼ extending Î»^n to â„¬(   )â„^n is called n-dimensional Lebesgue measure.

That is, Î¼ is an n-dimensional Lebesgue measure  if and only if  it satisfies:

:Î¼_ğ’¥_ho^n = Î»^n

where  denotes restriction.


Usually, this measure is also denoted by Î»^n, even though this may be considered abuse of notation.


=== Lebesgue Measure on the Reals ===

where:

Then Î¼^* is known as the Lebesgue outer measure and can be shown to be an outer measure.

title: Definition:Measure (Geometry)
definition:
A geometric quantity A is said to measure another quantity B when the size of A is a divisor of the size of B.

Category:Definitions/Geometry

title: Definition:Measurable Property/Measurement
definition:
Measurement is the process of determining the quantity of a measurable property according to some given scale of measurement.

A measurement is reported as a (real) number multiplied by a unit of measurement for that quantity.

title: Definition:Metrizable Topology
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

title: Definition:Categorical Syllogism/Premises/Minor Premise
definition:
The minor premise of a categorical syllogism is conventionally stated second.

It is a categorical statement which expresses the logical relationship between the secondary term and the middle term of the syllogism.

title: Definition:Minor of Determinant
definition:

definition:

The (complex) modulus is a real-valued function, and, as and when appropriate, can be referred to as the (complex) modulus function.

title: Definition:Modulus (Geometric Function Theory)
definition:
In geometric function theory, the term modulus is used to denote certain conformal invariants of configurations or curve families.

More precisely, the modulus of a curve family Î“ is the reciprocal of its extremal length:
:Î“ :=  1 Î»(   )Î“


=== Modulus of a Quadrilateral ===

Consider a quadrilateral; that is, a Jordan domain Q in the complex plane (or some other Riemann surface), together with two disjoint closed boundary arcs Î± and Î±'.

Then the modulus of the quadrilateral Q (   )Î±, Î±' is the extremal length of the family of curves in Q that connect Î± and Î±'.

Equivalently, there exists a rectangle R = { x + i y: | x | < a, | y | < b } and a conformal isomorphism between Q and R under which Î± and Î±' correspond to the vertical sides of R.

Then the modulus of Q (   )Î±, Î±' is equal to the ratio a/b.


See Modulus of a Quadrilateral.


=== Modulus of an Annulus ===

Consider an annulus A; that is, a domain whose boundary consists of two Jordan curves.

Then the modulus A is the extremal length of the family of curves in A that connect the two boundary components of A.

Equivalently, there is a round annulus Ãƒ = { z âˆˆâ„‚: r < | z | < R } that is conformally equivalent to A.

Then:
:A :=  1 2 Ï€ln(   ) R r

The modulus of A can also be denoted M (   )R.

title: Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)/Modulus
definition:
Let x be congruent to y modulo m.

The number m in this congruence is known as the modulus of the congruence.

title: Definition:Young's Modulus
definition:
Young's modulus is a modulus of elasticity used when an elastic body B is under tension or compression.

It is defined as the ratio of applied pressure to the resulting increase or decrease in length per unit length of B.

That is, it is the ratio of tensile or compressive stress to the associated strain.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Bulk Modulus
definition:
Let B be an elastic body.

The bulk modulus of B is a physical property of B which measures its resistance to change in volume without change of shape.

It is defined as the ratio of compressive stress per surface area of B to its change of volume per unit volume associated with this stress, assuming uniform pressure over the surface of B.

title: Definition:Rigidity Modulus
definition:
The rigidity modulus of a body or a substance is an elastic modulus used in relation to shear.

It is the ratio of shear stress to the resulting shear strain of the body.

title: Definition:Completely Multiplicative Function
definition:
Let K be a field.

Let f: K â†’ K be a function on K.


Then f is described as completely multiplicative  if and only if :

:âˆ€ m, n âˆˆ K: f (   )m n = f (   )m f (   )n


That is, a completely multiplicative function is one where the value of a product of two numbers equals the product of the value of each one individually.

title: Definition:Multiplicative Function on Ring
definition:
Let ( R, +, âˆ˜) be a ring.

Let f: R â†’â„ be a (real-valued) function on R.


f is a multiplicative function on R  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ R: f (   )x âˆ˜ y = f (   )x Ã— f (   )y


That is, a multiplicative function on R is one where the value of the product of two elements of R equals the product of their values.

title: Definition:Multiplicative Function on UFD
definition:
Let R be a unique factorization domain.

Let f : R â†’â„‚ be a complex-valued function.


Then f is multiplicative  if and only if :
:For all coprime x, yâˆˆ R: f (x y) = f (x) f (y)


=== Arithmetic Function ===
Let f : â„•â†’â„‚ be an arithmetic function.


Then f is multiplicative  if and only if :
:m âŠ¥ n  f (   )m n = f (   )m f (   )n
where m âŠ¥ n denotes that m is coprime to n.


That is, a multiplicative arithmetic function is one where the value of a product of two coprime numbers equals the product of the value of each one individually.

title: Definition:Multiple Root/Multiplicity
definition: The multiplicity of a multiple root is the number of times it appears.

title: Definition:Multiplicity (Complex Analysis)
definition:
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a function.

Suppose there is a âˆˆâ„‚ such that f (   )a = 0.

Then a is said to be a zero of multiplicity k  if and only if  there exists non-zero L âˆˆâ„ such that:

:lim_z â†’ a| f (   )z || z - a |^k = L

 

Category:Definitions/Complex Analysis

title: Definition:Multiple Edge/Multiplicity
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a multigraph.

The multiplicity of an edge is the number of edges having the same pair of endvertices.


For example, simple edges have multiplicity 1.

Thus, an edge is a multiple edge  if and only if  its multiplicity exceeds 1.

Category:Definitions/Multigraphs

title: Definition:Multigraph/Multiplicity
definition:
The multiplicity of a multigraph is the maximum multiplicity of its (multiple) edges.


Category:Definitions/Multigraphs

title: Definition:Prime Decomposition/Multiplicity
definition:
Let n > 1 âˆˆâ„¤.

Let:
:n = p_1^k_1 p_2^k_2â‹¯ p_r^k_r
be the prime decomposition of n, where:
:p_1 < p_2 < â‹¯ < p_r are distinct primes
:k_1, k_2, â€¦, k_r are (strictly) positive integers.


For each p_j âˆˆ{ p_1, p_2, â€¦, p_r }, its power k_j is known as the multiplicity of p_j.

title: Definition:Proper Name
definition:
A proper name is a symbol or collection of symbols used to identify a particular object uniquely.


In contrast with natural language, a proper name has a wider range than being the particular identifying label attached to a particular single entity (be it a person, or a place, or whatever else).

For example:
:Sloth is a proper name for the concept of being lazy.
:Rain is a proper name for the meteorological phenomenon of water falling from the sky.

title: Definition:Variable/Predicate Logic
definition:
In the context of predicate logic, a variable is often called an object variable or arbitrary name.

As such, it is a symbol which is assigned to an arbitrarily selected object from a given universe of discourse.


The understanding is that (during the scope of the argument to which it is relevant) the arbitrary name could apply equally well to any of the objects in that universe.

title: Definition:Logical Not
definition:
The logical not or (logical) negation operator is a unary connective whose action is to reverse the truth value of the statement on which it operates.

:p is defined as:
:p is not true
:It is not the case that p is true
:It is false that p
:p is false.


Thus the statement p is called the negation of p.


p is voiced not p.


=== Truth Function ===
The logical not connective defines the truth function f^ as follows:

 
 
 
 

=== Truth Table ===
The characteristic truth table of the negation operator p is as follows:

:[ p p; F T; T F;   ]

=== Boolean Interpretation ===
Let ğ€ be a propositional formula.

Let  denote the negation operator.


The truth value of ğ€ under a boolean interpretation v is given by:

:v (   )ğ€ = T    : v (   )ğ€ = F
F    : v (   )ğ€ = T

title: Definition:Negation Function
definition:
The negation function is the function defined on the various standard number systems as follows:


=== Integer Negation Function ===
The negation function h: â„¤â†’â„¤ is defined on the set of integers as:
:âˆ€ n âˆˆâ„¤: h (   )n = -n


Category:Definitions/Negation Functions
Category:Definitions/Integers

=== Rational Negation Function ===
The negation function h: â„šâ†’â„š is defined on the set of rational numbers as:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆâ„š: h (   )x = -x


Category:Definitions/Negation Functions
Category:Definitions/Rational Numbers

=== Real Negation Function ===
The negation function h: â„â†’â„ is defined on the set of real numbers as:
:âˆ€ x âˆˆâ„: h (   )x = -x


Category:Definitions/Negation Functions
Category:Definitions/Real Numbers

=== Complex Negation Function ===
The negation function h: â„â†’â„ is defined on the set of complex numbers as:
:âˆ€ z = x + i y âˆˆâ„‚: h (   )z = -x - i y


Category:Definitions/Negation Functions
Category:Definitions/Complex Numbers

Category:Definitions/Numbers
Category:Definitions/Negation Functions

title: Definition:Electric Charge/Neutral
definition: A body which has no electric charge on it is described as (electrically) neutral.

title: Definition:Equilibrium (Mechanics)/Neutral
definition:
Let B be a particle, a system of particles, or a body which is in equilibrium.

Let B be such that if a small displacement is applied, B remains in its new position.


B is then said to be in neutral equilibrium.

title: Definition:Identity (Abstract Algebra)/Two-Sided Identity
definition:
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be an algebraic structure.

An element e âˆˆ S is called an identity (element)  if and only if  it is both a left identity and a right identity:

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ S: x âˆ˜ e = x = e âˆ˜ x


In Identity is Unique it is established that an identity element, if it exists, is unique within ( S, âˆ˜).

Thus it is justified to refer to it as the identity (of a given algebraic structure).


This identity is often denoted e_S, or e if it is clearly understood what structure is being discussed.

title: Definition:Node (Graph Theory)
definition:
=== Vertex ===

For graphs which are not trees, the term vertex is generally used instead:

 

Let G = ( V, E ) be a graph.

The vertices (singular: vertex) are the elements of V.

Informally, the vertices are the points that are connected by the edges.


In the above, the vertices are the points A, B, C, D, E, F, G which are marked as dots.

=== Node ===
The vertices of a tree are called its nodes.

title: Definition:Acnode
definition: An acnode is a singular point of the locus of an equation describing a curve which is not actually on that curve.

title: Definition:Crunode
definition: A crunode is a double point P of the locus of an equation describing a curve which intersects itself in such a way that there are 2 distinct tangents at P.

title: Definition:Cusp
definition:
A cusp is a singular point on a curve at which there are two different tangents which coincide.

Thus a cusp is a special case of a double point in which the tangents are coincident.


=== Cusp of the First Kind ===
A cusp of the first kind is a cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on opposite sides of the coincident tangents defining that cusp.


=== Single Cusp of the First Kind ===
A single cusp of the first kind is a single cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on opposite sides of the coincident tangents defining that single cusp.
:

=== Double Cusp of the First Kind ===
A double cusp of the first kind is a double cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on opposite sides of the coincident tangents defining that double cusp.
:

=== Cusp of the Second Kind ===
A cusp of the second kind is a cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on the same side of the coincident tangents defining that cusp.


=== Single Cusp of the Second Kind ===
A single cusp of the second kind is a single cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on the same side of the coincident tangents defining that single cusp.
:

=== Double Cusp of the Second Kind ===
A double cusp of the second kind is a double cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on the same side of the coincident tangents defining that double cusp.
:

title: Definition:Double Cusp
definition:
A double cusp is a cusp in which 2 or more parts of the curve are both continuous through the point.

That is, the curve is tangential to itself.


=== Double Cusp of the First Kind ===
A double cusp of the first kind is a double cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on opposite sides of the coincident tangents defining that double cusp.
:

=== Double Cusp of the Second Kind ===
A double cusp of the second kind is a double cusp in which both parts of the curve lie on the same side of the coincident tangents defining that double cusp.
:

=== Point of Osculinflection ===
A point of osculinflection is a double cusp in which one or both parts of the curve has a point of inflection at the point of contact with the tangents defining that double cusp.
:

title: Definition:Metagraph
definition:
A metagraph ğ’¢ consists of:

* objects X, Y, Z, â€¦
* morphisms f, g, h, â€¦ between its objects

These are subjected to the following two axioms:

 
 
 
 

 
A metagraph is purely axiomatic, and does not use set theory.

For example, the objects are not "elements of the set of objects", because these axioms are (without further interpretation) unfounded in set theory.

title: Definition:Spline Function/Knot
definition:
Let [ a  . . ]b be a closed real interval.

Let T := { a = t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n = b } form a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b.

Let S: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„ be a spline function on [ a  . . ]b on T.


The points T := { t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n } of S are known as the knots.


=== Knot Vector ===
Let [ a  . . ]b be a closed real interval.

Let T := { a = t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n = b } form a subdivision of [ a  . . ]b.

Let S: [ a  . . ]b â†’â„ be a spline function on [ a  . . ]b on T.


The ordered n + 1-tuple ğ­ := ( t_0, t_1, t_2, â€¦, t_n - 1, t_n ) of S is known as the knot vector.


Category:Definitions/Knots of Splines

title: Definition:Noetherian Module
definition:
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


M is a Noetherian module  if and only if  every submodule of M is finitely generated.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


M is a Noetherian module  if and only if  it satisfies the ascending chain condition on submodules.

=== Definition 3 ===
Let A be a commutative ring with unity.

Let M be an A-module.


M is a Noetherian module  if and only if  it satisfies the maximal condition on submodules.

title: Definition:Noetherian Ring
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A commutative ring with unity A is Noetherian  if and only if  every ideal of A is finitely generated.

=== Definition 2 ===
A commutative ring with unity A is Noetherian  if and only if  it satisfies the ascending chain condition on ideals.

=== Definition 3 ===
A commutative ring with unity A is Noetherian  if and only if  it satisfies the maximal condition on ideals.

=== Definition 4 ===
A commutative ring with unity A is Noetherian  if and only if  it is Noetherian as an A-module.

title: Definition:Noetherian Topological Space
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is Noetherian  if and only if  its set of closed sets, ordered by the subset relation, satisfies the descending chain condition.

=== Definition 2 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is Noetherian  if and only if  its set of open sets, ordered by the subset relation, satisfies the ascending chain condition.

=== Definition 3 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is Noetherian  if and only if  each non-empty set of closed sets has a minimal element with respect to the subset relation.

=== Definition 4 ===
A topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is Noetherian  if and only if  each non-empty set of open sets has a maximal element   the subset relation.

title: Definition:Noetherian Scheme
definition:
Let ( X, ğ’ª_X ) be a scheme.


Then ( X, ğ’ª_X ) is Noetherian  if and only if  ( X, ğ’ª_X ) is locally Noetherian and quasi-compact.

title: Definition:Normal Family
definition:
Let X = ( M_1, d_1 ) and Y = ( M_2, d_2 ) be complete metric spaces.

Let â„± = âŸ¨ f_i âŸ©_i âˆˆ I be a family of continuous mappings f_i: X â†’ Y.


Then â„± is a normal family  if and only if :
:every sequence of mappings in â„± contains a subsequence which converges uniformly on compact subsets of X to a continuous function f: X â†’ Y.

title: Definition:Normal Operator
definition:
Let â„‹ be a Hilbert space.

Let ğ“: â„‹â†’â„‹ be a bounded linear operator.


Then ğ“ is said to be normal  if and only if :

:ğ“^* ğ“ = ğ“ğ“^*

where ğ“^* denotes the adjoint of ğ“.

title: Definition:Normal to Curve
definition:
Let C be a curve embedded in the plane.

The normal to C at a point P is defined as the straight line which lies perpendicular to the tangent to C at P and in the same plane as P.

title: Definition:Normal to Surface
definition:
Let S be a surface embedded in 3-dimensional space.

The normal to S at a point P is defined as the straight line which lies perpendicular to the tangent plane to S at P.

title: Definition:Normal Section
definition:
Let F be a 2-dimensional figure.

A normal section of F   one of the surfaces S of F is a plane section of F which is perpendicular to S.

title: Definition:Normal Vector
definition:
Let S be a surface in ordinary 3-space.

Let P be a point of S.


Let ğ§ be a vector whose initial point is at P such that ğ§ is perpendicular to S at P.


Then ğ§ is a normal vector to S at P.

title: Definition:Injection
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A mapping f is an injection, or injective  if and only if :
:âˆ€ x_1, x_2 âˆˆDom( f ): f (   )x_1 = f (   )x_2 x_1 = x_2


That is, an injection is a mapping such that the output uniquely determines its input.


=== Definition 1 a ===

This can otherwise be put:
A mapping f is an injection, or injective  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x_1, x_2 âˆˆDom( f ): x_1  x_2  f (   )x_1 f (   )x_2


That is, distinct elements of the domain are mapped to distinct elements of the image.

=== Definition 2 ===
An injection is a relation which is both one-to-one and left-total.


Thus, a relation f is an injection  if and only if :

 
 
 
 
 

=== Definition 3 ===
Let f be a mapping.

Then f is an injection  if and only if :
:f^-1_Img( f ): Img( f ) â†’Dom( f ) is a mapping
where f^-1_Img( f ) is the restriction of the inverse of f to the image set of f.

=== Definition 4 ===
Let f be a mapping.

f is an injection  if and only if :
:âˆ€ y âˆˆImg( f ): | f^-1(   )y | = |{ f^-1[ { y }]  }| = 1
where:
:Img( f ) denotes the image set of f
:| Â· | denotes the cardinality of a set
:f^-1(   )y is the preimage of y
:f^-1[ { y }] is the preimage of the subset { y }âŠ†Img( f ).


That is,  if and only if  the preimage of y is a singleton for all y in the image set of f.

=== Definition 5 ===
Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping where S âˆ….

Then f is an injection  if and only if :
:âˆƒ g: T â†’ S: g âˆ˜ f = I_S
where g is a mapping.


That is,  if and only if  f has a left inverse.

=== Definition 6 ===
Let f: S â†’ T be a mapping where S âˆ….

Then f is an injection  if and only if  f is left cancellable:
:âˆ€ X: âˆ€ g_1, g_2: X â†’ S: f âˆ˜ g_1 = f âˆ˜ g_2  g_1 = g_2
where g_1 and g_2 are arbitrary mappings from an arbitrary set X to the domain S of f.

title: Definition:One-to-One Relation
definition:
A relation â„›âŠ† S Ã— T is one-to-one if it is both many-to-one and one-to-many.


That is, every element of the domain of â„› relates to no more than one element of its codomain, and every element of the image is related to by exactly one element of its domain.

title: Definition:Orbit (Group Theory)
definition:
Let G be a group acting on a set X.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let G be a group acting on a set X.


The orbit of an element x âˆˆ X is defined as:

:Orb( x ) := { y âˆˆ X: âˆƒ g âˆˆ G: y = g * x }
where * denotes the group action.


That is, Orb( x ) = G * x.


Thus the orbit of an element is all its possible destinations under the group action.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let G be a group acting on a set X.


Let â„› be the relation on X defined as:
:âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ X: x â„› y âˆƒ g âˆˆ G: y = g * x

where * denotes the group action.


From Group Action Induces Equivalence Relation, â„› is an equivalence relation.


The orbit of x, denoted Orb( x ), is the equivalence class of x under â„›.

title: Definition:Orbit (Physics)
definition:
Let A and B be bodies in space.

The orbit of A around B is the path taken by A as it travels around B under the influence of the force acting between A and B.


=== Period of Orbit ===
Let body A be in orbit around body B.

The period of the orbit is the length of time it takes for A to travel once around B and return to its original position.

=== Radius of Orbit ===
Let body A be in orbit around body B.

Let ğ« be the position vector of the center of mass of A   the center of mass of B at a particular point in time.

The radius of the orbit of A around B is defined as:
:the position vector ğ«
or
:the length of ğ«.

Context will determine which is meant.

title: Definition:Dynamical System/Orbit
definition:
Let S be a dynamical system consisting of a mapping T and iteration x_n + 1 = T (   )x_n.


The orbit of x_0 is the set of points { x_0, x_1, x_2, â€¦}


When T is invertible, the orbit usually includes the points x_-1 = T^-1(   )x, x_-2 = T^-1(   )x_-1, â€¦

For a flow, the orbit of a point x is the union of all the points x (   )t for all t.

title: Definition:Orientation (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let G = ( V, E ) be a simple graph.

Let H = ( V, A ) be a digraph.


Then H is an orientation of G  if and only if  both of the following hold:

:(1):    H is a simple digraph. That is, A is antisymmetric.
:(2):   âˆ€ x, y âˆˆ V: ( { x, y }âˆˆ E ( x, y ) âˆˆ A ( y, x ) âˆˆ A )


That is, H is formed from G by replacing every edge of G with an arc.

title: Definition:Orientation of Differential Manifold
definition: An orientation of a differential manifold is a continuous choice of orientation for each of its tangent spaces.

title: Definition:Orientation of Coordinate Axes
definition:
The orientation of a coordinate system is the disposition of the coordinate axes relative to each other.


=== Cartesian Plane ===
There are 2 different orientations of a Cartesian plane:


:  


=== Right-Handed ===
A Cartesian plane is defined as being right-handed if it has the following property:

Let a right hand be placed, with palm uppermost, such that the thumb points along the x-axis in the positive direction, such that the thumb and index finger are at right-angles to each other.

Then the index finger is pointed along the y-axis in the positive direction.


:

=== Left-Handed ===
A Cartesian plane is defined as being left-handed if it has the following property:

Let a left hand be placed, with palm uppermost, such that the thumb points along the x-axis in the positive direction, such that the thumb and index finger are at right-angles to each other.

Then the index finger is pointed along the y-axis in the positive direction.


:

=== Cartesian 3-Space ===
There are 2 different orientations of a Cartesian 3-space:


:  


=== Right-Handed ===
A Cartesian 3-Space is defined as being right-handed if it has the following property:

Let a right hand be placed such that:
:the thumb and index finger are at right-angles to each other
:the 3rd finger is at right-angles to the thumb and index finger, upwards from the palm
:the thumb points along the x-axis in the positive direction
:the index finger points along the y-axis in the positive direction.

Then the 3rd finger is pointed along the z-axis in the positive direction.


:

=== Left-Handed ===
A Cartesian 3-Space is defined as being left-handed if it has the following property:

Let a left hand be placed such that:
:the thumb and index finger are at right-angles to each other
:the 3rd finger is at right-angles to the thumb and index finger, upwards from the palm
:the thumb points along the x-axis in the positive direction
:the index finger points along the y-axis in the positive direction.

Then the 3rd finger is pointed along the z-axis in the positive direction.


:

title: Definition:Orthogonal Curves
definition:
Let C_1 and C_2 be curves that intersect at a point P.

C_1 and C_2 are orthogonal at P  if and only if  the tangent line to C_1 at P is at right angles to the tangent line to C_2 at P.


=== Orthogonal Circles ===
Two circles are orthogonal if their angle of intersection is a right angle.


:

title: Definition:Orthogonal Coordinate System
definition:
An orthogonal coordinate system is a coordinate system in which the coordinate axes are pairwise perpendicular.


=== Orthogonal Curvilinear Coordinates ===
Let ğ’¦ be a curvilinear coordinate system in 3-space.

Let ğ’¬_1, ğ’¬_2 and ğ’¬_3 denote the one-parameter families that define the curvilinear coordinates.



Let the relation between those curvilinear coordinates and Cartesian coordinates be expressed as:

 
 
 
 
 

where:
:( x, y, z ) denotes the Cartesian coordinates of an arbitrary point P
:( q_1, q_2, q_3 ) denotes the curvilinear coordinates of P.


Let these equations have the property that the metric of ğ’¦ between coordinate surfaces of ğ’¬_i and ğ’¬_j is zero where i  j.


That is, for every point P expressible as ( x, y, z ) and ( q_1, q_2, q_3 ):

:âˆ‚ xâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ xâˆ‚ q_j + âˆ‚ yâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ yâˆ‚ q_j + âˆ‚ zâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ zâˆ‚ q_j = 0

wherever i  j.


Then ğ’¦ is an orthogonal curvilinear coordinate system.

=== Rectangular Coordinate System ===
A rectangular coordinate system is a Cartesian coordinate system in which each of the coordinate axes are perpendicular to each other.

title: Definition:Orthogonal Curvilinear Coordinates
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a curvilinear coordinate system in 3-space.

Let ğ’¬_1, ğ’¬_2 and ğ’¬_3 denote the one-parameter families that define the curvilinear coordinates.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let ğ’¦ be a curvilinear coordinate system in 3-space.

Let ğ’¬_1, ğ’¬_2 and ğ’¬_3 denote the one-parameter families that define the curvilinear coordinates.



Let the relation between those curvilinear coordinates and Cartesian coordinates be expressed as:

 
 
 
 
 

where:
:( x, y, z ) denotes the Cartesian coordinates of an arbitrary point P
:( q_1, q_2, q_3 ) denotes the curvilinear coordinates of P.


Let these equations have the property that the metric of ğ’¦ between coordinate surfaces of ğ’¬_i and ğ’¬_j is zero where i  j.


That is, for every point P expressible as ( x, y, z ) and ( q_1, q_2, q_3 ):

:âˆ‚ xâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ xâˆ‚ q_j + âˆ‚ yâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ yâˆ‚ q_j + âˆ‚ zâˆ‚ q_iâˆ‚ zâˆ‚ q_j = 0

wherever i  j.


Then ğ’¦ is an orthogonal curvilinear coordinate system.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ğ’¦ be a curvilinear coordinate system in 3-space.

Let ğ’¬_1, ğ’¬_2 and ğ’¬_3 denote the one-parameter families that define the curvilinear coordinates.

Let ( q_1, q_2, q_3 ) denote a set of curvilinear coordinates.

Let ğ’¦ have the property that for every arbitrary pair of coordinate surfaces q_i âˆˆğ’¬_i and q_j âˆˆğ’¬_j where i  j:

:q_i and q_j are orthogonal.


Then ğ’¦ is an orthogonal curvilinear coordinate system.

=== Scale Factor ===

title: Definition:Orthogonal Trajectories
definition:
Let f (   )x, y, c define a one-parameter family of curves F.

Let g (   )x, y, c also define a one-parameter family of curves G, with the property that:

:Every curve in F is orthogonal to every curve in G.


Then F is a family of (reciprocal) orthogonal trajectories of G, and contrariwise.

title: Definition:Orthogonal (Linear Algebra)
definition:
Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product space.

Let u, v âˆˆ V.


We say that u and v are orthogonal  if and only if :
:âŸ¨ u,   âŸ© v = 0

We denote this: 

:u âŠ¥ v


=== Orthogonal Set ===
Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product space.

Let S = { u_1, â€¦, u_n } be a subset of V.


Then S is an orthogonal set  if and only if  its elements are pairwise orthogonal:

:âˆ€ i  j: âŸ¨ u_i,   âŸ©u_j = 0

=== Orthogonality of Sets ===
Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product space.

Let A, B âŠ† V.

We say that A and B are orthogonal  if and only if :

:âˆ€ a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B: a âŠ¥ b

That is, if a and b are orthogonal elements of A and B for all a âˆˆ A and b âˆˆ B.


We write: 

:A âŠ¥ B

=== Orthogonal Complement ===
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product space.

Let SâŠ† V be a subset.


We define the orthogonal complement of S (with respect to âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·), written S^âŠ¥ as the set of all v âˆˆ V which are orthogonal to all s âˆˆ S.

That is: 

:S^âŠ¥ = { v âˆˆ V : âŸ¨ v,   âŸ© s = 0  for all  s âˆˆ S }


If S = { v } is a singleton, we may write S^âŠ¥ as v^âŠ¥.

=== Vectors in â„^n ===
Let ğ®, ğ¯ be vectors in â„^n.


Then ğ® and ğ¯ are said to be orthogonal  if and only if  their dot product is zero:

:ğ®Â·ğ¯ = 0


As Dot Product is Inner Product, this is a special case of the definition of orthogonal vectors.

title: Definition:Orthogonal (Bilinear Form)
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let b: V Ã— V â†’ğ•‚ be a reflexive bilinear form on V.

Let v,wâˆˆ V.


Then v and w are orthogonal (with respect to b)  if and only if  b (   )v, w = b (   )w, v = 0


This is denoted: v âŠ¥ w.


=== Orthogonal Subsets ===
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let b: V Ã— V â†’ğ•‚ be a reflexive bilinear form on V.

Let S, T âŠ‚ V be subsets.


Then S and T are orthogonal  if and only if  for all s âˆˆ S and t âˆˆ T, s and t are orthogonal: s âŠ¥ t.

=== Orthogonal Complement ===
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let b : VÃ— V â†’ğ•‚ be a reflexive bilinear form on V.

Let SâŠ‚ V be a subset.


The orthogonal complement of S (with respect to b) is the set of all v âˆˆ V which are orthogonal to all s âˆˆ S.


This is denoted: S^âŠ¥.

If S = { v } is a singleton, we also write v^âŠ¥.

=== Radical ===
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let b : VÃ— V â†’ğ•‚ be a reflexive bilinear form on V.


The radical of V is the orthogonal complement of V:
:rad(   )V = V^âŠ¥

title: Definition:Orthogonal (Linear Algebra)/Orthogonal Complement
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let ( V, âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·) be an inner product space.

Let SâŠ† V be a subset.


We define the orthogonal complement of S (with respect to âŸ¨Â·,   âŸ©Â·), written S^âŠ¥ as the set of all v âˆˆ V which are orthogonal to all s âˆˆ S.

That is: 

:S^âŠ¥ = { v âˆˆ V : âŸ¨ v,   âŸ© s = 0  for all  s âˆˆ S }


If S = { v } is a singleton, we may write S^âŠ¥ as v^âŠ¥.

title: Definition:Orthogonal (Bilinear Form)/Orthogonal Complement
definition:
Let ğ•‚ be a field.

Let V be a vector space over ğ•‚.

Let b : VÃ— V â†’ğ•‚ be a reflexive bilinear form on V.

Let SâŠ‚ V be a subset.


The orthogonal complement of S (with respect to b) is the set of all v âˆˆ V which are orthogonal to all s âˆˆ S.


This is denoted: S^âŠ¥.

If S = { v } is a singleton, we also write v^âŠ¥.

title: Definition:Oscillation (Analysis)
definition:
=== Real Space ===
Let X and Y be real sets.

Let f: X â†’ Y be a real function.

Let A âŠ† X be any non-empty subset A of X.


The oscillation of f on (or over) A is defined as:

:Ï‰_f (   )A := sup_x, y âˆˆ A| f (   )x - f (   )y |

where the supremum is taken in the extended real numbers R.


Category:Definitions/Oscillation

=== Metric Space ===
Let X be a set.

Let ( Y, d ) be a metric space.

Let f: X â†’ Y be a mapping.

Let A âŠ† X be any non-empty subset A of X.


The oscillation of f on (or over) A with respect to d, denoted Ï‰_f (   )A; d, is defined as the diameter of f [ A ]:

:Ï‰_f (   )A; d := diam(   )f [ A ] = sup_x, y âˆˆ A d (   )f (   )x, f (   )y

where the supremum is taken in the extended real numbers R.


The metric d is often suppressed from the notation if it is clear from context, in which case one would simply write Ï‰_f (   )A.

Similarly, one would speak of the oscillation of f on A in this case.


Category:Definitions/Metric Spaces

Category:Definitions/Oscillation

title: Definition:Oscillation (Physics)
definition:
Oscillation is a regular fluctuation in the magnitude of the displacement of a body about a particular position, value or state.

This usually occurs in the context of mechanical or electronic systems.


Thus, in the context of mechanics, an oscillation is an example of a periodic motion.


=== Period of Oscillation ===
Let B be a body undergoing oscillation.

The period of oscillation of B is the time taken for B to make one complete journey from one end of its path to the other and back again.


=== Symbol ===

title: Definition:Ordered Pair
definition:
The definition of a set does not take any account of the order in which the elements are listed.

That is, { a, b } = { b, a }, and the elements a and b have the same status - neither is distinguished above the other as being more "important".


=== Informal Definition ===
The definition of a set does not take any account of the order in which the elements are listed.

That is, { a, b } = { b, a }, and the elements a and b have the same status â€“ neither is distinguished above the other as being more "important".


An ordered pair is a two-element set together with an ordering.

In other words, one of the elements is distinguished above the other - it comes first.

Such a structure is written:
:( a, b )
and it means:
:first a, then b.


=== Coordinates ===
Let ( a, b ) be an ordered pair.

The following terminology is used:
:a is called the first coordinate
:b is called the second coordinate.

This definition is compatible with the equivalent definition in the context of Cartesian coordinate systems.

=== Kuratowski Formalization ===
The definition of a set does not take any account of the order in which the elements are listed.

That is, { a, b } = { b, a }, and the elements a and b have the same status - neither is distinguished above the other as being more "important".


The concept of an ordered pair can be formalized by the definition:

:( a, b ) := {{ a }, { a, b }}

This formalization justifies the existence of ordered pairs in Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory.


=== Coordinates ===
Let ( a, b ) be an ordered pair.

The following terminology is used:
:a is called the first coordinate
:b is called the second coordinate.

This definition is compatible with the equivalent definition in the context of Cartesian coordinate systems.

=== Empty Set Formalization ===
The concept of an ordered pair can be formalized by the definition:

:( a, b ) := {{âˆ…, a }, {{âˆ…}, b }}

=== Wiener Formalization ===
The concept of an ordered pair can be formalized by the definition:

:( a, b ) := {{âˆ…, { a }}, {{ b }}}

title: Definition:Doubleton
definition:
A doubleton is a set that contains exactly two elements.


The doubleton containing the distinct elements a and b can be written { a, b }.


The set { a, b } is known as the doubleton of a and b.


=== Class Theory Definition ===
Let a and b be sets.

The class { a, b } is a doubleton (class).

It is defined as the class of all x such that x = a or x = b:

:{ a, b } = { x: x = a  x = b: a  b }

title: Definition:Parallel (Geometry)/Lines
definition:
: 
:Parallel straight lines are straight lines which, being in the same plane and being produced indefinitely in either direction, do not meet one another in either direction.
 â€
 

The contemporary interpretation of the concept of parallelism declares that a straight line is parallel to itself.

title: Definition:Parallel (Geometry)/Planes
definition:
Two planes are parallel  if and only if , when produced indefinitely, do not intersect at any point.


 


The contemporary interpretation of the concept of parallelism declares that a plane is parallel to itself.

title: Definition:Parallel (Geometry)/Line to Plane
definition:
Let L be a straight line.

Let P be a plane.

Then L and P are parallel  if and only if , when produced indefinitely, they do not intersect at any point.

title: Definition:Parallel (Matroid)
definition:
Let M = ( S, â„) be a matroid.


Two elements x, y âˆˆ S are said to be parallel in M  if and only if  they are not loops but { x, y } is a dependent subset of S.


That is, x, y âˆˆ S are parallel  if and only if :
:{ x }, { y }âˆˆâ„ and { x, y }âˆ‰â„.

title: Definition:Parity of Integer
definition:
Let z âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

The parity of z is whether it is even or odd.


=== Even Parity ===
An integer z is of even parity  if and only if :
:z = 2 n
for some n âˆˆâ„¤.

=== Odd Parity ===
An integer z is of odd parity  if and only if :
:z = 2 n + 1
for some n âˆˆâ„¤.

=== Same Parity ===
Two integers z_1 and z_2 have the same parity  if and only if  either:
:z_1 and z_2 are both even
or:
:z_1 and z_2 are both odd.

=== Opposite Parity ===
Two integers z_1 and z_2 have opposite parity  if and only if  either:
:z_1 is even and z_2 is odd
or:
:z_2 is even and z_1 is odd.

title: Definition:Parity of Permutation
definition:
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters.

Let Ïâˆˆ S_n, that is, let Ï be a permutation of S_n.

The parity of Ï is defined as follows:


=== Even Permutation ===
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters.

Let Ïâˆˆ S_n be a permutation in S_n.


Ï is an even permutation  if and only if :
:sgn(   )Ï = 1
where sgn denotes the sign function.

=== Odd Permutation ===
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters.

Let Ïâˆˆ S_n be a permutation in S_n.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters.

Let Ïâˆˆ S_n be a permutation in S_n.


Ï is an odd permutation  if and only if  Ï is equivalent to an odd number of transpositions.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„• be a natural number.

Let S_n denote the symmetric group on n letters.

Let Ïâˆˆ S_n be a permutation in S_n.


Ï is an odd permutation  if and only if :
:sgn(   )Ï = -1
where sgn denotes the sign function.

where sgn(   )Ï denotes the sign of Ï.

title: Definition:Path (Topology)
definition:
Let T = ( S, Ï„) be a topological space.

Let I âŠ‚â„ be the closed real interval [ a  . . ]b.


A path in T is a continuous mapping Î³: I â†’ S.


The mapping Î³ can be referred as:
:a path (in T) joining Î³(   )a and Î³(   )b
or:
:a path (in T) from Î³(   )a to Î³(   )b.


It is common to refer to a point z = Î³(   )t as a point on the path Î³, even though z is in fact on the image of Î³.


=== Initial Point ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let I âŠ‚â„ be the closed real interval [ a  . . ]b.

Let Î³: I â†’ T be a path in T.


The initial point of Î³ is Î³(   )a.

That is, the path starts (or begins) at Î³(   )a.

=== Final Point ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let I âŠ‚â„ be the closed real interval [ a  . . ]b.

Let Î³: I â†’ T be a path in T.


The final point of Î³ is Î³(   )b.

That is, the path ends (or finishes) at Î³(   )b.

=== Endpoint ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let I âŠ‚â„ be the closed real interval [ a  . . ]b.

Let Î³: I â†’ T be a path in T.


The initial point and final point of Î³ can be referred to as the endpoints of Î³


Category:Definitions/Path-Connected Spaces

=== Composable Paths ===
Let T be a topological space.

Let f, g: [ 0  . . ]1 â†’ T be paths.


f and g are said to be composable paths if:

:f (   )1 = g (   )0.

title: Definition:Path (Graph Theory)
definition:
Let G be an undirected graph.

A path in G is a trail in G in which all vertices (except perhaps the first and last ones) are distinct.


A path between two vertices u and v is called a u-v path.


=== Subgraph ===
The set of vertices and edges which go to make up a path in a graph G form a subgraph of G.

This subgraph itself is also referred to as a path in G.

=== Open Path ===
An open path is a path in which the first and last vertices are distinct.



=== Endpoint of Open Path ===
Let P be an open path in a graph G.

The endpoints of P are its first and last vertices.


Category:Definitions/Paths (Graph Theory)

title: Definition:Path (Graph Theory)/Digraph
definition:
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

A path P in D is:
:a sequence of vertices v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_n in V and a sequence of arcs e_1, e_2, â€¦, e_n - 1 in E such that:
:P begins with v_1 and ends with v_n
:in which each arc e_j is incident from v_j and incident to v_j + 1
:all arcs are distinct
:all vertices (except perhaps the first and last ones) are distinct.

A path between two vertices u and v is called a path from u to v.


=== Predecessor ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let P be a path in D such that the vertices of P are v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_n.

Let v_j be a vertex of P such that j > 1.

Then the predecessor (vertex) of v_j is the vertex v_j - 1.


That is, if v â†’ w is an arc in P, v is the predecessor (vertex) of w.

=== Successor ===
Let D = ( V, E ) be a digraph.

Let P be a path in D such that the vertices of P are v_1, v_2, â€¦, v_n.

Let v_j be a vertex of P such that j < n.

Then the successor (vertex) of v_j is the vertex v_j + 1.


That is, if v â†’ w is an arc in P, w is the successor (vertex) of v.

title: Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)
definition:
A cycle is a circuit in which no vertex except the first (which is also the last) appears more than once.


An n-cycle is a cycle with n vertices.


=== Subgraph ===
The set of vertices and edges which go to make up a cycle form a subgraph.

This subgraph itself is also referred to as a cycle.

=== Odd Cycle ===
An odd cycle is a cycle with odd length, that is, with an odd number of edges.

=== Even Cycle ===
An even cycle is a cycle with even length, that is, with an even number of edges.

title: Definition:Perfect Number
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A perfect number is a (strictly) positive integer equal to its aliquot sum.


=== Sequence of Perfect Numbers ===
 

=== Definition 2 ===
A perfect number n is a (strictly) positive integer such that:
:Ïƒ_1 (   )n= 2 n
where Ïƒ_1: â„¤_>0â†’â„¤_>0 is the divisor sum function.


=== Sequence of Perfect Numbers ===
 

=== Definition 3 ===
Let n âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0 be a positive integer.


Let A (   )n denote the abundance of n.

n is perfect  if and only if  A (   )n = 0.


=== Sequence of Perfect Numbers ===
 

=== Definition 4 ===
A perfect number n is a (strictly) positive integer such that:
:Ïƒ_1 (   )n n = 2
where Ïƒ_1: â„¤_>0â†’â„¤_>0 is the divisor sum function.


=== Sequence of Perfect Numbers ===

title: Definition:Perfect Set
definition:
=== Definition 1 ===
A perfect set of a topological space T = (S, Ï„) is a subset H âŠ† S such that:
:H = H'
where H' is the derived set of H.

That is, where:
:every point of H is a limit point of H
and
:every limit point of H is a point of H.

=== Definition 2 ===
A perfect set of a topological space T = (S, Ï„) is a subset H âŠ† S such that:
: H is a closed set of T
: H has no isolated points.

=== Definition 3 ===
A perfect set of a topological space T = ( S, Ï„) is a subset H âŠ† S such that:
:H is dense-in-itself.
:H contains all its limit points.

title: Definition:Perfect Graph
definition: A graph is perfect if no two vertices have the same degree.

title: Definition:Perfect Group
definition:
A perfect group is a group which is its own derived subgroup.

That is, it is a group G such that:
:G = G'
where G' is the derived subgroup of G.

title: Definition:Perfect Field
definition:
Let F be a field.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let F be a field.


F is a perfect field   if and only if  F has no inseparable extensions.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let F be a field.


F is a perfect field  if and only if  one of the following holds:
:Char( F ) = 0
:Char( F ) = p with p prime and Frob is an automorphism of F

where:
:Char( F ) denotes the characteristic of F
:Frob denotes the Frobenius endomorphism on F

title: Definition:Helix/Pitch
definition: The pitch of a helix â„‹ is the distance by which a point on â„‹ is displaced in making 1 revolution around the axis of â„‹ in a direction parallel to the axis.

title: Definition:Pitch (Mechanics)
definition:
Let B be a body in motion through a fluid while subject to a gravitational field.

In practice, this will be an aircraft, spacecraft or projectile, or a ship on the sea, for example.


The pitch of the motion of B is the angular motion of B about a horizontal axis perpendicular to the direction of motion of B.

title: Definition:Polar Coordinates/Polar Axis
definition:
Let O be the pole of the polar coordinate plane.


A ray is drawn from O, usually to the right, and referred to as the polar axis.

title: Definition:Polar Equation
definition:
A polar equation is an equation defining the locus of a set of points in the polar coordinate plane.

Such an equation is generally presented in terms of the variables:
:r: the radial coordinate
:Î¸: the angular coordinate

title: Definition:Polar of Point
definition:
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section embedded in a Euclidean plane.

Let P be a given point in that plane.


=== Definition 1 ===
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section embedded in a Euclidean plane.

Let P be a given point in that plane.


Let a variable secant line pass through P and intersect ğ’¦ at L and M.


The polar of P   ğ’¦ is the locus of the intersections of the tangents to ğ’¦ at L and M.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ğ’¦ be a conic section embedded in a Euclidean plane.

Let P be a given point in that plane.


Let L and M be the points of contact between ğ’¦ and the tangents (whether real or imaginary) to ğ’¦ passing through P.


The polar of P   ğ’¦ is the straight line LM.

=== Circle ===
Let ğ’ be a circle embedded in a Cartesian plane.

Let P be a given point in that plane.

Let a variable secant line pass through P and intersect ğ’ at L and M.


The polar of P with respect to ğ’ is the locus of the intersections of the tangents to ğ’ at L and M.


=== Pole ===
Let ğ’ be a circle embedded in the plane.

Let P be a given point in the plane.


Let â„’ be the polar of P with respect to ğ’.

Then P is known as the pole of â„’.

=== Ellipse ===
Let ğ’¦ be an ellipse embedded in a Euclidean plane.

Let P be a given point in that plane.

Let a variable secant line pass through P and intersect ğ’¦ at L and M.


The polar of P with respect to ğ’¦ is the locus of the intersections of the tangents to ğ’¦ at L and M.


:


:

title: Definition:Spherical Coordinate System/Polar Axis
definition: The polar axis of a spherical coordinate system is the vertical straight line which passes through the origin O.

title: Definition:Polar Triangle
definition:
Let ABC be a spherical triangle on the surface of a sphere whose center is O.

Let the sides a, b, c of ABC be measured by the angles subtended at O, where a, b, c are opposite A, B, C respectively.


Let A', B' and C' be the poles of the sides BC, AC and AB respectively which are in the same hemisphere as the points A, B and C respectively.

:

Then the spherical triangle A'B'C' is the polar triangle of ABC.

title: Definition:Polar Vector
definition: A polar vector is a vector quantity whose action is along a line drawn in the direction of the vector itself.

title: Definition:Discontinuity (Real Analysis)/Infinite
definition:
Let X âŠ†â„ be a subset of the real numbers.

Let f: X â†’â„ be a real function.

Let f be discontinuous at c âˆˆ X.


f is an infinite discontinuity on f  if and only if  | f (   )x | becomes arbitrarily large as | x - c | becomes arbitrarily small.

title: Definition:Isolated Singularity/Pole
definition:
Let U be an open subset of a Riemann surface.

Let z_0 âˆˆ U.

Let f: U âˆ–{ z_0 }â†’â„‚ be a holomorphic function.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let U be an open subset of a Riemann surface.

Let z_0 âˆˆ U.

Let f: U âˆ–{ z_0 }â†’â„‚ be a holomorphic function.


Let z_0 be an isolated singularity of f.

Then z_0 is a pole  if and only if :
:lim_z â†’ z_0| f (   )z |â†’âˆ

=== Definition 2 ===
Let U be an open subset of a Riemann surface.

Let z_0 âˆˆ U.

Let f: U âˆ–{ z_0 }â†’â„‚ be a holomorphic function.


Let z_0 be an isolated singularity of f.

Then z_0 is a pole  if and only if  f can be written in the form:
:f (   )z = Ï•(   )z( z - z_0 )^k
where:
:Ï• is analytic at z_0
:Ï•(   )z_0 0
:k âˆˆâ„¤ such that k â‰¥ 1.

=== Order of Pole ===
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a complex function.


Let z_0 âˆˆ U âŠ‚â„‚ be such that f is holomorphic in U âˆ–{ z_0 }, with a pole at z_0.

By Existence of Laurent Series there is a series:

:f (   )z = âˆ‘_n â‰¥ n_0^âˆ a_j ( z - z_0 )^n

The order of the pole at z_0 is defined to be | n_0 | > 0.

=== Simple Pole ===
Let f: â„‚â†’â„‚ be a complex function.


Let z_0 âˆˆ U âŠ‚â„‚ be such that f is holomorphic in U âˆ–{ z_0 }, with a pole at z_0.

Let the order of the pole at z_0 be 1.

Then z_0 is a simple pole.

title: Definition:Polar Coordinates/Pole
definition:
Consider a system of polar coordinates used to identify points on the plane.

Let O be the distinct point identified as the center of the frame.


The point O is referred to as the pole of the polar coordinate plane.

title: Definition:Pole of Circle
definition:
Let S be a sphere whose center is O.

Let AB be a diameter of S, such that A and B are the points of intersection of AB with S.

Let C be a (small) circle of S embedded in a plane perpendicular to AB.
 

:


The points A and B are the poles of the circle C.


=== Special Case: Pole of Great Circle ===
This is a special case of the pole of a circle.


Let S be a sphere whose center is O.

Let C be a great circle of S.

Let AB be the diameter of S situated perpendicular to the plane of C.


:


The points A and B, where the diameter intersects S, are the poles of the great circle C.

title: Definition:Earth's Poles/North
definition:
Let an observer A be situated on Earth's equator.

Let A be facing the direction of Earth's rotation in space about its axis.


Then the North Pole is the particular one of Earth's poles which is on the left of A.


:

title: Definition:Earth's Poles/South
definition:
Let an observer A be situated on Earth's equator.

Let A be facing the direction of Earth's rotation in space about its axis.


Then the South Pole is the particular one of Earth's poles which is on the right of A.


:

title: Definition:Positive Definite (Ring)
definition:
Let ( R, +, Ã—) be a ring whose zero is denoted 0_R.

Let f: R â†’â„ be a (real-valued) function on R.


Then f is positive definite  if and only if :

:âˆ€ x âˆˆ R:  f (   )x = 0     : x = 0_R 
 f (   )x > 0     : x  0_R

title: Definition:Positive Definite Matrix
definition:
Let ğ€ be a symmetric square matrix of order n.

=== Definition 1 ===
Let ğ€ be a symmetric square matrix of order n.

ğ€ is positive definite  if and only if :
:for all nonzero column matrices ğ± of order n, ğ±^âŠºğ€ğ± is strictly positive.

=== Definition 2 ===
Let ğ€ be a symmetric square matrix of order n.

ğ€ is positive definite  if and only if :
:all the eigenvalues of ğ€ are strictly positive.

title: Definition:Positive Definite Vector Space
definition:
Let ğ• be a vector space such that:
:âˆ€ğ¯âˆˆğ•: ğ¯Â·ğ¯ > 0
where ğ¯Â·ğ¯ denotes the dot product.


Then ğ• is a positive definite vector space.

title: Definition:Power (Algebra)
definition:
=== Natural Numbers ===
Let â„• denote the natural numbers.


For each m âˆˆâ„•, recursively define e_m: â„•â†’â„• to be the mapping:
:e_m (   )n =  1     : n = 0 
 m Ã— e_m (   )x     : n = x + 1
where:
:+ denotes natural number addition.
:Ã— denotes natural number multiplication.


e_m (   )n is then expressed as a binary operation in the form:
:m^n := e_m (   )n

and is called m to the power of n.

=== Integers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

The expression x^n is called x to the power of n.

x^n is defined recursively as:


:x^n =  1     : n = 0 
   
 x Ã— x^n - 1    : n > 0 
   
x^n + 1 x     : n < 0

where x^n + 1 x denotes division.


=== Even Power ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an even integer.


Then x^n is called an even power of x.


Category:Definitions/Integer Powers
Category:Definitions/Even Integers

=== Odd Power ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

Let n âˆˆâ„¤ be an odd integer.


Then x^n is called an odd power of x


Category:Definitions/Integer Powers
Category:Definitions/Odd Integers

=== Rational Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„ be a real number such that x > 0.

Let m âˆˆâ„¤ be an integer.

Let y = âˆš(x) be the mth root of x.


Then we can write y = x^1/m which means the same thing as y = âˆš(x).


Thus we can define the power to a positive rational number:

Let r =  p q âˆˆâ„š be a positive rational number where p âˆˆâ„¤_â‰¥ 0, q âˆˆâ„¤_> 0.

Then x^r is defined as:
:x^r = x^p/q = ( âˆš(x))^p = âˆš(( x^p ) )


When r = -p q âˆˆâ„š: r < 0 we define:
:x^r = x^-p/q =  1 x^p/q
analogously for the negative integer definition.

=== Real Numbers ===
Let x âˆˆâ„_>0 be a (strictly) positive real number.

Let r âˆˆâ„ be a real number.


We define x^r as:

:x^r := exp(   )r ln x
where exp denotes the exponential function.


This definition is an extension of the definition for rational r.

This follows from Logarithms of Powers and Exponential of Natural Logarithm: it can be seen that:
:âˆ€ r âˆˆâ„š: exp(   )r ln x = exp(   )ln(   )x^r = x^r

 

=== Complex Numbers ===
Let z, k âˆˆâ„‚ be complex numbers.


z to the power of k is defined as the multifunction:

:z^k := e^k ln( z )

where:
:e^z is the exponential function
:ln is the  natural logarithm multifunction.


=== Principal Branch ===
The principal branch of a complex number raised to a complex power is defined as:

:z^k = e^k Ln z

where Ln z is the principal branch of the natural logarithm.


=== Positive Real Base ===
Let t > 0 be a real number and let k be a complex number.


The principal branch of a positive real number raised to a complex power is defined as:

:t^k = e^k ln t

where ln is the natural logarithm of a positive real number.


Category:Definitions/Complex Powers

Category:Definitions/Complex Powers

=== Multiindices ===
Let k = âŸ¨k_jâŸ©_j = 1, â€¦, n be a multiindex indexed by { 1, â€¦, n }.

Let x = ( x_1, â€¦, x_n ) âˆˆâ„^n be an ordered tuple of real numbers.


Then x^k is defined as:

:x^k := âˆ_j  = 1^n x_j^k_j
where the powers on the   are integer powers.


Category:Definitions/Analysis

=== Power of Zero ===
Let r âˆˆâ„ be a real number.

(This includes the situation where r âˆˆâ„¤ or r âˆˆâ„š.)

When x=0, x^r is defined as follows:

:0^r =  1     : r = 0 
 0     : r > 0 
Undefined    : r < 0

This takes account of the awkward case 0^0: it is "generally accepted" that 0^0 = 1 as this convention agrees with certain general results which would otherwise need a special case.

Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity element is e.

The definition a^n = âˆ˜^n (   )a as the nth power of a in a semigroup can be extended to allow an exponent of 0:

=== Invertible Element ===
Let ( S, âˆ˜) be a monoid whose identity element is e.

The definition b^n = âˆ˜^n (   )b as the nth power of b in (S, âˆ˜) can be extended to include the inverse of b:

:b^-n = ( b^-1)^n

definition:

 g^n - 1âˆ˜ g     : n > 0

or

:n Â· g =  e     : n = 0 
( ( n - 1 ) Â· g ) âˆ˜ g     : n > 0 
 -( -n Â· g )     : n < 0

The validity of this definition follows from the group axioms: g has an inverse element.

title: Definition:Prime Ideal of Ring

definition:
Let I be an ideal in an ordered set S.


Then I is a prime ideal in S  if and only if  S âˆ– I is a filter.

definition:

title: Definition:Primitive Curve
definition: A primitive curve is a curve from which some other curve is derived.

title: Definition:Primitive Element of Field Extension
definition:
Let F / K be a simple field extension such that F = K (   )Î±.
